                              33 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            October 7, 2014 Tuesday

Farm Loan Pilot Projects

LENGTH: 2033  words

DATELINE: Washington, DC


Office of Federal Register, Government of US has issued the following news
release:


Action

Notice And Request For Comment.
Summary

The Farm Service Agency (FSA) will conduct pilot projects of limited scope and
duration to evaluate processes and techniques that may improve the efficiency
and effectiveness of the Farm Loan Programs (FLP) real estate loans (also
referred to as "farm ownership loans"), operating loans, emergency loans, and
administrative provisions, as required by the Agricultural Act of 2014 (the 2014
Farm Bill). This notice provides an opportunity for the public to provide
comments for FSA to consider for pilot projects. FSA expects to conduct at least
two to three pilot projects.

Table of Contents Back to Top

DATES:
    ADDRESSES:
    FOR FURTHER INFORMATION CONTACT:
    SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION:
    Background
    FLP Pilot Projects

DATES: Back to Top

We will consider comments that we receive by November 7, 2014.
ADDRESSES: Back to Top

We invite you to submit comments on this notice. In your comment, include
volume, date, and page number of this issue of the Federal Register. You may
submit comments by any of the following methods:

Federal eRulemaking Portal: Go to http://www.regulations.gov. Follow the online
instructions for submitting comments.
    Mail: Carrie L. Novak, Senior Loan Officer, LMD DAFLP FSA, US Department of
Agriculture, 1400 Independence Avenue SW., Stop 0522, Washington, DC 20250-0522.

Comments will be available for viewing online at http://www.regulations.gov. In
addition, comments will be available for public inspection at the above address
during business hours from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Friday, except
holidays.
FOR FURTHER INFORMATION CONTACT: Back to Top

Carrie Novak; phone: (202) 720-1643. Persons with disabilities who require
alternative means for communication of information for this notice (Braille,
large print, audiotape, etc.) should contact USDA's TARGET Center at (202)
720-2600 (voice).
SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION: Back to Top

Background Back to Top

FSA makes and services a variety of direct and guaranteed loans to farmers who
are temporarily unable to obtain private commercial credit. FSA also provides
direct loan customers with credit counseling and supervision to enhance their
opportunity for success. FSA loan applicants are often beginning farmers and
socially disadvantaged farmers who do not qualify for conventional loans because
of insufficient net worth or established farmers who have suffered financial
setbacks due to natural disasters or economic downturns. FSA loans are tailored
to a customer's needs and may be used to buy farmland and to finance
agricultural production.

FSA makes direct and guaranteed operating and farm ownership loans to eligible
farmers and ranchers. Under its direct operating loan program, FSA also makes
loans to youths to establish and operate income-producing projects of modest
size in connection with their participation in 4-H clubs, Future Farmers of
America, and similar organizations. Guaranteed loans are made through private
lenders with a guarantee of up to 95 percent of the loss of principal and
interest. Direct and guaranteed operating loans can be used to purchase
livestock, equipment, feed, seed, and other material essential to a farm or
ranch operation.

Direct and guaranteed farm ownership loan funds may be used to purchase land,
construct buildings, or make farm improvements. Guaranteed operating and farm
ownership loans may also be used to refinance debt. FSA also provides assistance
to beginning and socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers under its Direct
Farm Ownership Down Payment Loan Program, and provides retiring farmers the
opportunity to transfer their land to future generations of farmers and
ranchers.

FSA also targets a portion of its direct and guaranteed operating loan and farm
ownership loan funds to beginning farmers and ranchers and socially
disadvantaged applicants.

Emergency loans are available to established farmers and ranchers who have
suffered losses as a result of a natural disaster or quarantine.
FLP Pilot Projects Back to Top

Section 5302 of the 2014 Farm Bill amends the Consolidated Farm and Rural
Development Act (also known as the CONACT) to provide the Secretary authority to
conduct pilot projects of limited scope and duration to evaluate processes and
techniques that may improve the efficiency and effectiveness of real estate
loans, operating loans, emergency loans, and administrative provisions (7 U.S.C.
1983d). Processes and techniques can be as specific as the manner in which
applications for assistance are submitted (for example, through electronic
submissions), or as broad as more effective methods of outreach on programs for
existing and potential customers.

FSA is constantly identifying ways to improve services and is interested in
hearing what kinds of pilots our customers, stakeholders, and other members of
the public want to see. FSA wants to hear how we can better serve our customers
and understand their needs. The following are examples of initiatives that FSA
has already taken to improve efficiency and effectiveness for FLP.

One way that FSA has made improvements is by expanding credit opportunities for
farmers and ranchers with the Microloan Program. A Microloan is a small direct
farm operating loan with a shortened application process and reduced paperwork.
In addition, modifications were made to the experience requirement to allow for
mentors and apprenticeships. This has already helped farmers.

FSA has recently released a recent package of technology enhancements that
include Web access for handheld and smartphone users, as well as a more
efficient and timely option for receiving news and critical program information.
The technology improvements will allow users of FSA information to gain access
to easy-to-read data, including key features such as loan deficiency payment
rates, posted county prices, FSA news releases and AskFSA, the agency's online
self-help knowledge base.

A recently revised policy allows FSA to issue farm loan guarantees to
nontraditional lenders. A nontraditional lender is one that does not typically
hold deposit accounts and is not subject to oversight and supervision. The most
common nontraditional lenders are those who are funded under the U.S. Department
of Treasury's Community Development Financial Institutions Fund. Nontraditional
lenders can originate, hold and service guaranteed loans. The goal is to improve
and maintain the quality of rural communities. This goal is accomplished by
assisting rural communities, individuals, groups, and support organizations with
viable rural development enterprises. FSA has worked with traditional lenders in
the past, but is now expanding to work with both traditional and nontraditional
lenders.

FSA is currently operating a pilot project in digital signatures. The Electronic
Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act (Pub. L. 106-229) ensures that a
signature, contract, or other record relating to such transaction may not be
denied legal effect, validity, or enforceability solely because it is in
electronic form. It is an FSA policy decision whether a certain electronic
format is practicable for a certain transaction.

This digital signature pilot will allow FSA to evaluate the use of this
available technology, potential cost and time savings, and determine whether it
is practical for FLP and Farm Programs (FP) purposes. This will assist FSA to
develop policy to not only allow the use of digital signatures by FSA officials,
but by producers, FLP applicants, borrowers, and lenders as well. The pilot is
to be conducted in Indiana and Texas; digital signatures are only authorized for
certain FLP and FP documents.

FSA is requesting comments that will be used to develop recommendations for
pilot projects that will meet the intended goals to evaluate processes and
techniques that may improve the efficiency and effectiveness of real estate
loans, operating loans, emergency loans, and administrative provisions. The
pilot projects may diverge from program regulations at 7 CFR parts 761 through
767, but the pilot projects must be consistent with the existing statutory
provisions governing Real Estate Loans, Operating Loans, Emergency Loans, and
Administrative Provisions (see 7 U.S.C. Chapter 50, subchapters I through IV for
the details of these CONACT provisions). For example, a suggestion could be for
projects that provide financial and management assistance to eligible family
farmers for authorized loan purposes. Additional information on FLP policies and
procedures is available in FSA handbooks 1-FLP through 6-FLP at
http://www.fsa.usda.gov/FSA/webapp?area=home&subject=lare&topic=hbk.

The following questions provide examples of loan making and servicing concerns
that may be helpful to consider for your comment:

How can FSA better reach and serve veterans, especially returning veterans who
plan to start or return to farming?
    How can FSA encourage lending for urban agriculture?
    What pricing models can be developed or expanded to assist loan officers in
lending to producers who sell traditional and specialty agricultural products at
non-traditional markets?
    What types of borrower training systems can be explored to provide long term
economic benefits to agricultural producers?
    Should FSA explore the use of credit scores for small, streamlined loan
applications?
    Are there alternative lenders and financers (grocery chains, implement and
feed dealers, community development organizations) that could partner and
improve service to joint customers as well as strengthen their own business
needs?
    What type of consulting service could be developed to assist existing
borrowers to be more productive and successful?
    How can the role of a mentor be expanded beyond microloans?
    What are other methods that an applicant can successfully prove experience
and managerial ability?

In your comment it will be most helpful to:

Explain the proposed pilot project in as much detail as possible, including the
issue or concern to be addressed and the intended benefit(s);
    Provide specific examples to illustrate your points;
    Describe whether the project is intended to benefit any particular region,
type of agricultural producer (organic, direct market, wholesale, etc.), or end
customer; and
    Outline any potential costs or costs savings and the basis for the
assumptions.

At the conclusion of the comment period, FSA staff will review and consider all
of the suggestions in the comments.

As required by the 2014 Farm Bill, at least 60 days before initiating a pilot
project, the Secretary will submit notice of the proposed pilot project to the
Committee on Agriculture of the House of Representatives and the Committee on
Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry of the Senate. FSA will also consider any
feedback provided to the Secretary in response to that notice.

FSA expects to select at least two to three pilot projects. FSA will announce
the pilot projects through news release.

FSA expects that one of the results of the pilot project will help expand
service to underserved producers. For example, in remote areas, such as Indian
Country, distance and travel time make it extremely difficult to establish the
network of contacts essential for effective outreach and to provide technical
assistance. FSA lacks the necessary knowledge and staff resources to overcome
language and cultural barriers for some minority communities and provide
effective outreach and technical assistance. In such situations, partnerships
with local organizations could use existing networks and expertise to provide
effective outreach and technical assistance and expand participation. This is
one example of how FSA may carry out some pilot projects.

In addition to this notice, general information about FSA's administration of
FLP is also available on the FSA Web site at
http://www.fsa.usda.gov/FSA/webapp?area=home&subject=fmlp&topic=landing.

Signed on September 30, 2014.

Val Dolcini,

Administrator, Farm Service Agency.

                              The American Banker

As the 'Green Line' Advances, Some Farmers Still Lack Needed Funds

                            March 28, 1985, Thursday

By RICHARD RINGER

DATELINE: CHICAGO


A farmer writing a check for seed suddenly paused when he heard other farmers
near him moaning because they lacked the money to do the same.

''I better go check with my banker,'' the farmer told the seed dealer upon
hearing the sighs of his fellow farmers. ''I may be worse off than I thought I
was.''

That incident, retold by Richard Johnson, general manager of Minneapolis-based
Cargill Seeds, bespeaks the financial condition of many farmers as another
planting season approaches. Farmers either have obtained loans to buy the seed
and fertilizer to stay in business for another year, or they are trying
desperately to find financing.

Traditionally, March 1 is when farmers try to have their operating or production
loans arranged. The date is partly a psychological deadline for farmers. In most
parts of the country, soggy fields and inclement weather make planting
impossible for at least several more weeks. But if a farmer has his credit lined
up, a big worry is weeded out.

Yet with March almost gone, some farmers still have to worry about getting a
loan. For these farmers, the accumulated debt of the last several years and the
unlikelihood of making a profit this year erodes their chances of getting a loan
this spring.

Seed is among the first purchases farmers make after getting operating loans
approved, and seed dealers typically prefer to make cash sales. Any credit that
is extended is of the short-term variety. Early sales trends of seed, therefore,
provide a reasonable indication of just how tight credit conditions are, as well
as the number of farmers who qualify for or anticipate getting loans.

So far, seed companies report good sales volume. Early sales figures at Cargill
Seed are up several million dollars over the same time last year, said Mr.
Johnson, the company's general manager. Mr. Johnson attributed much of the gain
to discounts that are available to farmers who purchase seed early, a program
many of the large seed companies offer.

Uncollected Payments Up

At the same time, Mr. Johnson said uncollected payments carried over to this
year are double that of three years ago. And the fact that sale cancellations
are beginning to increase may be a strong indication that some farmers are
finding it difficult to get operating loans.

Farmers apparently can't get loans for purchases, or, if they rent land to farm,
are cutting back on the acreage they intend to plant this year, said Mr.
Johnson.

Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc., a Des Moines company that is among the
largest sellers of corn seed, reports that early indications for sales volume of
all seeds during the company's quarter ending Feb. 28 was about equal to last
year's mark. However, the preliminary results show that the number of customers
is down a bit, said Jim Ansorge, the company's manager of financial relations.

That could mean fewer farmers may get loans for planting, but those farmers will
be planting all or nearly all their tillable acreage.

Some farmers, said Mr. Ansorge, may have delayed buying seed because they have
not yet satisfactorily completed the paperwork that commercial banks and other
lenders now require in applying for loans. The documentation is a ''new
experience for some,'' said Mr. Ansorge.

Whatever the case, the ''green line'' - or the line demarcating the region where
good weather has arrived to enable farmers to plant - is now in Oklahoma and
quickly moving northward. And unless the farmers without loan agreements soon
get them, it may be too late. ''It's going to be an interesting 30 days and a
tough 30 days for a lot of farmers who don't have financing arranged,''
Cargill's Mr. Johnson recently predicted.

Time Growing Short

''It's getting a little late'' if farmers don't have credit arranged, said James
D. Herrington, chairman and president of the Coldwater National Bank in
Coldwater, Kan., which is north of the Oklahoma border. The bank has assets of
$11 million, 90% of it in agricultural-related loans.

Land used for grazing cattle is already turning green, and farmers are beginning
to prepare the land for planting in the Coldwater area, said Mr.  Herrington.
Yet every week, two or three farmers who have been told by their previous
lenders that loans won't be extended this year stray into the Coldwater bank
hoping to get a loan. But Coldwater National isn't making loans to any new
customers, said Mr. Herrington.

Francis A. Voit, executive vice president of Citizens State Bank of Loyal, Wis.,
is expecting a rush of farmers in the next several weeks seeking operating
loans. With almost a month elapsed after the March 1 deadline, about 40% of the
bank's agricultural borrowers have not arranged operating credits.  The bank,
which has about 70% of its $38 million in assets in agricultural related loans,
is located in Wisconsin's dairy region. The difference between dairy and grain
farming allows operating loans for dairymen to be made later than those for
grain farmers.

Still, the number of farmers with operating loans not in place by the beginning
of March was higher than normal, said Mr. Voit.

Farmers applying for loans are finding more stringent credit standards.  There
is little lending being done on the basis of the appraised value of farm land.
Today, farmers must be able to show not only that they can make a profit but the
ability to repay their debts.

Closer Scrutiny in Dairy Country

The Bank of Osseo, Osseo, Wis., is taking a ''harder look'' than ever before at
farm borrowers, said Greg Le Gare, an agricultural representative at the bank,
also in the dairy region. Mr. Le Gare said that with about two-thirds of loan
analysis completed, his bank has concluded that about 3% of last year's
borrowers won't get credit this year. He characterized that number as being ''a
shade higher'' than normal.

Included in the tougher analysis, said Mr. Le Gare, is a statistical look of the
farm's operating expenses and income. ''Some people are looking at it real good,
and some people won't want to look at their mess,'' he said.

Gene Malone, assistant director of information for the American Farm Bureau
Federation, said that the number of farmers encountering problems qualifying for
operating loans has been increasing. He estimated that between 8% and 12% of the
nation's farmers are having a difficult time getting operating loans from
commercial banks, Production Credit Associations, and the Farmers Home
Administration.

A survey published earlier this month by the U.S. Department of Agriculture
found that 70,000 farms of all sizes, or 3.2% of the 2.2 million farms in the
country, were technically insolvent at the start of the year.

In addition, another 73,000 farms, or 3.3% of all farms, had debts equal to 70%
of assets. The report noted that at current levels of interest rates and farm
income, farmers with debts equaling 40% of total assets face cash flow problems
and financial stress.

Farm banks are ''not lending any more than they have to,'' said Steven R.
Schroll, an analyst with Dain Bosworth Inc. in Minneapolis. The banks are
restructuring prior loans and servicing existing loans but aren't making many
new loans, he said.

Farmers, too, aren't finding much help from the federal government, said Mr.
Schroll. He said that not much of the $650 million the government set aside for
farm operating loans has been disbursed to farmers.

                                     Agweek

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 23, 2009 Tuesday

FSA loan programs gain in tightening ag economy

BYLINE: Mikkel Pates, Agweek Magazine

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 936 words


Jun. 23--FARGO, N.D. -- Demand for the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm
Service Agency loans in the region is higher than normal and has overtopped the
available funds in some categories, although administrators expect those funds
to be available as a bill passes Congress.

Curt Thoreson, farm loan program director FSA in North Dakota, says his agency
since last December has changed its unofficial slogan from the "Lender of Last
Resort" to the "Lender of First Opportunity" to emphasize its beginning farmer
programs.

"Here in North Dakota, for sure, we think our niche is helping young folks get
started," Thoreson says. "That's why we say 'the lender of first opportunity.'"
"Overall, we're seeing, probably, is that our demand is higher -- especially in
the amount of dollars we've funded and stockpiled. That has shown a dramatic
increase over last year. The number of loans funded has also gone up."

There are generally three primary categories of FSA loans -- operating loans,
real estate ownership and guaranteed loans -- all with subgroups.

Here are summaries of the activities:

-- Operating loans: This year's direct operating loan funds lent so far stands
at about $26 million, involving 341 loans. As of May 6, there were loans
totaling another $2.2 million "stockpiled," or approved and waiting for funding.

Lent funds in this category already showed a 40 percent increase from last
year's total of $18.5 million, with about 300 loans last year.

"I'd say factors affecting the increase are that the livestock economy has hurt
a lot of our producers and they're coming to us for some funding," Thoreson
says. "Cattle prices took a drop and people were buying feed for their cattle
last fall, already, due to drought. Also, we have increased our limits from
$200,000 last year to $300,000 per borrower."

Thoreson also says some of the activity is a result of some farmers having
problems marketing crops -- just getting them off the farm to sell -- because of
spring flooding and infrastructure damage. Loans are not tracked county by
county, so more detail is not yet available.

Thoreson cannot confirm whether there is any local tightening in the private
sector lending, as Doug Caruso, administrator of the FSA discussed in a June 11
hearing in Congress.

He says that the May 6 date was significant because that's when national
officials directed states to take any money that had been allocated to the state
and return extra funds to a national "pool," which would be administrated from
Washington. At that time, North Dakota had $4 million in unused funds in the
operating loan category.

"We're seeing a very late year in operating loan applications," Thoreson says.
"That's part of the problem. For some reason, with the winter, the late spring,
we're seeing applications very late this year. We're still getting applications
in daily."

Thoreson expects direct operating loan applications to drop, however, through
the end of the fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30.

-- Farm ownership: Overall, Thoreson expects activity here to be about the same
as 2008, when $11.5 million were lent. This year, the FSA has lent $3.6 million,
but has about $9.1 million of stockpiled applications, which he expects will be
funded if a supplemental appropriations passes through Congress as originally
proposed.

"Actually, it looks like it will have more than we planned," Thoreson says.

Thoreson says this activity has been healthy, probably influenced by two good
crop and financial years in 2007 and 2008. Within this category there are four
major sub-categories: -- Direct standard farm ownership: These are for standard
borrowers, with an interest rate in the 4 percent to 5 percent range and fixed
over 40 years.

-- Beginning farmer loans: This has the same terms as the standard loans, but is
its own category to reserve funds for beginning farmers. Here, the agency has
funded more than $2 million already, with another 18 loans stockpiled. There had
been little use for this category in 2008.

-- Down payment program: Here, FSA provides 45 percent of the purchase price at
45 percent of the appraised value, or $225,000 maximum. This is at 4 percent
below the direct farm ownership rate, or a minimum of 1.5 percent, and a down
payment of 5 percent, with a maximum of a 20-year term.

-- Joint financing: This is where the borrower gets 50 percent of their real
estate loan from the FSA and 50 percent from some other private source, whether
it's some private lender, the Bank of North Dakota and North Dakota Rural Rehab
Corp.

-- Loan guarantees: None of these loans are stockpiled for the operating loans,
for the purchase of things like machinery and livestock.

"We're down about $14 million in applications for loan guarantees from the same
time, at about $38.8 million" Thoreson says.

The state handled $52 million in guarantees through the whole year 2008.

Here, the FSA offers a guarantee of up to 90 percent of the loan value if the
loan should default. This is for producers who want to continue to deal with
their private lender, but tend to be used when these loans are getting a little
riskier.

Farm ownership loan guarantees so far this year are about $10 million, less than
last year's $12.9 million total for this time of year.

To see more of Agweek, or to subscribe to the magazine, go to
http://www.agweek.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Agweek Magazine Distributed by
McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                              The American Banker

Agriculture: Shopping Online for Tractors - and Mortgages

                           August 24, 2000, Thursday

BY CRAIG WOKER



Agricultural bankers like to boast about how well they know their customers, but
Larry J. Lanie, president of Farm Bureau Bank in Sparks, Nev., has never met
most of the 1,000-plus farmers who have accounts with his bank.

In fact, few of those customers have even visited the bank's sole branch.
That's because Farm Bureau Bank, with $156 million of assets, exists only in
cyberspace. Conceived by the nation's largest farm trade group, the one-year-old
bank is aiming to fill a void it believes has been left in rural markets where
big banks have acquired smaller ones.

"The Internet is the great equalizer in today's financial services environment,"
said Mr. Lanie, the bank's president and chief executive officer.  "You can be a
tiny community bank and have the ability to access customers all over the
country. We're reaching out to farm customers in rural areas that larger
institutions ignore."

As if to emphasize the irrelevance of distance in the Internet age, Mr.  Lanie
actually works two time zones away from Sparks, at the bank's operations center
in San Antonio.  Farmers and the Internet might seem like an odd mix, but the
"Hee Haw" image of agriculture has faded as farmers turn to computers and other
sophisticated technology to help run their businesses.  According to the
Department of Agriculture, 47% of the country's 1.9 million farms had computers
last year, and 29% of farms had Internet access in 1999 - more than double the
13% of two years earlier. And with farmers already buying everything from
tractors to bull sperm at sites such as Farmbid.com and Breednet.com, bankers
say that it is only logical that the nation's farmers - who owed $173 billion on
agricultural loans in 1999 - would start shopping around the Internet for
financial services.

"It's the wave of the future," said Ron Raney, an executive vice president of
$43 million-asset Hampton State Bank in Hampton, Iowa. "If farmers start to look
online for loans, we need to be ready." Mr. Raney's bank started a Web site four
years ago that provides information on agricultural loans and even includes a
calculator to help farmers estimate the payment on different types of loans. The
site also contains links to sites that provide information such as crop prices
at the Chicago Board of Trade and up-to-date weather forecasts.

But the boundaryless Internet has its limitations. Hampton State Bank, like most
agricultural banks with Web sites, does not offer online applications for
operating or real estate loans.

Bankers said they would like to sell these products online but are inhibited by
geography. For instance, most operating loans are designed for farmers to borrow
in the spring, before planting, and repay after harvest rather than monthly.

Bankers said they cannot make such loans out-of-area because to protect
themselves they must inspect the collateral to ensure that farmers have bought
and planted the seed they said they would.  Other agricultural loans, such as
those for land, also can pose a problem. Banks usually sell these long-term
loans to secondary-market firms such as Farmer Mac, but they often try to earn
fee income by servicing the loan - something they say is easier done with loans
close to home.  Even Farm Bureau Bank, which is affiliated with the five
million-member American Farm Bureau Federation and is designed to serve only
farmers, has limited its financial service offerings to simply structured
products such as money market accounts, car loans, and mortgages. The bank does
not plan to consider offering farm operating or real estate loans for at least a
couple of years.  "If you're going to use the Internet, how do you target it?
That's the million-dollar question for ag bankers," said Mike Cowley, an
assistant vice president in the agricultural department at First Victoria
National Bank in Victoria, Tex.  First Victoria, with $553 million of assets, is
one ag bank that has found a niche on the Web. Its Web site allows farmers to
fill out applications for one type of operating loan - cattle feedlot financing.

Most feedlots are in the arid Southwest. Dozens or even hundreds of farmers rent
pens from the lot owner and jointly raise their animals for slaughter,
benefiting from volume pricing on feed and veterinary care. (By contrast, in
such midwestern states as Illinois and Wisconsin, rich in pastureland, cattle
can graze economically on individual farms.) Because First Victoria can lend to
multiple farmers at these centralized feedlots, it conducts multiple collateral
inspections at a time - making Internet marketing feasible. The bank focuses on
feedlots in Texas, New Mexico, and Oklahoma but says it would go farther if a
large enough client came along.

"The geographic concerns aren't as pressing," Mr. Cowley said.  A longtime
supplier of risk management software for farm loans claims to have devised an
even broader solution to the geographic challenge.  In early July, Equity
Consultants Inc., which sells the Farm Equity Manager software used by more than
2,000 banks, launched a site called Onlineequity.com. The Glenwood, Iowa,
company said the site should help pair community banks with farm borrowers.

Onlineequity.com allows farmers to apply online for virtually any type of loan -
operating, real estate, or machinery. The company processes the loan application
and compares the borrowers' financial position to the credit-quality and
geographical of its participating bank.

The site returns up to eight banks that would be willing to make the loan, along
with their rates. To be listed on the site, banks pay $15 a month for the first
20 ZIP codes they want to target plus a referral fee based on the number of
leads they receive.  "This allows banks to expand a little outside of their
trade area, but not so far away that it's not economical," said Kevin Britten,
vice president of corporate alliances for Onlineequity.com. Mr. Britten hopes to
have 1,000 banks signed up within a year.  Royal Bank of Canada is also devising
a way over the geographic hurdle for Canadian farmers. But if the idea works,
the $280 billion-asset bank said other banks on both sides of the border are
sure to follow with a similar product

Royal Bank, which controls about 30% of the Canadian market for agricultural
loans, was preparing this summer to test-market a business credit card on the
bank's Web site. The card would offer farmers a credit limit of $100,000 - or
even more - and would be designated for agricultural operating expenses.

The bank said it believes the card could complement other agricultural products,
such as term loans for equipment, already available on its Web site.

The card would make it unnecessary for farmers going to fill out operating- loan
paperwork each year at a Royal Bank branch. Instead they would use the card for
their chemical, feed, fertilizer, and other expenses. The bank would mail a
suggested repayment schedule.  Because the card loans are unsecured, Royal Bank
plans to charge a higher rate - 2.75% above prime, versus 1% to 2% above prime
for traditional operating loans secured by collateral. The bank says that some
farmers would prefer to pay the extra amount rather than prepare operating
statements, financial forms, and loan applications each year.  "The card is more
akin to other behaviors people have on the Web - they want to deal with things
on their schedule rather than on ours," said Scott Manns, national manager for
farming and lifestyle agriculture at Royal Bank.

And this is only the beginning for farmers on the Internet, Mr. Manns predicts.

"The Web opens up this whole new world to them," he said. "They no longer have
to be near a large money-center - or even a town - to get all this information
on financial services and to find all these options."

Copyright c 2000 American Banker, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

                              The American Banker

Many - but Not All - Midwest States Helping Farmers with Credit

                            April 30, 1985, Tuesday

By ANDREA BENNETT

DATELINE: CHICAGO


As the planting deadline nears, many Midwest states have put into place
emergency credit programs to make sure farmers will have money to plant crops
this year.

In recent weeks, Illinois, Indiana, Minnesota, Montana, North Dakota, Ohio, and
Wisconsin have either put into place new programs or expanded existing state
programs to get funds to farmers. Farm aid packages are also being considered in
Kansas, Michigan, and Missouri.

Farm states are making unprecedented forays into the area of farm credit - once
exclusively the preserve of the federal government - after deeming recent
federal efforts inadequate to help farmers this spring. Most programs at the
state level are meant to provide short-term help and make sure farmers are able
to get loans that will let them plant crops.

''It's going to take more than just a loan bill,'' said state Rep. Jerry Burch,
sponsor of a farm credit package in Missouri. But, he said, states must do
something, because ''the rug has been pulled out from under them on the federal
level.''

Farm credit has been one of the most hotly debated issues in several of the
states, with tempers running high. In the Missouri General Assembly, after the
state Senate killed a farm aid bill overwhelmingly passed by the House, the
entire membership of the House marched on the Senate to lobby for the bill. The
House hadn't stormed the Senate in that manner since 1961.

Those states still considering legislation for farm aid are expected to act
within the next few weeks, as farmers begin to head into the fields to plant.
The time when farmers actually do that varies from state to state, but most
should be in the fields by the end of April.

''We have missed some of the spring season,'' Rep. Burch said. Most Missouri
farmers begin planting at the end of April, but Mr. Burch pointed out that
Missouri is a double-crop state, with many farmers going back to the fields to
plant soybeans later in the summer. ''I don't think there's such a thing as too
late,'' he said.

However, it is believed to be too late for farm aid in the two states that are
often thought to be in the worst trouble because of the poor farm economy.
Bankers in Iowa and Nebraska said that they do not expect any help at the state
level for farmers in their states.

Wes Ehrecke, government relations director for the Iowa Bankers Association,
said the state ran out of time trying to implement various plans debated in the
General Assembly. He said there was a possibility that farm credit aid might be
put together next year.

Stan Matzke, executive vice president of the Nebraska Bankers Association, said
farm states like Nebraska are finding it difficult to come up with funds to help
farmers as the ailing farm economy reduces state revenues.

''We've been working the Farmers Home Administration program pretty hard and
having some successes,'' Mr. Matzke said. He said activity in the administration
program has picked up dramatically in recent weeks, and he was optimistic in his
thinking that most farmers would be able to get operating loans.

Among the actions taken or being considered by states:

* Illinois - In early February, the state allocated about $105 million for
low-interest farm loans. Under the program, the state deposits money in banks at
low interest rates. The banks then loan the money to farmers at no more than
2.5% above the rate paid to the state for the deposits. The state increased its
allocation by $50 million in mid-March, after receiving requests for $244
million in farm loans, the treasurer's office said.

In mid-April, the state also authorized a $25 million farm credit relief package
to reduce farmers' interest rates on operating loans to 6% or 7% by the state
paying half the interest. The relief package calls for the farmers to repay the
state over a five-year period.

* Indiana - The state has put together a ''linked'' deposit, low-interest
subsidy program similar to Illinois'. Indiana has set aside $50 million that it
will place in banks as low-interest certificates of deposit, and the bank will
reloan the money to farmers. Initial loan rates to farmers could range from 5.5%
to 8%.

* Kansas - The Kansas Senate has passed an interest subsidy bill that would
allow bankers to reduce interest rates on operating loans by up to 3%.  The
state would subsidize the writedown by allowing banks to take a credit against
the Kansas franchise tax over a five-year period. The bill would allow about $15
million in interest rates to be written down, said Harold Stones, executive vice
president of the Kansas Bankers Association. The bill has the support of the
governor, but the real test of its popularity should come in the House of
Representatives, Mr. Stones said. It may be considered by the House during its
''veto'' session at the end of April.

* Michigan - A bill authorizing a $70 million farm loan program was introduced
into the Legislature in mid-April after state hearings on farm aid.  The
legislation, supported by Gov. James J. Blanchard, would authorize a ''linked
deposit'' program for low-interest farm loans similar to programs in Illinois
and Indiana.

* Minnesota - The Legislature passed a $25 million interest rate subsidy plan
this year. Two programs are available. In one, the state and lender join to
reduce interest rates on farm operating loans, with the state paying for
two-thirds of the writedown and the lender for the other third. Under the second
program, the state will pay a subsidy equal to 60 days' interest on a loan if
the lender agrees not to foreclose on the loan for 90 days.

* Missouri - A bill to subsidize interest rates on farm loans by using
''linked'' state deposits overwhelmingly passed the House but was defeated in
the Senate. It would have made $200 million available to banks to make farm
loans at 3% below market rate.

* Montana - A bill that would allow a state agricultural agency to guarantee
farm loans made by private lenders was recently signed into law.  Another bill
that would have allowed the state to transfer money out of its coal tax trust
fund for farm loans was defeated.

* North Dakota - Gov. George Sinner recently signed a bill that makes
low-interest operating loans available and also helps buy down interest rates on
farm loans.

* Ohio - Gov. Richard F. Celeste recently signed into law a bill to provide $100
million in ''linked'' state deposits to help write down interest rates on farm
operating loans by about 3%. The program is expected to help 1,000 to 3,000 of
the state's 90,000 farmers.

* Wisconsin - The state has committed $10 million to guarantee about $50 million
in loans by private lenders. It has set aside another $1 million to subsidize
interest rates. Under the second program, if a lender lowers loan rates to 11%,
the state will subsidize a further 2% drop. Ron McCrea, press secretary for Gov.
Anthony Earl, said there has been ''considerable activity'' in these programs.
He estimated they could help several thousand farmers in the state.

SECTION: AGRICULTURAL LENDING; Pg. 7

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                US Official News

                             June 28, 2016 Tuesday

Ag Secretary Vilsack to Provide Additional $500 Million for Farm Loans

LENGTH: 390  words

DATELINE: New York



 Atlanta: Growing Georgia has issued the following news release:



   Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack has notified Congress that he plans to tap
a $500 million discretionary fund to cover a projected shortfall in demand for
guaranteed farm ownership loans for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, according
to USDA's Farm Service Agency, which administers the loan program.





 Low commodity prices and a dramatic decline in farm income over the past two
years have caused banks to become more cautious in their lending practices,
hence there is a greater demand for USDA guaranteed loans. The department's Farm
Service Agency has just about run out of the $2 billion Congress approved for
the guaranteed loan program, three months before the end of the fiscal year. FSA
is also looking at a projected shortfall in federally assisted farm operating
loans.



 "USDA is entering a brief period where there is a gap in funding earlier than
normal," said FSA spokesman Kent Politsch, who added that the situation is not
unusual.



 "People forget this happens frequently where one of the funds, or all of funds,
start to dwindle as they get closer to the end of fiscal year," he said. "We
don't tell farmers we're out of money and they can't come to us anymore. We tell
them the opposite, to continue to apply for credit. In many case the producer is
put on waiting list and when appropriates happen, they are the first to get
funds."



 In early June, eight national farm and financial organizations asked Congress
to increase funding for operating loans for the current fiscal year in the FY
2017 agricultural appropriations bill.



 The groups, including the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition and the
American Bankers Association and the National Farmers Union, said an additional
$16.5 million in the spending bill for 2017 would make available additional $300
million in direct FSA operating loans and $350 million in FSA guarantees of
private sector commercial loans. These amounts would allow USDA to cover the
estimated shortfall of available loan dollars. The legislation currently
includes the USDA-requested program level of $1.46 billion for direct operating
loans, and $1.432 billion for guaranteed operating loans.

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                           Ivanhoe Times (Minnesota)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 April 24, 2014

Farm loan programs modified under new 2014 Farm Bill

BYLINE: Ivanhoe Times staff

LENGTH: 439  words


WASHINGTON, D.C.-The new 2014 Farm Bill signed into law by President Barak Obama
on February 7, updates certain requirements and modifies several loan programs
administered by the Farm Service Agency (FSA).

Several areas that FSA customers can expect to take effect immediately as a
result of the new 2014 Farm Bill that has been signed into law are as follows:

The percent of guarantee offered on all Conservation Loans (CL) will increase
from 75 percent to 80 percent. The percent of guarantee will increase to 90
percent for CLs made to socially disadvantaged and beginning farmers.

The interest rate charged on Direct Farm Ownership loans that are made in
conjunction with other lenders is set at two percent below the regular Direct
Farm Ownership rate, with a floor of 2.5 percent.

The requirement for FSA to appraise the value of oil, gas or other minerals to
be used as collateral for Farm Ownership loans has been removed.

The maximum loan amount for down payment Farm Ownership loans increased to
$300,000 from $225,000, consistent with all other Direct Farm Ownership loans.

The rural residency requirement for Youth Loans is removed. Previously, to
qualify for a Youth Loan an applicant had to live in a rural area.

Micro loans made to beginning and veteran farmers and/or ranchers are exempt
from direct term limits. Term limits still apply for non-microloan direct loans
(regular operating loans and Farm Ownership loans).

A limited resource rate is available to beginning and veteran farmers who
receive a Microloan. Borrowers will be given a choice to accept the limited
resource rate or regular operating loan rate.

The restriction that an applicant could receive a Guarantee Operating Loan (OL)
for no more than 15 years has been eliminated.

The definition of a qualified beginning farmer or rancher is modified to set the
average size of farmland owned at no greater than 30 percent of the average size
farm. Previously, this definition used the median farm size which eliminated
many otherwise qualified applicants.

Debt forgiveness will no longer preclude a former Youth Loan borrower from
obtaining additional loans from any U.S. government agency. Additionally,
borrowers with Youth Loan debt forgiveness or who are delinquent on Youth Loan
debt can receive student loans. The servicing and collection of Youth Loans is
not affected by the statute and will continue under the present regulation. FSA
is revising the definition of debt forgiveness to comply with this statute.

Additional information regarding FSA Farm Loans or other FSA programs can be
found by visiting a nearby FSA Service Center or online at fsa.usda.gov

                           The Florala News (Alabama)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any

                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 April 25, 2012

FSA targets funds for socially disadvantaged farmers

BYLINE: The Florala News staff

LENGTH: 443  words


USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA) in Alabama has new funds available for Socially
Disadvantaged Applicants (SDA) who want to purchase or operate a family-size
farm.

In fiscal year 2011, which ended September 30, 2011, Alabama FSA made 112 SDA
loans totaling $3.7 million, and guaranteed 23 SDA loans totaling more than
$10.4 million. Alabama FSA has six farm loan teams located in Coffee, DeKalb,
Elmore, Lawrence, Monroe and Tuscaloosa counties. SDA farmers serviced by the
Coffee County FSA farm loan team benefited from $782,000.00 in farm loans
disbursed in Fiscal Year 2011. The Coffee County FSA farm loan team serves
Barbour, Bullock, Butler, Coffee, Conecuh, Covington, Crenshaw, Dale, Escambia,
Geneva, Henry, Houston and Pike counties.

"An SDA farmer, rancher or agricultural producer is one of a group whose members
have been subjected to racial, ethnic or gender inequality without regard to
their individual qualities. SDA members include women, African Americans,
American Indians, Hispan-ics, Asian Americans, Pacific Islanders and Alaskan
Natives," said John H. Dor-rill, III, Farm Loan Manager for the Coffee County
FSA farm loan team.

The SDA program provides direct and guaranteed assistance in the form of farm
operating and farm ownership loans. Direct loans are made by FSA. Guaranteed
loans are issued by lending institutions; however, typically 90 percent of the
loan is guaranteed by FSA.

Operating loans may be used to purchase livestock, equipment, feed, seed and
other business related expenses. Repayment terms run from one to seven years.

Ownership loans provide capital to purchase or enlarge a farm, construct or
improve buildings, promote soil and water conservation and pay closing costs.
Direct ownership loan terms are up to 40 years. Guaranteed loan terms are
established by the lender.

Qualified candidates are provided information and assistance to develop sound
management practices, analyze problems and utilize available resources essential
for successful farming operations to cope with the changing agricultural
environment.

SDA loan applicants do not receive automatic approval. Individuals must be U.S.
citizens with a satisfactory history of meeting credit obligations; have
significant education, training or experience managing or operating a farm;
possess legal capacity to incur debt; and be unable to obtain credit elsewhere.

Special loan funds are also available for beginning farmers and ranchers.

Contact the Coffee County FSA farm loan team at 334-894-5581 Ext. 4 or the local
FSA Service Center Office for more information. Local offices are found under
the blue or government pages of local telephone directories.

                              41 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            October 31, 2016 Monday

Farm Lending Decline but Remains Elevated

LENGTH: 265  words

DATELINE: New York



 Atlanta: Growing Georgia has issued the following news release:



   Farm lending at commercial banks declined in the third quarter of 2016, but
remained elevated as lenders continued to assess the downturn in the U.S.
agricultural economy, according to the Federal Reserve's Agricultural Finance
Databook.





 The need for short-term financing in the farm sector remained high as profit
margins remained weak. The volume of farm loans originated in the third quarter
decreased about 19 percent from a year ago but remained elevated by historical
standards. Consistent with recent trends, loans for operating expenses continued
to drive the demand for new loans. So far in 2016, loans used to finance
operating expenses have comprised about 70 percent of all non-real estate farm
loans and nearly 60 percent of total loan volume.



 Alongside growing risk in the sector and slight declines in loan performance,
agricultural bankers made modest adjustments to loan terms. Bankers also
continued to rely more heavily on farm real estate as collateral. Most
prominently, the share of collateral on loans of more than $250,000 that was
comprised of farm real estate increased from 10 percent to 32 percent. The sharp
increase reversed a five-year decline in the use of farm real estate as a share
of total collateral on non-real estate loans.



 Farmland values continued to decline at a modest pace, which may put further
pressure on agricultural credit conditions for some borrowers



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

                                The Denver Post

                              May 10, 2009 Sunday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Farmers hurt by bank loss to get aid Feds to offer loans in time for spring
planting after the closing of New Frontier.

BYLINE: Colleen O'Connor The Denver Post

SECTION: DENVER & THE WEST; Pg. B-02

LENGTH: 300 words


Hundreds of distressed family farmers hurt by the closure of New Frontier Bank,
which specialized in agriculture loans, will receive assistance from the Farm
Service Agency in time for spring planting.

U.S. Sens. Michael Bennet and Mark Udall, and Rep. Betsy Markey, all Colorado
Democrats, announced Saturday that the Farm Service Agency will free more money
in the form of direct operating loans.

The lawmakers had sent a letter requesting assistance to Agriculture Secretary
Tom Vilsack, who then authorized a transfer of unused FSA subsidized guaranteed
operating loan funds into the agency's direct operating fund.

"He made a quick decision," Bennet said. "It's not just about the change in
direct loan amounts. He also said that the USDA will send more personnel to help
farmers with the loan application process, which is tremendous.

"Lots of people are concerned with a very immediate problem, so all hands on
deck means that people's difficulties will be solved more quickly."

About 1,900 family farmers will receive direct operating loan assistance, and
620 family farmers will receive guaranteed operating loan funds.

"I'm glad to see that the agriculture secretary will be here on Monday," Bennet
said about Vilsack's planned meetings in Fort Morgan and Fort Collins.

Many farmers were left in a credit bind with the closure last month of Greeley's
New Frontier Bank, on top of a significant drop in prices for milk and other
farm products.

Dairies and other livestock companies struggled to secure bank credit to fund
spring planting, cow feed and farmhand labor costs.

There are more than 60 dairies in Colorado. More than a third depended on New
Frontier Bank loans, and many feared the bank closure would mean the end of
their family farms.

Colleen O'Connor: 303-954-1083

or coconnor@denverpost.com

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                        The Moultrie Observer (Georgia)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              March 7, 2010 Sunday

Loans available for disadvantaged farmers

BYLINE: The Moultrie Observer, Ga.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 433 words


Mar. 7--ATHENS, Ga. -- The Georgia State Farm Service Agency (FSA) announced the
availability of $9.5 million in direct loan funds for socially disadvantaged
(SDA) individuals who want to purchase or operate a family-size farm in fiscal
year 2010.

In Fiscal year 2009, which ended Sept. 30, 2009, Georgia Farm Loan Programs made
116 direct SDA loans totaling more than $7.3 million.

"The special financing is for people who have been subjected to racial, ethnic
or gender inequality without regard to their individual qualities. SDA members
include women, African Americans, American Indians, Hispanic, Asian and Pacific
Islanders and Alaskan Natives," said Hobby Stripling, state executive director
of the Georgia Farm Service Agency.

The SDA program provides direct and guaranteed assistance in the form of farm
operating and farm ownership loans. Direct loans are made to applicants from
FSA. Guaranteed loans are issued by lending institutions, but typically 90 or 95
percent of the loan is guaranteed by FSA.

Operating loans may be used to purchase livestock, equipment, feed, seed, and
other business-related expenses. Repayment terms run from one to seven years.

Ownership loans provide capital to purchase or enlarge a farm, construct or
improve buildings, promote soil and water conservation and pay closing costs.
Direct ownership loan terms are up to 40 years. Guaranteed loan terms are
established by the lender.

Qualified candidates are provided information and assistance to develop sound
management practices, analyze problems and utilize available resources essential
for successful farming operations to cope with the changing agricultural
environment. SDA loan applicants do not receive automatic approval. Individuals
must be U.S. citizens with a satisfactory history of meeting credit obligations;
have sufficient education, training or experience managing or operating a farm;
possess legal capacity to incur debt; and be unable to obtain credit elsewhere.

Contact your local FSA County Office or USDA service Center for more loan
information. You may find the local office phone number listed under the blue or
government pages of your local telephone directory.

To see more of The Moultrie Observer or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.moultrieobserver.com. Copyright (c) 2010, The Moultrie Observer, Ga.

to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                           November 15, 2011 Tuesday

FSA targets funds for socially disadvantaged farmers

BYLINE: The Moultrie Observer, Ga.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 378 words


Nov. 15--ATHENS, Ga. -- The Georgia State Farm Service Agency (FSA) announced
the availability of direct and guaranteed loan funds for Socially Disadvantaged
(SDA) individuals who want to purchase or operate a family-size farm in fiscal
year 2012.

In Fiscal Year 2011, which ended September 30, 2011, Georgia Farm Loan Programs
made 178 direct and guaranteed SDA loans totaling more than $26.27 million.

"The special financing is for people who have been subjected to racial, ethnic
or gender inequality without regard to their individual qualities. SDA members
include women, African Americans, American Indians, Hispanic, Asian and Pacific
Islanders and Alaskan Natives," said Hobby Stripling, state executive director
of the Georgia Farm Service Agency.

The SDA program provides direct and guaranteed assistance in the form of farm
operating and farm ownership loans. Direct loans are made to applicants from
FSA. Guaranteed loans are issued by lending institutions, but typically 90
percent of the loan is guaranteed by FSA.

Operating loans may be used to purchase livestock, equipment, feed, seed, and
other business related expenses. Repayment terms run from one to seven years.

Ownership loans provide capital to purchase or enlarge a farm, construct or
improve buildings, promote soil and water conservation and pay closing costs.
Direct ownership loan terms are up to 40 years.

Guaranteed loan terms are established by the lender.

Qualified candidates are provided information and assistance to develop sound
management practices, analyze problems and utilize available resources essential
for successful farming operations to cope with the changing agricultural
environment.

SDA loan applicants do not receive automatic approval. Individuals must be U.S.
citizens with a satisfactory history of meeting credit obligations; have
sufficient education, training or experience managing or operating a farm;
possess legal capacity to incur debt; be unable to obtain credit elsewhere; and
meet certain other eligibility requirements.

For more information, contact the Colquitt County FSA office at 985-6509 ext. 2.

                          September 2, 2009 Wednesday

FSA targets funds for socially disadvantaged farmers

BYLINE: The Free Press, Kinston, N.C.

SECTION: LIFESTYLE

LENGTH: 447 words


Sep. 2--The North Carolina Farm Service Agency has announced the availability of
funds targeted for socially disadvantaged individuals who want to purchase or
operate a family-size farm in fiscal year 2009-10.

In Fiscal Year 2009, which ends Sept. 30, North Carolina Farm Loan Programs made
92 SDA loans totaling more than $10.8 million. This was 17 percent of the total
loans made, and 13 percent of the total dollars loaned. In Craven, Carteret and
Jones countids, SDA farmers benefited from $408,500 in farm loans disbursed to
date.

"This special financing is for people who have been subjected to racial, ethnic
or gender inequality without regard to their individual qualities. SDA members
include women, African Americans, American Indians, Hispanics, Asian and Pacific
Islanders and Alaskan Natives," said Sue A. Smithwick, manager of the Craven,
Carteret, Jones, Lenoir and Pamlico County FSA Farm Loan Program.

The SDA program provides direct and guaranteed assistance in the form of farm
operating and farm ownership loans. Direct loans are made to applicants from
FSA. Guaranteed loans are issued by lending institutions, but typically 90 or 95
percent of the loan is guaranteed by FSA.

Operating loans can be used to purchase livestock, equipment, feed, seed and
other business related expenses. Repayment terms run from one to seven years.

Ownership loans provide capital to purchase or enlarge a farm, construct or
improve buildings, promote soil and water conservation and pay closing costs.
Direct ownership loan terms are up to 40 years. Guaranteed loan terms are
established by the lender.

Qualified candidates are provided information and assistance to develop sound
management practices, analyze problems and utilize available resources essential
for successful farming operations to cope with the changing agricultural
environment.

SDA loan applicants do not receive automatic approval. Individuals must be U.S
citizens with a satisfactory history of meeting credit obligations; have
sufficient education, training or experience managing or operating a farm;
possess legal capacity to incur debt; and be unable to obtain credit elsewhere.

For more information, call Pat Williams at the Lenoir County FSA Office, (252)
523-0524 or Smithwick at (252) 946-1076.

                        The Clarendon Enterprise (Texas)

                                January 31, 2013

Microloans expand small farm options

BYLINE: The Clarendon Enterprise staff

LENGTH: 371  words


Donley County USDA Farm Service Agency (FSA) Farm Loan Officer Debbie Roberts,
announced that beginning farmers and ranchers in Texas now have a new Microloan
credit option to consider.

On January 17, FSA started offering Microloans which are designed to help
farmers and ranchers with credit needs of $35,000 or less. The loan features a
streamlined application process built to fit the needs of beginning and the
smallest of family farmers and ranchers.

"The microloan application process is simpler and requires less paperwork than
traditional operating loans," said Roberts. "This loan program will also be
useful to specialty crop producers and operators of community supported
agriculture," she said.

In 2012, the Farm Service Agency provided $196.4 million in farm loan assistance
to agricultural producers of all sizes in Texas. That year, operating loans
accounted for the majority of the loans extended totaling $129.4 million, while
farm ownership loans totaled more than $61 million. In 2012, $5.7 million in
emergency loans were made to producers in Texas recovering from natural
disasters.

"The current interest rate for Microloans is 1.25 percent and the maximum term
for microloans is seven years," according to Roberts. "Producers can contact
their local FSA farm loan office for details about the Microloan Program."

Microloans can be used to pay for initial start-up expenses such as hoop houses
to extend the growing season, essential tools, irrigation, delivery vehicles and
annual expenses such as seed, fertilizer, utilities, land rents and marketing
and distribution expenses. As financing needs increase, applicants can apply for
an operating loan up to the maximum amount of $300,000 or obtain financing from
a commercial lender under FSA's Guaranteed Loan Program.

In response to tighter financial markets, USDA has expanded the availability of
farm credit, helping farmers obtain loans across the U.S. Since 2009, USDA has
provided more than 128,000 loans to family farmers totaling more than $18
billion. In Texas, more than 70 percent of the loans went to beginning and
socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers.

For information on Microloans, contact The Donley County USDA service center at
806-874-3561.

                              48 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The American Banker

Volcker Outlines Fed's Farm Policies for Independent Bankers

                            March 12, 1985, Tuesday

By RICHARD RINGER

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, Tex.


Agricultural banks, which have traditionally been better capitalized than most
other institutions, will need that strength to recover from many of their
borrowers' problems, according to Federal Reserve Board Chairman Paul A.
Volcker.

Speaking Saturday at the close of the annual Independent Bankers Association of
America convention here, Mr. Volcker also outlined already-implemented changes
in a program to assure farm banks of needed liquidity to finance operating loans
this spring.

In his prepared remarks, and at a press conference later, Mr. Volcker also
expressed concern about bank holding companies pursuing loopholes in current
laws to circumvent interstate banking restrictions.

He hinted that the Fed may take action against Missouri-based Mark Twain
Bancshares Inc. for moving its Independence branch to Overland Park, Kan., about
16 miles across the state line.

At the press conference, Mr. Volcker said the Fed has not taken any ''action as
of yet'' concerning Mark Twain. He said a court ruling on one of two lawsuits,
both aimed at stopping Mark Twain from operating in Kansas, could come this
week.

The Fed has also sent a letter to Mark Twain officials asking for a legal
analysis of the relocation.

Mark Twain obtained approval from the Comptroller of the Currency to relocate
the Independence subsidiary to Kansas.

Mark Twains' application and the Comptroller's decision were based on a section
in the National Bank Act allowing national institutions to move anywhere within
30 miles.

Mr. Volcker also reiterated hopes that Congress passes legislation to close the
limited-service, or nonbank, bank loophole, and to give banks and holding
companies expanded powers so long as such authority doesn't jeopardize the
institutions' safety and soundness.

A limited-service bank either takes deposits or offers commercial loans, but not
both. As such, it is not subject to Bank Holding Company Act provisions
regulating interstate movements.

Efforts to assure farm banks' liquidity to finance agricultural operating loans
include allowing certain farm banks to borrow from the Fed's discount window
more cheaply and to obtain from the Fed a larger portion of their seasonal cash
needs for farm lending.

Both measures, said Mr. Volcker, are modifications in the Fed's seasonal credit
program which provides access to discount window borrowing for institutions
demonstrating recurring financing needs related to seasonal fluctuations in
deposit flows and loan demands.

Under the modifications, the Fed has reduced the amount a bank must fund from
its own liquidity.

The formula for computing the deductible has been changed from 4% to 2% of the
first $100 million in deposits and from 7% to 6% of the second $100 million in
deposits.

The interest rate on credit advanced under the modified program will be set at a
rate that will remain fixed during the time the credit is outstanding. The rate
was initially 8 1/2%, which is is between the basic discount rate, and the rate
on extended credit that is outstanding for more than 60 days.

Farm banks that can take advantage of the liberalized seasonal credit program
are those with deposits of $200 million or less, that have at least a 60% loan
-to-deposit ratio, and that have a ratio of loans to farmers or of farm real
estate to total loans of greater than 17%.

Farm banks today generally have sufficient liquidity to finance farm operating
loans. But Mr. Volcker said the changes were designed to ensure that liquidity
strains don't hamper the necessary credit flow in various regions.

The most severe problem facing farm banks is the ability of farmers to pay off
existing debts to qualify for new operating loans.

A new Agriculture Department report indicates that the problem is worse than
previously thought.

The report states that one-third of all family commercial farms will experience
financial difficulties this year, and that nearly 14% of those farms are either
insolvent or approaching insolvency.

The report states that 73,000, or 3.3%, of all farms have debts totaling 70% or
more of total assets. Another 10% of the farms, or 220,000, have debts equal to
40% to 70% of assets.

At current levels of farm income and interest rates, farmers with debts
amounting to 40% or more of assets are experiencing cash flow problems, the
report says.

SECTION: Pg. 8

LENGTH: 725 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1985 American Banker, Inc.


                              49 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                     Western Kansas World (Wakeeny, Kansas)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                August 28, 2014

FSA Targets Funds to Minority, Women & Beginning Farmers

BYLINE: Western Kansas World staff

LENGTH: 426  words


Adrian J. Polansky, State Executive Director of the USDA Kansas Farm Service
Agency (FSA), announced that the FSA is reaching out to minority and women
farmers who want to purchase or operate a family-size farm.

"Each year, FSA targets a portion of its farm loan funding for socially
disadvantaged applicants (SDA)", Polansky said. The targeted funds are available
to socially disadvantaged applicants who include minority farmers, women
farmers, as well as beginning farmers.

For FSA farm loan purposes, FSA defines an SDA person as one of a group whose
members have been subjected to racial, ethnic, or gender prejudice because of
their identity as members of a group without regard to their individual
qualities. For additional information regarding FSA loans to minority or women
farmers, please visit www.fsa.usda.gov/ks.

A beginning farmer or rancher is defined as someone who:

Has not operated a farm or ranch for more than 10 years

Does not own a farm or ranch greater than 30 percent of the median size farm

Meets the loan eligibility requirements of the program to which he/she is
applying

Substantially participates in the operation; and

If applying for a farm ownership loan, must have participated in a farm for at
least three years

Polansky said that "while funding is targeted for loans to socially
disadvantaged applicants and beginning farmers, loan approval is neither
automatic nor guaranteed." Polansky stated that "in Fiscal Year 2013, Kansas
obligated $9,104,655 for a total of 135 loans to qualified farmers under the
Socially Disadvantaged Persons Loan Program. We also obligated $46,323,649.62
for a total of 418 loans to qualified farmers under the Beginning Farmer
Program."

"Applicants seeking credit through FSA must meet certain eligibility criteria,"
Polansky said. FSA applicants must be U.S. citizens, have a satisfactory history
of meeting credit obligations, have sufficient education, training or experience
managing or operating a farm, possess legal capacity to incur debt; and be
unable to obtain credit elsewhere.

Traditional operating loans may be used to purchase livestock, equipment, feed,
seed or pay other business related expenses. Operating loans are usually repaid
in one to seven years.

Ownership loans are available to provide capital to purchase or enlarge a farm,
construct or improve buildings, promote soil and water conservation and pay
closing costs. Direct ownership loan terms are up to 40 years.

For additional information, contact your local Farm Service Agency at the county
USDA Service Center nearest you.

                        The Moultrie Observer (Georgia)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 5, 2011 Saturday

FSA targets funds for socially disadvantaged farmers

BYLINE: The Moultrie Observer, Ga.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 410 words


March 05--ATHENS, Ga. -- The Georgia State Farm Service Agency (FSA) announced
the availability of direct and guaranteed loan funds for Socially Disadvantaged
(SDA) individuals who want to purchase or operate a family-size farm in fiscal
year 2011.

In Fiscal year 2010, which ended Sept. 30, 2010, Georgia Farm Loan Programs made
220 direct and guaranteed SDA loans totaling more than $34.1 million.

"The special financing is for people who have been subjected to racial, ethnic
or gender inequality without regard to their individual qualities. SDA members
include women, African Americans, American Indians, Hispanic, Asian and Pacific
Islanders and Alaskan Natives," said Hobby Stripling, state executive director
of the Georgia Farm Service Agency.

The SDA program provides direct and guaranteed assistance in the form of farm
operating and farm ownership loans. Direct loans are made to applicants from
FSA. Guaranteed loans are issued by lending institutions, but typically 90 or 95
percent of the loan is guaranteed by FSA.

Operating loans may be used to purchase livestock, equipment, feed, seed, and
other business related expenses. Repayment terms run from one to seven years.

Ownership loans provide capital to purchase or enlarge a farm, construct or
improve buildings, promote soil and water conservation and pay closing costs.
Direct ownership loan terms are up to 40 years.

Guaranteed loan terms are established by the lender.

Qualified candidates are provided information and assistance to develop sound
management practices, analyze problems and utilize available resources essential
for successful farming operations to cope with the changing agricultural
environment. SDA loan applicants do not receive automatic approval. Individuals
must be U.S. citizens with a satisfactory history of meeting credit obligations;
have sufficient education, training or experience managing or operating a farm;
possess legal capacity to incur debt; be unable to obtain credit elsewhere; and
meet certain other eligibility requirements.

Contact your local FSA County Office or USDA Service Center for more loan
information.

To see more of The Moultrie Observer or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.moultrieobserver.com. Copyright (c) 2011, The Moultrie Observer, Ga.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more information
about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
(MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                           The Ottawa Herald (Kansas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 8, 2009 Tuesday

Farm aid available for women, minorities

BYLINE: The Ottawa Herald, Kan.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 504 words


Sep. 8--Women and members of minority groups who want to own or operate a farm
may be able to get a little help from the federal government.

"Each year, the Farm Service Agency earmarks a portion of its farm loan funding
for socially disadvantaged applicants, people who have been subjected to racial,
ethnic or gender inequality without regard to their individual qualities," Stacy
Kull, farm loan manager of the USDA Farm Service Agency for Anderson, Coffey,
Douglas, Franklin, Johnson, Linn, Miami, Osage and Shawnee counties, said.

Socially disadvantaged applicants may be women, African-Americans, American
Indians, Hispanics, Asian and Pacific Islanders and Alaska Natives.

Kull said that while funding is earmarked for loans to socially disadvantaged
applicants, loan approval is neither automatic nor guaranteed.

"Socially disadvantaged applicants must meet the same eligibility criteria as
other applicants," Kull said.

Applicants must be U.S citizens; have a satisfactory history of meeting credit
obligations; have sufficient education, training or experience managing or
operating a farm; possess legal capacity to incur debt; and be unable to obtain
credit elsewhere.

The agency can make direct loans to applicants who are unable to get commercial
credit or provide loan guarantees to commercial lenders.

Guaranteed loans may be made by any lending institution subject to Federal or
state supervision (banks, savings and loans, and units of the Farm Credit
System). FSA typically guarantees 90 or 95 percent of the loan against any loss
that might be incurred if the loan fails.

Applicants can use operating loans to purchase livestock, equipment, feed, seed
or pay other business-related expenses. Operating loans are usually repaid in
one to seven years.

Ownership loans provide capital to purchase or enlarge a farm, construct or
improve buildings, promote soil and water conservation and pay closing costs.
Direct ownership loan terms are for up to 40 years, while guaranteed loan terms
are established by the lender.

Qualified applicants receive information and assistance to develop sound
management practices, analyze problems and utilize available resources essential
for successful farming operations to cope with the changing agricultural
environment.

In fiscal year 2008, Kansas obligated $1,321,855 for a total of 48 loans to
qualified farmers under the Socially Disadvantaged Persons Loan Program.

"We also obligated $12,198,317 for a total of 198 loans to qualified farmers
under Beginning Farmer Program," Kull said.

For more information about the agency's loan programs, call Kull at (785)
242-3260.

To see more of The Ottawa Herald or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.ottawaherald.com Copyright (c) 2009, The Ottawa Herald, Kan.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.
