                              The American Banker

Farm Loan Accommodation Sought;
ABA Wants Balance Between Compassion and Prudence

                           February 28, 1983, Monday

By LISA J. Mc CUE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Continued low prices for farm commodities and high operating costs are making
lenders take a hard look at ways to help farmers meet their debt payments.

The American Bankers Association recently formed an agricultural task force to
find a balance between compassion for farmers delinquent on loan payments and
protections of bank deposits and stockholders' equity.

The ABA has announced that the task force will meet Tuesday with congressional,
regulatory, and administration officials regarding possible amendments to bank
regulation and examination procedures that could address the farm loan problems.

Also, the Farm Credit Administration recently pledged its support in assisting
its hard-pressed borrowers who are having a hard time paying off farm loans
because of declining prices and mounting operating costs.

The FCA is the federal agency responsible for the supervision, examiniation and
regulation of the Farm Credit System.

That agency's policy making board recommended that the System place ''strong
emphasis on appropriate loan servicing that will benefit borrowers who are
cooperative and making an honest effort to meet the conditions of their loan
contracts.''

The policy group said the System's Federal Land Banks should adopt policies
regarding: informal forebearance; deferment of principal; and amortized
extensions, among other things.

Regarding the ABA's meeting Tuesday, the task force is expected to meet with the
following: examination officials of the Federal Reserve Board, the Office of the
Comptroller of the Currency, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., as well as
congressional agriculture committee staff and Department of Agriculture
representatives.

In a study conducted by the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, figures showed
74% of the bankers surveyed expect farmers' demand for debt refinancing next
quarter will be above normal levels and that 40% of the bankers believe the
farmers' ability to repay debt will worsen during that period.

''Most bankers expect net farm earnings will again fall short of their
year-earlier level in the first quarter of 1983,'' the report said.

SECTION: Pg. 3

LENGTH: 359 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1983 American Banker, Inc.


                             149 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    December 14, 1985, Saturday, ALL EDITION

Western farmers get boost to start the next season

BYLINE: Joe Ralko

SECTION: SECTION 2, INSIDE BUSINESS; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 287 words


  THE 6% loans which the Agricultural Credit Corp. of Saskatchewan is being
empowered to make should insure that the province's 65,000 farmers have
operating funds to start the season next year.


The provincial government has decided to quadruple the credit corporation's
borrowing power to $2 billion and enable it to offer operating loans of $25 a
cultivated acre. If all eligible Saskatchewan farmers take the loans, it will be
a $1.2-billion program. Until now, the Crown corporation only had administered a
$200-million cash advance program for livestock producers and a small irrigation
systems credit program.

''Last year, we called for 7 1/2% money for farmers and got laughed at,''
Saskatchewan Wheat Pool President Ted Turner says. ''But I think (it's finally
being recognized) the farmers can't exist on money that's costing them over
8%.''

Barbara Isman, executive director of the Regina-based Western Canadian Wheat
Growers Association, describes the Saskatchewan program as ''strong and
sensible.''

Devine has received many suggestions for farm aid programs, ranging from
recommendations for a $50-per-acre grant to a national disaster assistance plan.

Precise program details and application forms will be available in January. The
loans are unsecured personal promissory notes, apparently with no strings
attached. Repayment details and a ceiling, if any, on the total loan farmers may
receive are still being worked out.

A farmer with 1,200 cultivated acres - a farm size not unusual in Saskatchewan -
could receive $30,000 in 6% operating credit next spring. The savings in
interest costs in the first year alone is about $1,800 based on a commercial
rate of 12%.




LOAD-DATE: December 9, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1985 Financial Post Ltd.


                             150 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                      Saint Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                            March 21, 1998 Saturday

OFFICIALS SEEK ADDED LOANS FOR FLOOD-AFFLICTED FARMERS

BYLINE: Lee Egerstrom, Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS TWIN CITIES; Pg. 2B

LENGTH: 530 words


Responding to last year's floods and the spread of wheat disease that followed
in the Red River Valley, Minnesota and North Dakota state Farm Service Agency
directors said Friday they are seeking an additional $105 million in federal
loan funds to help get farmers back in their fields this spring.

State directors of Farm Service Agency offices in St. Paul and Fargo said they
expect their agencies will exhaust existing allocations for federal farm loans
by early April.

Wally Sparby, executive director of the agency in Minnesota, said in a statement
issued late Friday that he expects the need for federal farm loan assistance
will grow as spring approaches.

"Farmers and the public can be assured that the agency is doing everything
within its power to help," he said. "Once producers have fully identified their
financial needs, I expect to see an increase in numbers."

But in the meantime, agency officials in the two states are finding a financial
crisis developing in the valley, especially for wheat farmers.

Sparby and his North Dakota counterpart, Scott Stofferahn, conducted a two-state
survey of the valley and North Dakota wheat areas on March 12. The agencies are
part of federal and state programs directing assistance to farms and communities
harmed by last spring's flooding along the Red River of the North.

The agencies also administer emergency, direct farm operating and guaranteed
subsidized farm loans that are major programs of the former Farmers Home
Administration before USDA offices and agencies were reorganized. The Farm
Service Agency, like its predecessor, remains the so-called "lender of last
resort" for farmers who have been denied credit from other bankers.

While last spring's flooding in the valley was widely known, less public
attention was given to how wet fields contributed to the spread of scab, a wheat
disease that ruined crops for farmers on both sides of the river.

Sparby's agency in Minnesota had appropriations of $59.1 million for these
programs. It is seeking $34 million in additional funds to meet farm family
needs in Kittson, Roseau, Marshall, Polk, Pennington, Red Lake, Norman and
Mahnomen counties.

The biggest increase in projected needs is for the agency to help farmers and
lenders restructure existing loans following last year's poor wheat crop. Income
from wheat farming was further hurt by declining wheat prices, both from a
rebuilding of world wheat stocks and from weaker export demand - particularly in
Asia.

Problems are increasing for wheat farmers across North Dakota, but most new loan
applications and calls for loan restructuring assistance are coming from farmers
in the eastern counties along the Red River.

In a statement issued for North Dakota, Stofferahn projected that an additional
$15.5 million is need for the agency's direct farm operating loans, $11.4
million for borrowers to convert existing loans, and $44 million for new
applicants seeking guaranteed subsidized loans. The latter, guaranteed loans,
are loans written by commercial and cooperative lenders who have secured USDA
guarantees to back up a majority of the loan value.

LOAD-DATE: October 18, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                     Copyright 1998 St. Paul Pioneer Press
                              All Rights Reserved

                    Lyon County Reporter (Rock Rapids, Iowa)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 April 25, 2012

New FSA help for beginning farmers and ranchers

BYLINE: Lyon County Reporter staff

LENGTH: 570  words


ROCK RAPIDS -- The USDA Farm Service Agency is working harder than ever to
assist new farmers and ranchers to succeed. Iowa FSA Executive Director John R.
Whitaker recently unveiled a new Land Contract Guarantee Program and several
other tools designed to help beginning farmers and ranchers build the foundation
for a successful career in agriculture.

"New farmers face many challenges, like obtaining land for example," said
Whitaker. "FSA is going to provide new options to help them to work through this
challenging start-up issue." Peak land values, tight commercial credit, minimal
credit history and less collateral make it difficult for new and smaller farmers
in Iowa to get a commercial business loan right now.

The Land Contract Guarantee Program provides a new approach for landowners
willing to sell and finance a land purchase to a beginning or socially
disadvantaged farmer. The national program offers two options, one that
guarantees up to three annual installment payments on the contract and one that
guarantees 90% of the unpaid principal of the contract. Guarantees can be used
in the purchase of land for up to $500,000.

"Iowa farmers represent all walks of life, a wide variety of ethnic backgrounds,
and all different ages," notes

Whitaker "This new program will work well for beginning and minority growers in
our state and we encourage producers to visit with us to see if they qualify and
how it could fit their needs," he said. You can find FSA loan information,
disaster assistance programs and other helpful programs at www.fsa.usda. gov.

Another new change to the agency's lending rules for new producers is to allow
more flexibility in the minimum experience requirement. Under the new rule, FSA
loan officers are now allowed to consider all prior farming experience,
including on-the-job training and formal education when determining eligibility
for FSA Farm Operating and Ownership Loans. To qualify for the Beginning Farmer
and Rancher Loan Program, applicants must have a minimum level of agricultural
experience, but not more than 10 years operating a farm or ranch. Whitaker also
recommends that people considering a farming career should visit a new USDA
website www.start2farm.gov to learn more about USDA and FSA programs for
beginning farmers and ranchers.

Iowa FSA's support for Beginning and Socially Disadvantaged Farmers and Ranchers
is evident in the high level of minority and new farmer participation generated
through staff outreach into the community. In 2011, 75% of all FSA farm loans in
Iowa were made to socially disadvantaged farmers and ranchers.

For more information about these and other USDA programs, you can always call or
visit your nearest USDA Farm Service Agency office that handles this type of
loan. The contact office for Lyon County farmers is Sibley, Iowa. There has been
a change in personnel at the Sibley Office where Joyce Heaton was a Farm Loan
Officer. Joyce has accepted a lateral transfer to Guthrie Center, Iowa where she
is providing service on farm loans. There are two new Farm Loan Officer Trainees
that have taken Joyce's place. They are Heather Helm-rich and Callie Erickson.
Heather and Callie will be working with farmers and bankers in Lyon, Osceola,
and Dickinson counties. John Vote, the Farm Loan Manager from Orange City, will
be guiding and assisting them in their work. For more information contact
Heather or Callie at 712-754-3643.

LOAD-DATE: July 11, 2013

                             152 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                               Irish Independent

                           February 14, 2017 Tuesday
                                   Edition 1;
                                National Edition

The pros and cons of partnerships versus company status for farmers

SECTION: FARMING;NEWS; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 759 words


QI have been following the recent articles on farm partnerships but I have been
advised in the past that entering a limited company would be a good option for
me. What are the main differences between a partnership and a limited company?
Are there any pitfalls to be aware of with these business structures? A The main
difference between a partnership and a limited company is that an entirely new
legal entity is created by forming a company. This new entity, while controlled
by the directors, is a separate legal being from the farmer, who is a director
and shareholder of the company. A partnership is the joining of, typically, two
self-employed farmers, who wish to combine their efforts and split the proceeds
that they make from the joint effort. In this context there is no new legal
being created.

Here are reasons to consider changing your business structure.

TAX EFFICIENCY The main factor which entices people to enter a new business
structure is greater efficiency and, mainly, tax efficiency. For farmers (and
their spouses) who are taxed at the higher rate, they must pay tax at in excess
of 50pc for the portion of their income which falls into the higher band.

This can make it difficult to accumulate money in the business over time, as the
farmer is returning over half of what he is making in tax.

The benefit to operating in a private limited company is that the company pays
corporation tax at the rate of 12.5pc on its profits.

This makes it easier to accumulate money in a company for reinvestment and other
purposes.

It is important to stress that a farmer who is a shareholder of the company and
who draws out some of the money that the farm company makes must pay income tax
at the ordinary rate.

For those farmers with relatively low need for personal drawings from the farm
(by comparison to the total profit that the farm business makes) he or she would
likely be better off farming in a company structure.

If, however, your drawings are close to the total profit of the farm, then there
is little or no benefit to operating in a limited company.

This is because there are some additional costs to operating as a limited
company, which would not arise for a self-employed person/partner in a
partnership.

For example, a company tax return tends to cost more than a personal tax return.

DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE/EU SCHEME BENEFITS For farmers at different stages of
their career, there will be inevitable differences in priorities. For example,
many young farmers starting out will be eager to expand or improve farm
infrastructure and so investment will be a priority.

In this context, partnerships have, in some circumstances, more beneficial
access to certain schemes.

A good example is the TAMS II, whereby partnerships with a qualifying young
trained farmer will be able to draw down a greater amount of funding than two
similar farmers who are not in a registered farm partnership.

Many of the schemes do not afford this benefit to limited companies even in
circumstances whereby one of the directors/shareholders meet the same criteria
as a young trained farmer.

LIMITED LIABILITY The post-boom years saw a greater focus on liability for
payment of loans and losses. In the vast majority of cases, for the purposes of
accessing bank finance - whether you are borrowing in the name of a limited
liability company or not - the financial institution will require a personal
guarantee.

It is only if the loan is not personally guaranteed by the
directors/shareholders that the liability for paying the loan will be limited to
the assets owned by the limited liability company.

In the context of a partnership, both partners are liable for the repayment of
loans in the terms agreed in the loan agreement.

OWNERSHIP AND SUCCESSION Both a company structure and a registered farm
partnership offer different ways to prepare for succession or the handing-on of
the family farm.

For example, the last budget introduced a tax incentive for those entering a
farm partnership with a view to transferring a portion of the farm assets during
the duration of the partnership.

Caution is advised before entering any such agreements insofar as you should
consult with a professional adviser on your individual circumstances before
entering any such agreements.

Theresa Murphy is a barrister based in Ardrahan, Co Galway. This article is
intended as a general guide only and professional advice should always be sought
for individual www.circumstances.No liability is accepted for errors.

partnership.S  ;  ;  OFTEN HAVE  ;  ;  BETTER ACCESS  ;  ;  TO SCHEMES ;

LOAD-DATE: February 14, 2017

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: IIN


             Copyright 2017 Independent Newspapers Ireland Limited
                              All Rights Reserved


                             153 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                             August 20, 2000 Sunday
                                  City Edition

Tall job for tough times FSA puts service first despite shaky ag economy

BYLINE: ART HOVEY Lincoln Journal Star

SECTION: B; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 650 words


You don't have to talk to the federal government's farm-lending leadership in
Lincoln for very long to get a sense of conflicting missions.

On the one hand, the Farm Service Agency is the lender of last resort to
farmers, and steps in when banks see too much risk. On the other, its farm loan
section, successor to the Farmers Home Administration, is a steward of the
taxpayer's money.

Or consider this: The state FSA office in Lincoln is in competition with other
major farm states for hundreds of millions of dollars in direct loans and loan
guarantees this year and every year. Yet it bears the scars of the 1980s farm
crisis, when other millions were never collected from bankrupt borrowers.

"The'80s are not that long ago," said John Berge, FSA executive director.
"The'80s, with their high interest rates, high inflation, were an
across-the-board nightmare in the economy, but particularly in agriculture."

Berge believes the agency learned something from the 1980s about careful
scrutiny of its loan portfolio.

"I think we'll use that institutional knowledge to our benefit when we lend out
money."

But he can't deny that the stakes of conflict are being raised again as another
fiscal year approaches Oct. 1. The $158 million in Nebraska loan guarantees in
1999 is the highest total since 1986. And FSA officials and taxpayers are
backing another $114 million in bank loans through mid-August of 2000.

If farmers hit with low prices, drought and other problems can't pay it back,
taxpayers will.

"It's a little bit nerve-wracking when you have to put out $158 million in
guaranteed loans to producers," conceded Berge. "That's an indication of a
serious problem in agriculture."

So far, said Mark Wilke, a farm loan specialist at the Lincoln office, there are
some reassuring factors. Interest rates, inflation and delinquency rates are all
much lower than in the 1980s and the economic barometer of farmland values has
been holding steady. But, "with farm income in question," Wilke said, "who knows
what land values will do in the future?"

While acknowledging their responsibilities to taxpayers, Berge and Wilke don't
want potential critics to lose sight of the point that the federal government
fills a crucial lending role in rough agricultural times. When banks are
hesitant to lend more money to struggling customers, federal backing can make
the difference in whether the loan is extended or not.

"We always look first of all at our mission," Wilke said, "Our mission is to
help existing farmers and help beginning farmers."

From that perspective, they are encouraged that they still had almost $69
million in unobligated loan guarantee money to use over the next six weeks. That
includes more than $27 million that came this way in competition with their
peers.

"We did very, very well in competition with other states in our region in
getting money back from national pooling," Berge said.

Overall, the Nebraska office is positioned to do more than $190 million in
direct loans and loan guarantees this fiscal year, including $31 million in
direct operating loans. So far in fiscal year 2000, the state's beginning
farmers have gotten about $30.1 million in direct and guaranteed ownership and
operating loans.

At this point, the delinquency rate attached to all the FSA lending is between 6
percent and 7 percent. At the beginning of 1986, the delinquency rate for its
predecessor, the Farmers Home Administration, was 22.2 percent.

In the absence of the boom and bust cycle that defined the last half of the
1970s and the first half of the 1980s, the FSA loan leadership is hoping to stay
in single digits for delinquencies.

"We get back to the initial question," Berge said. "Our mission is to provide
service to producers. That's one of the missions chartered to us by Congress, to
provide loan assistance to farmers. That's what we're doing."

Reach Art Hovey at 473-7241 or ahovey@journalstar.com.

LOAD-DATE: December 17, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: 2 color head photos of John Berge and Mark Wilke color graph of federal
farm loans, from 1986 until 2000, D. MATT VAN DRIEST Lincoln Journal Star,
Source: Nebraska Farm Service Agency

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2000 Lincoln Journal Star,
                              All Rights Reserved


                             154 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The American Banker

Easing the Farm Loan Interest Problem;
Minnesota's Gov. Perpich Signs Bill Offering State Subsidies to Farmers

                            March 7, 1985, Thursday

Special to the American Banker

DATELINE: ST. PAUL


Minnesota Gov. Rudy Perpich signed into law farm aid legislation that could
begin pumping $25 million into the state's ailing agriculture economy.

Designed to help farmers find credit for spring planting, the legislation
creates state subsidies for loan interest payments for qualified farmers and
sets up a subsidized debt restructuring program.

''I believe we have shown leadership in Minnesota,'' Gov. Perpich said as he
signed the bill on Tuesday, not more than an hour after the House passed it, 122
to 5.  ''We can only hope this message will be heard in Washington.''

He added, however, that it ''will in no way solve all the farm problems.'' Gov.
Perpich flew to Washington Wednesday to meet with congressional leaders and
representatives of the Reagan administration.

A Perpich ally and leading farm spokesman was more blunt about the limited
impact of the bill.

''Ever read in the Bible about the eye of the needle?'' said Rep. Glen Anderson,
D-Bellingham.  ''That's what you'll have to do to qualify for one of those
loans.''

Commerce Commissioner Michael Hatch said application forms have been drafted and
should be in the mail to the state's lending institutions on Friday.  He said
the lenders could begin processing loans Monday.

Rep. Elton Redalen, R-Fountain, the chief House sponsor of the farm aid bill,
said many lenders are already beginning to process some of the loans.

The Minnesota Senate passed the bill overwhelmingly last week. The House had
been expected to do the same on Monday, but a record-breaking snowstorm delayed
the passage by one day.

The Legislature has been under increasing pressure to act on farm aid since
early January when thousands of farmers flocked to St. Paul, the state capital,
demanding action to hold off farm foreclosures and to pump aid into farm
operations that might not obtain credit for spring planting.

The Senate version of the bill had contained a 120-day voluntary moratorium on
farm mortgage foreclosures.  That was dropped in a House-Senate conference
committee in the face of opposition from the Republican-controlled House.
Instead, loans submitted to the Farmers Home Administration for debt
restructuring will be immune from a foreclosure for up to 90 days.

The bill provides for interest subsidies for existing and new loans.  The state
will pay the interest attributable to the first 60 days of a 120-day loan period
for real estate and operating loans, up to $25,000 each.  Lenders will submit
the loans to the Farmers Home Administration for debt restructuring and loan
guarantees.

Officials say that only about 80 of more than 700 state banks are accredited by
the Farmers Home Administration to make such loans.

In addition, farmers may apply to lenders for a direct state subsidy for farm
operating loans. The loans must be offered at interest rates between 7% and 10%.
The loans would not extend beyond March 1, 1986, at which time they must be paid
off. For farmers to qualify for a subsidized loan, the lenders must analyze
their debt structure and projected revenues in order to assess whether the loan
would allow them to make a profit.

For every percentage point that a participating bank must reduce the interest
rate on the loan, the state will enable the bank to reduce the rate the farmer
pays on the loan by another two percentage points by subsidizing the repayment
of the loan.

The plan has been criticized as a bailout for banks instead of for farmers.
Sen. Charles Berg, R-Chokio, who refused to sign the conference committee
agreement, called the bill a ''cruel hoax.''

While the bill does not contain a major mortgage moratorium, the moratorium
issue is gaining momentum.

The Senate passed a one-year moratorium measure, and House Republicans are
planning their own version.

In a related move to help financially strapped farmers plant crops this spring,
a Minnesota Senate committee approved a bill Tuesday that would allow farmers to
delay paying the first half of their property taxes until Oct. 15.

First-half property taxes normally are due May 15.  The bill, approved
unanimously by the tax committee, gives farmers what amounts to a five-month
interest-free loan of $82 million.

Under the measure, local governments could borrow interest-free money from the
state to replace the deferred farm property taxes.  They would repay the state
after receiving second-half taxes in October.

SECTION: Pg. 3

LENGTH: 736 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1985 American Banker, Inc.


                             155 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                          September 7, 2016 Wednesday

Washington: Hoeven: USDA Makes Additional Funding Available to Support Up to
$185 Million in Farm Operating Loans, Loan Guarantees

LENGTH: 345  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the Senator John Hoeven has issued the following news
release:



 Senator John Hoeven, a member of the Senate Agriculture Committee and
Agriculture Appropriations Committee, today announced that the U.S. Department
of Agriculture (USDA) Farm Service Agency (FSA) will make additional funding
available to leverage up to $185 million in additional lending for direct and
guaranteed farm operation loans. Hoeven wrote to USDA Secretary Tom Vilsack in
July, urging the agency to replenish the loan programs to ensure that the
nation's agriculture producers have access to necessary credit during the
current period of low commodity prices.





 "These FSA loan programs exist to help our farmers and ranchers weather low
prices and keep their operations going," Hoeven said. "When the programs faced a
shortfall due to the rapid increase in demand for loans, we worked with USDA and
our colleagues in the Agriculture Committees of both chambers to reprogram FSA
funding to open up more loan authority. This means our ag producers will have
access to more capital to get them through these tough times."



 Due to low commodity prices and cash flow issues, farmers across the nation
have been increasingly relying on the FSA loan programs for temporary
assistance, which were then facing a shortfall in loan authority. The additional
funding announced today will help ensure that farmers have access to the capital
they need to continue their operations.



 To this same end, Hoeven and Senator Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) have introduced
the Capital for Farmers and Ranchers Act, legislation that increases the maximum
loan amount that an individual farmer or rancher is able to receive under the
FSA's loan and loan guarantee programs. Specifically, it increases the FSA loan
guarantee amount to cover up to $2.5 million, up from $1.39 million, and doubles
the amount on Direct Operating and Direct Farm Ownership Loans from $300,000 to
$600,000.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

LOAD-DATE: September 7, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                             158 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                             National Mortgage News

                                 July 12, 1993

Farm Credit System Raises Net Quarter Income

SECTION: FARM AND RURAL MORTGAGES; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 264 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The Farm Credit System reported net income of $ 397 million for the first
quarter of 1993, up from $ 243 million during the first quarter of 1992.

The first-quarter net income included $ 135 million from the cumulative effect
of an accounting change related the System's accounting for income taxes,
according to the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corp.

The first-quarter results also included a $ 32 million expense representing the
cumulative effect of an accounting change related to retirement benefits.

The first quarter 1992 results were restated downward by $ 37 million to
represent accounting changes as well.

The combined System income, before the cumulative effect of accounting changes,
increased five percent to $ 294 million for the first quarter of 1993.

"The System's operating performance for the quarter continued to be very
strong," said James Brickley, president and chief executive of the Funding Corp.

"Net interest margin was higher, and the credit quality of the System's loan
portfolio continued to improve."

Net interest income increased 10% to $ 488 million for the first quarter, due to
an increase in average net interest margin.

The higher interest margin reflected refinancing of higher-cost debt with
lower-cost debt.

The System sells debt in the capital markets to fund loans made by Farm Credit
associations across the country.

Long-term real estate loan volume remained relatively stable.

The System makes rural residential mortgage loans, agricultural real estate
loans, agricultural operating loans and loans to cooperatives.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1993 National Thrift News, Inc.


                             159 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                   January 9, 1989, MONDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

FARM CREDIT SYSTEM LEADERS VOTE TO REORGANIZE LOCAL INSTITUTIONS

BYLINE: Jerri Stroud Of the Post-Dispatch Staff

SECTION: BUSINESS PLUS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 1027 words


Leaders of Farm Credit System organizations in Missouri, Illinois and
Arkansashave voted to reorganize the system's local lending institutions,
pending approval by regulators and stockholders.  Late last year, directors of
local associations in the three states voted to consolidate 20 Federal Land Bank
Associations into nine and to split the Central Production Credit Association
into nine associations that would be managed jointly with the Land Bank groups.
The reorganization gives each of the paired groups ''an excellent prospect for
full financial and competitive vitality on into the 1990s,'' said C.T.
''Terry'' Fredrickson, chief executive of the Farm Credit Banks of St.  Louis.
''These prospects are based on financial analyses which assume substantial
further operating cost reductions,'' said Fredrickson.  The plan is designed to
move loan decisions and delivery closer to local customers, said Curt Billhymer,
a Farm Credit spokesman in St. Louis. The local groups will operate more
autonomously and thus will be able to provide more flexible service to
borrowers.  Under the plan, the Farm Credit Bank of St. Louis would give up
direct lending responsibilities for Land Bank loans, said Billhymer. The St.
Louis bank would then act only as a financial intermediary and funding source
for the local associations, much as it already does for production credit loans.
Land Bank associations make farm loans for real estate and other long-term
obligations. Production Credit Associations make short and intermediate-term
loans for such things as farm operating expenses, supplies and machinery.
Billhymer said the new plan does not necessarily mean that some Farm Credit
offices will close. But some back-office functions will be consolidated and some
employees could lose their jobs. The plan would have no immediate impact on
employment in St. Louis, but it could lead to more streamlining in the future,
he said.  Several local associations have elected to stay out of the new plan.
They are the Federal Land Bank Association in Caruthersville, Mo.; the
Production Credit Association in Sikeston, Mo.; the Southern Illinois Production
Credit Association in Harrisburg, Ill., and the Delta Production Credit
Association in Dermott, Ark. The same groups have stayed out of other
reorganization plans in the three states.  A task force developed the proposed
reorganization in the first half of 1988 and presented the plan to directors of
the Farm Credit Banks of St.  Louis in July. The vote by directors of the
smaller organizations brings the plan a step closer to reality.  The proposal
now goes to the Farm Credit Administration in Washington. If that regulatory
body approves the plan, stockholders likely will vote on the plan in May. If
stockholders approve the plan, the changes would occur on July 1.  Under the
plan, four Federal Land Bank Associations in Missouri would be consolidated into
two new associations. Two new Production Credit Associations would be set up and
managed jointly to serve the same territories as the corresponding Land Bank
groups.  One pair of associations would serve northeast, central and
east-central Missouri. The other pair would serve northwest, western and
southwest Missouri. Lending operations in five southeast Missouri counties would
be managed by a Land Bank and Production Credit group in eastern Arkansas.  In
Illinois, the eight Federal Land Bank Associations would be consolidated into
four new associations, each serving about a fourth of the state.  Four new
Production Credit Associations would be created to operate in the same
territories as the new Land Bank groups.  In Arkansas, eight Federal Land Bank
Associations would be consolidated into three, each serving about a third of the
state, divided vertically.  Three parallel Production Credit Associations would
be created and managed jointly with the Land Bank groups.

LOAD-DATE: October 23, 1993

LANGUAGE: English

GRAPHIC: Map; MAP by Post-Dispatch. Farm Credit Service Areas..in Missouri,
Arkansas and Illinois.

                  Copyright 1989 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


                             160 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                          Australian Financial Review

                              June 27, 1988 Monday
                                  Late Edition

US GOVERNMENT TO BEAR BRUNT OF FARM LOAN LOSSES

BYLINE: Source: _AP-Dow Jones

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Pg. 38

LENGTH: 762 words


Banks and other traditional US farm lenders may be able to avoid heavy losses
from the drought because of the Government's growing role in financing the
operations of US farmers.

Bankers, economists and agriculture officials say the Government's share of loan
losses from the drought is likely to be much higher than in previous dry spells.

This is because many Federal subsidy payments are made in advance of planting
under the current farm programme. These payments, which total $US4.3 billion,
often replace the planting loans farmers get from commercial banks, the Farm
Credit System and other lenders.

If crops fail, many farmers will not be able to pay back the advances.

Mr James Kirk, president of the Farm Credit System's Omaha bank, said about 85
per cent of farmers in his four-State area used the advance payments to plant.

"Smaller, healthier farmers haven't had to rely on borrowed money. The advance
payments have taken care of a lot of their requirements," he said.

Mr Richard Kovacevich, vice-chairman of Norwest Corp, one of the nation's
biggest agricultural lenders, said: "It's a Government drought."

He said the Minneapolis-based bank expected few loan losses from the drought,
largely because Federal payments, guarantees and other aspects of farm
programmes would bear the brunt of losses should the drought continue.

Other banks, the Farm Credit System and even the Government's own Farmers Home
Administration say their planting loan volume is down sharply under the latest
farm programme.

The Government expects the drought to save it money overall because market
prices for grains have soared.

That narrows the difference between market and so-called target prices that must
be made up with subsidy payments. The Government's increased financing role will
nonetheless reduce those savings.

The situation shows how the 1985 farm legislation, which has flooded the farm
economy with cash over the past three years, also expanded the Government's
exposure to losses.

Administration officials and members of Congress are already proposing emergency
relief, and the cost could run into billions of dollars.

"The Federal Government is going to be in for a lick," said Mr Brian Crowley, a
deputy director at the General Accounting Office.

He said emergency disaster loans made by the Government's Farmers Home
Administration tended to be "the toughest ones to collect".

Rather than make emergency loans, the Government could merely let farmers keep
the advance subsidy payments, he said.

Among the larger crops covered in the farm programme, use of the payments is
heavy. The $US4.3 billion of payments outstanding is a small sum compared with
the approximately $US140 billion of farm debt nationally, but it is among the
most likely to go uncollected.

Much farm debt is secured by real estate and other hard assets.

And banks, for the most part, have been more conservative in making planting
loans since the farm crisis unfolded.

Farm credit and commercial banks have been making far fewer operating loans,
cutting into their profits in good times but now, amid the drought, limiting
their potential losses.

"Everybody is less loaned up than in the past," said Mr Gundy Gunderson,
president of Commercial State Bank in Wausa, Nebraska.

Less than half of his $US18 million of assets is in loans, compared with 80 per
cent a few years ago.

An Agriculture Department economist, Mr Greg Gajewski, said: "The banks are in a
better position than they were in 1983", the last widespread drought.

Mr Kovacevich said: "We've got four cushions against losses from the drought,
all largely provided by the Government: subsidised crop insurance, a likely
emergency disaster loan programme or some other Federal bail-out, the fact that
some farmers have residual financial strength because of previous programmes,
and a strong outlook for prices next year."

Unfortunately, for farmers who have been operating near the brink of insolvency,
a crop ruined by drought could mean there will not be a next year- and federally
owned and controlled lenders finance most of these farmers.

Farmers Home Administration, the agricultural lender of last resort, and the
Farm Credit System have thousands of borrowers who could be hurt.

Mr Brent Beesley, president of the Farm Credit Corp of America, an arm of the
Farm Credit System, said the system had restructured 15,000 loans to troubled
borrowers in the past 18 months. Another 80,000 borrowers represented potential
problems.

"Clearly, a major decrease in farm income (from the drought) could push some of
them back into the problem state," he said.

LOAD-DATE: March 15, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             161 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                               Los Angeles Times

                          December 28, 2016 Wednesday
                                  Home Edition

U.S. budget patch averts farm loan crisis

BYLINE: Associated Press

SECTION: BUSINESS; Business Desk; Part C; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 589 words


U.S. farmers drained all available government agricultural loan money this last
fiscal year to get through one of the worst agricultural downturns in recent
years, but because of an unusual provision passed this month by Congress, no one
who qualifies for a farm loan will be denied in the next four months.

The budget patch gives the Agriculture Department's Farm Service Agency
authority to meet the surge in loan demand by using future funding, according to
Sen. Jerry Moran (R-Kan.), who chairs an agricultural appropriations panel.
There is no limit to how much the USDA can lend through April 28 -- a victory
for farm groups that pressed Washington for the fix to avert a looming loan
crisis.

Already, corn and wheat prices have pushed farmers to the limit, and beef prices
are hurting ranchers. They turned to lenders, leading the FSA to fall $137
million short of needed direct and guaranteed loan funds in the fiscal year
ending Sept. 30.

When the money ran out, approved loans were funded in the current fiscal year,
piling on to the demand for loans and raising the specter that FSA would again
run out of money before spring -- when most farmers need it the most.

"If you are trying to grow a crop and feed a family and pay the bills, it is a
problem," Moran said. "This is one of the most difficult times in agriculture in
a long time."

The top recipients of loan support from the FSA this year are states that are
heavy producers of grains, beans, livestock and dairy. In the first nine months
of 2016, Iowa led with $405 million, and Wisconsin, Nebraska, Minnesota, Texas,
Oklahoma and Arkansas each received more than $300 million. California -- which
has a $46-billion agricultural economy centered on fruits, nuts, vegetables and
dairy -- received $92 million, the agency said.

Operating loans for 2016 are coming due at a time of widespread downturn.
Farmers in Georgia, the Carolinas and Alabama have gotten a double whammy of
drought and flooding. Midwest states are reeling from a glut in global grain
markets that has slashed crop prices, and cotton growers in Georgia and Texas
are suffering because of low prices.

Not as many people are able to pay off their 2016 operating loans, and the next
60 to 90 days will be telling, said Steve Apodaca, vice president of the
American Bankers Assn.'s Center for Agricultural and Rural Banking in
Washington.

Most borrowers will be able to sustain themselves another year, and bankers will
be able to help restructure their loans and add federal guarantees to commercial
loans, Apodaca said. He is not expecting a repeat of the 1980s farm crisis, when
land values tanked and interest rates were high.

One measure of the farm economy is equity -- the amount of debt compared to
assets like land and machinery. The USDA's Economic Research Service predicted
last month that U.S. farm equity would decline 3.1% in 2016 to $2.47 trillion --
the second straight year of declines. Farm debt is expected to rise 5.2% to
$375.4 billion in 2016.

This year's bountiful yields and low interest rates on loans helped many
growers. But many commercial lenders are now demanding farmers whose operations
are under stress to get government guarantees that any money lent for next
year's crops will be repaid.

"When a farmer goes under, it affects that rural community," Apodaca said. "He
is no longer buying seed, he is no longer buying equipment. His family is no
longer going to the local Main Street and buying goods and services."

--

Times staff writer Geoffrey Mohan contributed to this report.

LOAD-DATE: December 28, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Wire

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                        Copyright 2016 Los Angeles Times
                              All Rights Reserved

             National Post's Financial Post & FP Investing (Canada)

                          December 28, 2016 Wednesday
                                 Final Edition

Budget patch will keep U.S. farmers from default

BYLINE: Roxana Hegeman, The Associated Press

SECTION: FINANCIAL POST; Pg. N5

LENGTH: 596 words

DATELINE: WICHITA, Kan.


U.S. farmers drained all available government agricultural loan money this past
fiscal year to get through one of the worst agricultural downturns in recent
years, but no one who qualifies for a farm loan will be denied in the next four
months due to an unusual provision passed this month by Congress.

The budget patch gives the Agriculture Department's Farm Service Agency
authority to meet the spike in loan demand by using future funding, according to
U.S. Sen. Jerry Moran, a Kansas Republican who chairs an agricultural
appropriations panel.

There is no limit to how much the USDA can lend through April 28 - a victory for
farm groups who pressed Washington for the fix to avert a looming loan crisis.

Already, corn and wheat prices have pushed farmers to the limit, and beef prices
are hurting ranchers. They turned to lenders, leading the FSA to fall $137
million short of needed direct and guaranteed loan funds in the fiscal year
ending Sept. 30.

When the money ran out, approved loans were funded in the current fiscal year,
piling on to the demand for loans and raising the spectre that FSA would again
run out of money before spring - when most farmers need it the most.

"If you are trying to grow a crop and feed a family and pay the bills, it is a
problem," Moran said. "This is one of the most difficult times in agriculture in
a long time." Operating loans for 2016 are coming due at a time of widespread
downturn. Farmers in Georgia, the Carolinas and Alabama have gotten a double
whammy of drought and flooding. Midwest states are reeling from a glut in global
grain markets that has slashed crop prices, and cotton growers in Georgia and
Texas also are suffering due to low prices. Consumer demand for milk is down.
Cattle prices are falling.

Not as many people are able to pay off their 2016 operating loans, and the next
60 to 90 days will be telling, said Steve Apodaca, vice-president for the
Washington, D.C.-based American Bankers Association's Center for Agricultural
and Rural Banking.

Most borrowers will be able to sustain themselves another year, and bankers will
be able to help re-structure their loans and add federal guarantees to
commercial loans, Apodaca said. He is not expecting a repeat of the farm crisis
of the 1980s, when land values tanked and interest rates were high.

Matt Ubell and his two siblings took out an FSA loan this month to buy their
parents' cattle and crops farm in Wheaton, Kansas, but he says the agricultural
economy "has us scared to death." Their balance sheet was just above the
break-even point to qualify for the loan.

"We are kind of starting out fresh. We bought the farm, we bought the
equipment." Ubell said. ".. . We are pretty highly leveraged right now." The
34-year-old farmer and his wife put in long hours to make ends meet for their
four children. His wife is a cook and a nursing assistant. He works at a
lumberyard and delivers liquidfeed supplements for cattle.

One measure of the farm economy is equity - the amount of debt compared to
assets such as land and machinery.

The USDA's Economic Research Service predicted last month U.S. farm equity would
decline 3.1 per cent in 2016 to $2.47 trillion - the second straight year of
declines. Farm debt is expected to rise 5.2 per cent to $375.4 billion in 2016.

With such low commodity prices, Russell Boening said he is doing everything he
can not to borrow more money than he absolutely needs to operate his 7,500-acre
family farm in south Texas because "that gets you further and further behind."

                             163 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               October 21, 1984, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

THE FARM BANKS BATTLE TO STAY AFLOAT

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER

SECTION: Section 3; Page 12, Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1695 words


WASHINGTONIn recent years, wheat farmers and

cattlemen in the tiny, high plains

town of Hereford, Colo., have had two local institutions they could count on.

One was Chuck Monpas's bowling alley and bar, the town's social center. The
other was the Hereford State Bank, which had been a source of feed and seed
loans for 65 seasons.

The bowling alley survives, but last Aug. 24 the hardy little bank that had
weathered the Great Depression was closed by the Colorado State Bank
Commissioner and turned over to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for
liquidation. Bank examiners said the bank had spread its modest assets too thin
in trying to prop up customers who would never repay their loans.

The demise of the Hereford State Bank was part of a larger reversal in a banking
sector that, for decades, has rested solidly on a prosperous farm economy. While
the banking industry at large is pulling out of the recession, many farm banks
are staggering under a burden of precarious loans into their worst slump since
the 1930's.

''When farming performed, these banks performed,'' said Emanuel Melichar, an
economist who follows farm banks for the Federal Reserve System. ''When it
turned around, it took the banks with it.''

For decades, the nation's farm banks - that is, any bank that makes 25 percent
or more of its loans to farmers - outperformed their city counterparts. But now
they are showing up in disproportionate numbers on lists of bank failures and
problem banks. Farm banks like Hereford, for example, accounted for 10 of the
nation's 27 bank failures between June 1 and Sept. 30. And six more of the 27,
while not classified as farm banks, nevertheless had 10 percent or more of their
loans outstanding to farmers when they failed. And farm-related loans were
implicated in the troubles of some banks not normally regarded as farm banks,
including the near failure of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust
Company.

The farm bank crisis is severe enough that most experts foresee additional farm
bank failures, and a period of tighter credit for already hard-pressed farmers.
And it has come on suddenly. At the end of 1983, the balance sheets of farm
banks still looked good. While these banks make up 28 percent of the nation's
more than 14,000 commercial banks, they accounted for only 24 percent of the
institutions on the ''problem bank'' list compiled by the Federal Deposit
Insurance Corporation in December. By last June, however, the figure had jumped
to 34 percent, and was rising.

Nor do the statistics augur well for the future. The portion of banks whose
delinquent loans exceed their total capital is growing rapidly in four farm
states: Iowa, Missouri, Kansas and Nebraska. This ratio is usually a reliable
barometer of severe banking problems ahead because total capital - the money
invested in a bank by its owners plus earnings set aside as loan loss reserves -
represents what a bank has available to cover the losses from loans that go bad.

''The farming people have not only caught up'' with the troubles of non- farm
banks, ''but the trend line is such that you would expect a further
deterioration,'' said Mr. Melichar. ''The speed of change is worrisome. The
outlook is poor.''

Banking experts hasten to add that they do not foresee a collapse like that of
the Depression era, when thousands of rural banks went broke because of
bankruptcies in the farm sector and depositor panic. Government price support
programs have put a floor under farm income, and Government insurance has put a
safety net under most bank depositors.

Moreover, most farm banks have adequate capital reserves built up during the
boom years since World War II. And most farm banks are still profitable. Last
year, farm banks had an average return on equity of 11 percent, a decline from
the peak of 16 percent in 1980, but still healthy.

Still, the squeeze on farm banks has caused drastic changes in the way many of
them do business. Those in communities with other commercial ventures have set
out to diversify their loans, said Weldon V. Barton, a farm credit specialist
for the Independent Bankers Association of America. And farm banks no longer
base their loans primarily on the value of a farmer's assets; now they look more
closely at his cash flow.

The adjustment is not always a pleasant one for a farm community.

According to Thomas H. Huston, superintendent of banks in Iowa, the tightening
of bank credit to farmers contributes, in turn, to a cycle of hardship for
everyone who does business with farmers. ''When they tighten up, they have to
put more people out of business,'' he said. ''And every time you put somebody
out of business there's more land and equipment on the market, and the values of
land and equipment fall again.''


FEDERAL regulators classify

about 4,300 institutions as farm

banks. Most are small, with $500 million or less in assets. But they hold the
bulk of the $50 billion in outstanding commercial farm loans, most of which is
short-term lending to cover a farmer's operating costs.

''The commercial banks that extend most of the operating debt are the
institutions that are primarily at risk,'' said Weldon V. Barton, a farm credit
specialist for the Independent Bankers Association of America. ''With
longer-term debt, at least you can hold on as long as it is manageable, and you
have land collateral. Shorter-term loans are usually secured with livestock or
machinery, and in order for farm producers to stay in business they have to get
continuous operating capital.''

Ten years ago, when farmers were commanding high prices for almost anything they
produced and when borrowing was easy, many farmers seized the opportunity to
expand their land holdings and buy new farm equipment. ''We were going to feed
the world,'' said John F. Spies, president of Iowa Trust and Savings Bank in
Emmetsburg. ''We were encouraged to plant fence to fence.''

Then came a series of body blows to the farm economy: The 1980 curtailment of
grain exports to the Soviet Union, a slump that year in grain prices, a dramatic
deflation in farm land values, and, above all, soaring interest rates. In many
communities, the hostile economy has been accompanied by drought.

Farmers who borrowed heavily during the boom have been caught far out on a limb.
The independent bankers association estimates that one in three farmers now has
debt worth at least 40 percent of his assets, and one in six has debt amounting
to 70 percent or more of assets.

Farm banks found themselves with legions of customers who could barely meet the
interest payments on their loans. Yet the farmers needed fresh loans last spring
to carry them through to another harvest if they were to have any hope of
avoiding bankruptcy. Bankers have negotiated loan extensions, but one common
method of refinancing a loan - selling a piece of land to pay a portion of the
debt - is complicated by the lack of a market for farm land.

The farmers' problems spread quickly to other bank customers. The machinery
dealers, feedlots, packing houses, grain elevators and local stores have
borrowed to tide them over a time of slack business. ''If agriculture doesn't
have any money, then they don't go to town,'' said Eldon Chandler, who was
president of the Hereford Bank when it failed. In Hereford, it was not troubled
farm loans that immediately precipitated the collapse, but loans to stores,
filling stations and repair shops that serve the farmers.

''The bank is forced to support all of those people to support the community,''
said Robert Neelley, president of the Friona State Bank in northern Texas. ''If
it doesn't, everybody goes down together.''

The solution, banking experts agree in a full-throated chorus, is lower interest
rates.

''Our rural communities just cannot live much longer with the interest rates
we're paying today,'' said John Tincher, president of the Lyndon State Bank in
Lyndon, Kan. ''As long as those rates stay at 14 1/2, 15 percent, every
agricultural bank in this country has something to worry about.''

To buy themselves time, bankers have lobbied for Federal loan guarantees, and
they have pleaded for more flexibility from bank examiners in tolerating
troubled loans.

Last month, the Reagan Administration, with an eye on the farm vote, announced a
new program to back up commercial bank farm loans with Federal guarantees.
Bankers would be required to forgive at least 10 percent of a troubled loan in
exchange for the Farmers Home Administration guaranteeing repayment of the
remaining 90 percent. For a loan to qualify, the farmer who holds it would have
to demonstrate that the 10 percent concession would improve his cash flow enough
to give him a reasonable chance of recovery.

The Farmers Home Administration said it expected to be making loan guarantees
within the next few weeks, using $706 million in lending authority just approved
by Congress. But while banking industry leaders initially appeared at an
Administration news conference to praise the program, many farm bankers now
contend it is too little, too complicated, and too late.

Many farm bank officials balk at forgiving debts, saying that would weaken their
own financial position in the eyes of bank examiners. They said picking
candidates for loan forgiveness is difficult, and would antagonize solid
customers who did not qualify for the Federal assistance.

''You'll find a lot of lip service paid to that kind of program, but I'll
venture a guess that you'll see very little participation,'' said Mr. Neelley,
the Texas bank president. But officials of the Farmers Home Administration said
they still believed some banks would use the program, rather than accept face
the alternative of having customers go bankrupt.

Both the Federal Reserve and the F.D.I.C. say they are trying to ease the
situation. They have issued memos to their examiners urging forebearance in
judging bankers' farm loans. Bankers said they have yet to see much change in
attitude among examiners in the field, however.

Says Mr. Barton: ''The bank regulators are increasingly classifying farm debt as
substandard debt.''


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo of Robert Neelley; Photo of exterior of Friona State Bank; Graph

                                 The Bond Buyer

House Panel Asks GAO to Research Farm Credit Woes

                           September 19, 1986, Friday

By Dave Ahearn

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 18


The House Agriculture Committee's credit subcommittee has asked the General
Accounting Office to research ways to solve the farm credit crisis outlined
today in a GAO report.

William J. Anderson, assistant comptroller general, said he will try to have a
report finished by Jan. 1.

In today's report, the GAO found that the Farm Credit System likely will run a
$2.9 billion operating loss for 1986, ''which would essentially deplete the
system's remaining surplus.'' But it still would have $9.6 billion in total
capital.

''Because the system's loan portfolio is essentially related to the depressed
agricultural economy, there is little hope of relief for the loan portfolio
problem during the next few years,'' the report said.

In addition, the system has borrowed money at high fixed rates, but lent money
to farmers at lower adjustable rates that sank still further as interest rates
declined.

The report calls for lessening the frequency of adjusting interest rates on
loans to farmers, making more fixed-rate loans to farmers, borrowing new funds
for the system by issuing securities with a call provision or floating rates,
and issuing more debt with short-term maturities.

But Farm Credit Administration chairman Frank Naylor pointed out that the system
cannot soon roll over about $18 billion of noncallable securities on which it
has to pay high yields.

Mr. Naylor urged the system to more aggressively seize collateral on
nonperforming loans to farmers and sell the collateral to raise money.

But some subcommittee members worry that seizing farms could create a glut of
farm land and depress the market value of all farms, worsening the problem.

Treasury undersecretary George D. Gould, when asked by reporters to comment on
the numbers in the GAO report, said he was ''surprised'' by the $2.9 billion
operating loss figure and said it was ''well beyond the numbers we've received''
from Farm Credit System officials.

SECTION: Pg. 4

LENGTH: 329 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             166 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The American Banker

Regulators' Farm Crisis Proposals Viewed Positively

                            March 13, 1986, Thursday

By JOHN P. FORDE

DATELINE: NEW YORK


Observers of the nation's farm bank crisis responded positively to relief
measures that regulators suggested in the Senate on Tuesday.

In Senate Banking Committee hearings on Tuesday, officials of the Federal
Deposit Insurance Corp., the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, and the
Federal Reserve Board outlined several steps that they would suggest to provide
relief to farm banks.

Jerry Swords, chairman of Swords Associates in Kansas City, Mo., said the
proposals show that ''the regulatory people are not letting up on poorly made or
speculative loans, but they're much more understanding on operating loans'' to
farmers. Swords Associates is a bank consulting firm that works with many
agricultural lenders.

Sandy McEvoy, director of governmental relations for the Independent Community
Banks of Illinois, said that, at first glance, the group is ''cautiously
pleased'' with the regulators' proposals. She added that they appear similar to
recent policy proposals by the Independent Bankers Association of America and
the American Bankers Association.

''We do believe it will help agricultural banks remain open and help them
continue to extend credit to their customers,'' she said.

The steps proposed on Tuesday included allowing farm banks to operate with
capital below the normal minimum capital requirements, provided the institution
has the capability to restore capital in five years.

The regulators also reaffirmed their policies to allow banks to forbear on farm
loans through appropriate debt restructurings, with the understanding that the
borrower will eventually be able to repay the loan.

They suggested that banks follow Financial Accounting Standards Board Rule 15,
which does not necessarily require a restructured loan to be charged off.  Under
this rule, the loan may stay on a bank's book if the total repayments on the
loan under the restructuring agreement equal at least the loan's principal
value.

''Anything that can be done to help these guys see if they can get a crop in the
ground is good,'' says Mr. Swords.

However, he cautioned that ''you want the guys who are deserving for operating
needs to get [the benefit of the proposals], not the guys who are going to use
it for speculative purposes, such as to buy more land and to feather their own
nest with it.''

While the consultant believes the proposals will help ease the plight of farmers
somewhat, he doesn't see the measures as a panacea for the farm debt crisis. He
believes the only permanent answer to the problem will be found in better crop
prices and lower interest rates.

''The farm economy functions very well at 6%,'' he said. ''Once you get above
that, it just doesn't function that well.''

But as for doing something to answer problems until interest rates come down or
prices go up, he said that ''the start has to be with the people who criticize
these loans.''

Regulators that declare loans nonperforming put the farmer on a ''liquidation
base,'' which causes foreclosures and takes farmers off their land. ''Then he's
on the public dole because you've taken away his means of living,'' said the
consultant.

One banking expert raised questions about the idea.

Anthony M. Santomero, professor of finance at the Wharton School of the
University of Pennsylvania, sees several problems in the reclassified loan
policies and lowered capital requirements for troubled farm banks.

The treatment of nonperforming loans has always been a ''crude classification,''
he said. A nonperforming loan can either be viable under the restructuring
agreement or it can be simply the last step before charging the loan off.

Mr. Sanotmero said he believes some banks may be overly optimistic in declaring
some farm loans restructured but viable. ''While the proposal makes intuitive
sense, its application is likely to result in the forestalling of doom'' at some
institutions, he says.

Also, he says that regulators may be hard pressed to limit the use of a
''restructured'' loan classification to farm banks. ''One thing is clear, '' he
said. ''There is no particular justification for taking one kind of loan and
treating it differentially.''

The lowering of capital ratios for troubled banks is another proposal which
''intuitively makes sense,'' but has practical problems, he said. ''What they're
trying to say is that if you get into trouble, you can use your capital to get
out,'' said Mr. Santomero. However, ''it is only the companies which the
regulators consider well-managed,'' but which ran into problems, which will get
the chance to work at lower capital guidelines, he added.

SECTION: Pg. 11

LENGTH: 769 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1986 American Banker, Inc.

                         Countryman (Western Australia)

                               September 25, 2014
                                 First Edition

$20m drought loans could be too late

SECTION: CTY; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 318  words


WAFarmers has welcomed the long-awaited arrival of $20 million in concessional
loans for the State's drought-stricken farmers, but warns it could be a case of
too little, too late.

In a joint statement released on Tuesday, Federal Minister for Agriculture
Barnaby Joyce and WA Minister for Agriculture and Food Ken Baston announced  WA
farmers could now apply for an Australian Government drought concessional loan.

To be eligible for a loan, WA farm businesses must be experiencing a one-in-20
year drought event, or a one-in-10 year drought event that has caused
significant financial impact.

Applicants must submit a valid Bureau of Meteorology rainfall deficiency report
as part of their application.

Drought concessional loans will be available for debt restructuring, operating
expenses and drought recovery and preparedness activities.

Mr Baston said the Rural Business Development Corporation was geared up to
deliver the loans.

But WAFarmers president Dale Park said although he was pleased to see the loans
finally made available, drought-stricken farmers had been let down over the time
it had taken to administer them, despite best assurances from government.

In late March this year, WAFarmers met with Mr Joyce and called for immediate
action to be taken by the State Government to ensure struggling farmers could
access the drought assistance package as soon as possible, he said

But we are now six months down the track and applications for the loans have
only just opened.

Had the loans been made available sooner, those in need could have put in crops,
appropriately serviced their stock or crops or substantially improved the
operating conditions of their farm businesses.

Mr Joyce said the drought concessional loans were in addition to other forms of
Federal support available to WA farmers such as farm finance concessional loans,
the farm household allowance and rural financial counselling.

LOAD-DATE: September 24, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

              Copyright 2013 GlobalData Ltd., All Rights Reserved
                         GlobalData - Company Statement

                               September 6, 2013

                                 AgriBank, FCB

                          30 E 7th Street, Suite 1600
                               St Paul,  MN 55101
                                 United States

* * * * * * * * * * COMPANY STATEMENT * * * * * * * * * *
Overview:

   The statement from the AgriBank, FCB Management's Discussion and Analysis
section is given below. The statement has been taken from the company's 2011
annual report.

   The Farm Credit System: Lending Support to Rural America

   The Farm Credit System is a nationwide network of borrower-owned lending
institutions and specialized service organizations. Farm Credit provides more
than $170 billion in loans, leases, and related services to farmers, ranchers,
rural homeowners, aquatic producers, timber harvesters, agribusinesses and
agricultural and rural utility cooperatives. Nearly one hundred years ago, the
United States (U.S.) Congress established the Farm Credit System to provide a
reliable source of credit for America's farmers and ranchers. The Farm Credit
System has been lending support to rural America throughout the 20th century and
into the 21st century. Today, the Farm Credit System provides more than
one-third of the credit needed by those who live and work in rural America.
Nearing Farm Credit's 100th anniversary, the Farm Credit System has:


     ·    Nearly 500,000 member-borrowers
     ·    political, legal, regulatory, financial markets and economic
          conditions and developments in the U.S. and abroad;
     ·    weather-related, disease, and other adverse climatic or biological
          conditions that periodically occur that impact agricultural
          productivity and income;
     ·    actions taken by the Federal Reserve System in implementing monetary
          policy.


   Financial Overview

   AgriBank's financial strength is clear, as proven by our strong financial
performance in 2011. This strength translates into long-termvalue for
customer/owners. We recorded net income of $464.9 million for the year ended
December 31, 2011. Net income continues to be very strong and reflects the
positive impact from our funding actions and fee income generated on repricing
assets and resulted in our second highest level of earnings trailing only 2010.

   Net interest income for 2011 continues to be very strong and reflects the
positive impact of our funding actions. During 2010, we took advantage of a
favorable interest rate environment and repriced unprecedented levels of debt at
lower costs at a pace, that exceeded the rate at which interest-earning assets
repriced. This continued in 2011, although at a slower pace, which was expected
given the level of activity in 2010 and the absolute low level of interest
rates. During this same timeframe, Association retail customers reduced their
interest costs by converting and refinancing a significant amount of loans,
which ultimately flowed through the pricing of our wholesale loans.

   Net interest income continues to be enhanced by the participation interests
in retail loans purchased under the Asset Pool program,which was initiated in
May 2008, and the AgDirect program, which was initiated in April 2011. Because
these assets were purchased from Associations, they were essentially converted
from wholesale assets to retail assets which positively impacted net interest
incomebecause they earn a retail spread for AgriBank. Related to the Asset Pool
program transactions, we established separate patronage pools for each
Association and in December, our Board declared patronage on each of these pools
in amounts that approximate the net earnings from each pool. Over time, we
expect to pay patronage for the AgDirect program in an amount approximately
equal to the net earnings of the program less a specified return on our capital.
Such patronage is at the sole discretion of the board. No patronage has been
declared on our AgDirect program as of December 31, 2011.

   Non-interest income was $121.7 million for 2011. Loan prepayment and fee
income was $54.4 million in 2011 reflecting fee income generated on repricing
assets. Business services income was $19.9 million in 2011 reflecting revenue
earned from business services offered to our Association customers. Mineral
income of $46.0 million was generated in 2011 from mineral rights held primarily
in North Dakota and Arkansas. Non-interest expense was $105.9 million in 2011
primarily consisting of $61.3 million of operating expenses and $23.3 million of
investment impairment losses. Total loans were $62.0 billion at December 31,
2011, an increase from $59.5 billion at December 31, 2010. AgriBank's primary
business is providing wholesale lending to its affiliated Associations.
Wholesale volume directly reflects the retail marketplace activities at the
Associations which are funded through their wholesale lines with the Bank.
Throughout the year Associations' seasonal operating loan demand was lower than
historical patterns, but this was more than offset by new volume in December
from strong levels of loan originations in the real estate mortgage sector and
advance purchases of 2012 inputs on operating lines. Loans also increased due to
$1.3 billion of loan volume purchased through the AgDirect program operated in
partnership with Farm Credit Associations.

   AgriBank's loan portfolio credit quality improved during 2011 and remains
strong at 99.7% acceptable and special mention under the Farm Credit
Administration's Uniform Classification System at December 31, 2011, up from
99.5% at December 31, 2010. This strong credit quality continues, in part, due
to cash grain producers experiencing strong profitability, higher milk prices
improving dairy profitability and ethanol producers remaining profitable. Our
capital totaled $3.8 billion at December 31, 2011, an increase of $211.0 million
over the capital level at December 31, 2010. This increase is primarily due to
the retention of net income and increased Association stock investments. We
recorded $289.8 million of patronage in 2011, consisting of $126.8 million
related to the Asset Pool program and $163.0 million of wholesale patronage.

                              The American Banker

Confidence Found Rising in Midwest

                          November 13, 1980, Thursday

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS


The ninth semi-annual survey of more than 700 Midwest bankers, conducted by
Northwestern National Bank of Minneapolis, shows growing optimism and improving
economic conditions throughout the region.  The result is summarized by the
Midwest Confidence Index which has been a good leading indicator of economic
activities in the region.  Back in 1979, the Index correctly predicted the
latest economic downturn.  Now the Index is painting a healthier economic
picture.

"Agriculture will lead the region out of recession," said Sung Won Son, senior
vice president and chief economist at Northwestern, whose staff conducted the
survey.  "Strong farm conditions will help agriculture-related businesses
prosper, with the recovery spreading to the whole farm community and ultimately,
the entire region.  Crops in large parts of the region are considerably better
than the national average," he said."And when combined with much improved
prices, farm income has rebounded sharply from depressed levels this past
spring.

Survey findings reveal most Twin Cities bankers anticipate a slow recovery from
the recession.  Half of these bankers expect economic conditions to remain at
current levels during the next six months, while 30% expect conditions to
improve.  Thus, the economic recovery in the Twin Cities is expected to be
slower than in most farm communities in Minnesota.  This contrasts with the past
six months in which economic activity tended to be more depressed in farm
communities than in the Twin Cities.

The survey of bankers in the Twin Cities, Minesota's Iron Range and rural
communities in Minnesota, Iowa, Montana, Nebraska, North and South Dakota and
western Wisconsin found Iowa and Minnesota bankers showing the greatest amount
of confidence concerning the general economic outlook for 1981.  The most
pessimistic appraisal was found in western South Dakota.

According to the survey, liquidity is significantly higher at agricultural banks
as evidenced by a sharp drop in the average loan-to-deposit ratio, falling to
its lowest level in three years.  The increased liquidity is a result of sharply
reduced farm machinery purchases earlier this year; increased marketing of
grains; bonus payments from oil and gas leases; and reductions in beef cattle
herds which have temporarily increased deposits and reduced loans.

Loan demand at agricultural banks is expected to be stronger in 1981.  The
greatest increase is anticipated in crop operating loans, followed by farm
machinery and equipment loans.  The increase in crop operating loans reflects
the upward march in farm production costs combined with the adverse impact the
drought will have on cash flows in some locations.  Liquidity presures, however,
are not expected to become widespread.

Complete results of the survey were released in "northwest Economic Indicators,"
a monthly publication of the Economics Department of Northwestern Bank.
