                             240 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The American Banker

Banking Groups Appeal for Farm Lending Relief

                            February 7, 1986, Friday

By JAY ROSENSTEIN; Miriam Hill contributed to this story

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The banking industry on Thursday appealed to the government for changes in
regulatory accounting procedures and other relief as ways to assist troubled
farm lenders.

A joint task force of the American Bankers Association and the Independent
Bankers Association of America, the two largest trade groups for the industry,
developed the recommendations, which were sent to House Agriculture subcommittee
chairman Ed Jones, D-Tenn., by Bud Gerhart, chairman of the IBAA's
agriculture-rural committee, and Randall Killebrew, vice chairman of the ABA's
government relations council. The committee released copies of the proposals on
Thursday at a hearing on farm credit problems.

At a time of budget constraints, it is unclear whether the government will be
more willing than in the past to assist farm banks.

The ABA/IBAA proposals are aimed at stabilizing bank capital levels as well as
supporting farm borrowers and farm real estate values.

The recommendations include:

* Changes in regulatory accounting procedures to enable prudently managed banks
to amortize their loan losses over several years. ''Such a procedure is
relatively simple to administer, would assist a broad segment of banks and their
borrowers, and would entail no direct government cost,'' the groups said.

* Enabling regulators to inject capital into some troubled banks, such as in the
form of debt or equity. Another option is to authorize net worth or income
capital certificates for banks similar to those currently authorized for thrift
institutions.

* Expansion of the role of the Agriculture Department. One suggestion was to
increase the Farmers Home Administration agricultural loan guaranty programs as
a low-cost way for the government to stabilize and extend farm debt. Another was
to provide cash flow assistance to borrowers by expanding the interest rate
buy-down program, in which the government matches a farm bank's reduction in its
loan interest rate. The banking groups also asked for a clarification of the
Farmers Home Administration's willingness to provide direct loans to farmers who
cannot be financed in full by commercial lenders.

* Developing a secondary market for long-term real estate loans originated by
banks as a way to stabilizing farm real estate values. The groups said this
would provide additional funds and diversify the risks and returns from farm
lending. Among the options, they said, is to pool Farmers Home Administration
guaranteed loans for resale as mortgage-backed securities.  'Where Existing Law
Is Inadequate'

The ABA and IBAA said they would seek regulatory action where possible as well
as legislation ''where existing law is inadequate.''

The bank groups also cautioned about the potential impact of House-passed tax
legislation that would decrease the flexibility of banks to recognize losses and
in turn increase the impact of losses on bank capital levels. The provision
would cut back the current authority to carry net operating losses back 10 years
and to obtain refunds for taxes paid in those years. ''If this change were to
become law,'' the two groups said, ''agricultural banks now incurring net
operating losses would lose some of their ability to maintain an adequate level
of capital.''

The ABA has a membership of about 13,000 banks, or about 90% of the industry.
The IBAA has a membership of about 7,200 mostly small and rural banks. The work
of the two groups on the farm credit proposal is a sign of the severity of the
farm problem in the eyes of the industry.

At a hearing on Thursday of the House Agriculture subcommittee on conservation,
credit, and rural development, Farmers Home Administration official Vance L.
Clark said his office will try every option before it moves to take adverse
action against farmers with delinquent loans. Rescheduling of loans, deferral of
payments, and restructuring of loans are among the options available to farmers
with delinquent loans, he said, adding that not all farmers will be able to
resolve their debt problems.

''There are those who are so far behind or have a debt structure that no amount
of assistance can help,'' he said.

Mr. Clark said the new Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law eventually will force
the Farmers Home Administration to reduce direct loan programs by 4.3%, but that
the agency should be able to provide essential services for the current fiscal
year.

Also testifying was Frank Naylor, under secretary of the Agriculture Department,
who said there is adequate credit available for farmers.

SECTION: AGRICULTURAL LENDING; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 755 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1986 American Banker, Inc.

                             245 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                           Merredin Wheatbelt Mercury

                               September 30, 2014

Drought relief delay hurts: WAFarmers

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 414  words


WAFARMERS president Dale Park has slammed a six-month state government delay in
implementing federal concessional drought relief loans.

They were made available to farmers only last week.

The delay in delivering the WA loans program had put some farmers into further
financial difficulty, Mr Park said.

WAFarmers met federal Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce on March 21 and called
for immediate action to be taken by the state government to ensure struggling
farmers could access the drought assistance package as soon as possible.

"We are pleased to see these loans finally made available to those who require
assistance," Mr Park said last week.

"However, despite assurances everything was being done to make these loans
available promptly, we are six months down the track and applications have just
opened.

"Had the loans been made available sooner, those in need could have put in
crops, appropriately serviced their stock or crops, or substantially improved
the operating conditions of their farm businesses."

Mr Park said it was good to see the loans could be used to restructure existing
debt, but there were still concerns about the eligibility of many in need
considering the onus to prove substantial rainfall deficiency.

"While many of the areas of concern have had substantial dry periods or erratic
rainfall, these are not often recognised through official rainfall data," Mr
Park said.

"I would encourage anyone who would benefit from these loans to apply, even if
they are not certain of their eligibility, and not to self-assess."

WA Agriculture and Food Minister Ken Baston and Mr Joyce jointly announced on
Tuesday last week that WA drought-impacted farm businesses could apply for up to
$1 million or half their eligible debt in concessional loans at an initial rate
of 4 per cent interest-only payments over five years.

Loans could be used to restructure existing debt, finance operating costs and
preparations for recovery from drought.

Eligible farm businesses must be in a one-in-20-year drought or a one-in-10-year
drought which has caused significant financial impact and applicants must submit
a Bureau Of Meteorology Rainfall Defi ciency Report to support their
application.

Mr Baston urged farm businesses not to self-assess their eligibility and to
contact the Rural Business Development Corporation to find out more about the
scheme and what was required to apply.

For information on the Drought Concessional Loans Scheme visit agric.wa.gov.au
or free call 1800 198 231.

LOAD-DATE: October 02, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                             246 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The American Banker

Minnesota Senate Backs Moratorium on Farm Foreclosures

                            February 1, 1985, Friday

By ANDREA BENNETT

DATELINE: CHICAGO


Calls for moratoriums on farm foreclosures are picking up steam in the Midwest.

A bill that calls for a voluntary 120-day moratorium on farm foreclosures was
passed by the Minnesota Senate last week and is being considered by the state's
House of Representatives.

That action comes on the heels of calls for a similar moratorium in Iowa by farm
groups there. Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad has said he will give himself until March
1 to decide whether or not to impose one.

The Minnesota bill, which represents a coalition effort by farm and banking
groups in the state, passed the Senate on a voice vote with ''practically no
opposition to it in its final form,'' said Norbert A.  McCrady, executive vice
president of the Independent Bankers of Minnesota.

To not support the moratorium would have been ''playing with fire,'' Mr.
McCrady said. A narrowly defeated amendment to the bill calling for a mandatory
one-year moratorium ''points to the danger that could come from opposing this
moderate bill,'' he said. ''Those opposing the bill think that the alternative
is no moratorium at all. That is not true. The alternative is a mandatory
moratorium for a year or possibly two.''

Under the bill, lenders can choose to participate in a 120-day voluntary
moratorium on farm loan foreclosures. The moratorium will cover both real estate
and operating loans and would halt both current foreclosures and the start of
future foreclosure actions during the 120 days. For the first 60 days of the
moratorium, the state will pay interest on up to one real estate and one
operating loan per customer.

Mr. McCrady estimated that about 300 of the state's 765 banks would participate
in the voluntary action should it become law and that the cost to the state for
the interest payments would be about $9.2 million.  He said nearly all of the
state's agricultural banks ''will be anxious to go into this because the
alternative is to have too many loans go down the tube.''

Among the farming groups supporting the bill are the Minnesota Farmers Union,
the Minnesota National Farmers Organization, and the Minnesota American
Agricultural Movement. Kim Brown, communications director for the Minnesota
Farmers Union, said the coalition had been working together since last fall.

A second part of the bill, calling for support of a Communicating for
Agriculture debt-modification proposal, also has the support of the Minnesota
Bankers Association. Mr. McCrady said this proposal would ''put [more] money''
into the federal farm lending agencies and would need federal action to go into
effect.

But the bankers association was lukewarm in its support of the debt moratorium.
An agricultural task force for the group outlined a 10-point program to help
ease current agricultural problems, including ''acceptance'' of the voluntary
120-day moratorium. The task force said the Minnesota BA opposed moratoriums
''as a matter of principle'' but would not oppose the 120-day grace period
called for in the bill.

But the bankers association said it believed ''that the dollars allocated in
Senate File 54 [the voluntary moratorium bill] could be put to more effective
and immediate use by funding a joint state-lender farm operating loan interest
reduction program.''

The association's proposal called for a combination of state and federal
actions, including the formation of such a joint interest-reduction program.
Other proposals included looking into creating a state bonding program making
funds available for agricultural loans, programs to inject equity capital into
farming operations, tax relief for farmers, allowing higher prices for food
products, and reducing the federal budget deficit.

If state actions are not met by help at the federal level, ''the effect will be
little more than trying to heal a gaping wound with a bandaid,'' task force
chairman Les Peterson said.

Mr. McCrady termed the voluntary moratorium bill ''a moderate, partial
solution.'' He said the Independent Bankers of Minnesota also wants to drum up
support on the federal level for the Communicating for Agriculture
debt-modification proposal and work for a 1985 farm bill different from the one
being proposed by the Reagan administration.

SECTION: Pg. 6

LENGTH: 705 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                 De Baca County News (Fort Sumner, New Mexico)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                               February 16, 2012

FSA promotes loans for new farmers, ranchers

BYLINE: De Baca County News staff

LENGTH: 397  words


ALBUQUERQUE - The USDA Farm Service Agency recently unveiled a new Land Contract
Guarantee Program and several other tools designed to help beginning farmers and
ranchers build the foundation for a successful career in agriculture.

"New farmers face many challenges, like obtaining land for example," said FSA
acting director Brenda Archuleta "FSA is going to provide new options to help
them to work through this challenging start-up issue."

Peak land values, tight commercial credit, minimal credit history and less
collateral make it difficult for new and smaller farmers in New Mexico to get a
commercial business loan right now. The Land Contract Guarantee Program provides
a new approach for landowners willing to sell and finance a land purchase to a
beginning or socially disadvantaged farmer. The national program offers two
options, one that guarantees up to three annual installment payments on the
contract and one that guarantees 90% of the unpaid principal of the contract.
Guarantees can be used in the purchase of land for up to $500,000.

"New Mexico farmers represent all walks of life, a wide variety of ethnic
backgrounds, and all different ages," notes Archuleta. "This new program will
work well for beginning and minority growers in our state and we encourage
producers to visit with us to see if they qualify and how it could fit their
needs," she said.

Another new change to the agency's lending rules for new producers is to allow
more flexibility in the minimum experience requirement. Under the new rule, FSA
loan officers are allowed to consider all prior farming experience, including
on-the-job training and formal education when determining eligibility for FSA
Farm Operating and Ownership Loans.

To qualify for the Beginning Farmer and Rancher Loan Program, applicants must
have a minimum level of agricultural experience, but not more than 10 years
operating a farm or ranch. Archuleta also recommends that people considering a
farming career should visit a new USDA website www.start2farm.gov to learn more
about USDA and FSA programs for beginning farmers and ranchers.

In 2011, 35% of all FSA farm loans in New Mexico were made to socially
disadvantaged farmers and ranchers and 53% of the loans were to beginning
producers.

For more information about these and other USDA programs, you can always call or
visit the nearest USDA Farm Service Agency office.

LOAD-DATE: March 24, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Local Government

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

LOAD-DATE: February 24, 2017


                             252 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             April 19, 1996 Friday

LENGTH: 177 words


Among new policies would be: þ Direct farm ownership loans may not be used to
refinance existing debt. þ Delinquent borrowers may not receive loans for
essential family living or operating expenses. þ Borrowers who have received
debt forgiveness in the past are not eligible for direct or guaranteed loans. þ
The Farm Service Agency will require an interest payment on all loans as a
condition of rescheduling or reamortizing loans. þ The option to buy out a loan
at net recovery value is eliminated and replaced with a buy-out option at
current market value. þ The lease buy-back program is eliminated. þ The agency
will notify a borrower of delinquent status when the delinquency has reached 90
days, instead of 180 days as provided under the previous law. þ The are new
limits on the number of years the agency can make a direct operating loan to a
farmer and guarantee a loan to a farmer. þ A borrower may be required to
purchase hazard insurance as a condition for receiving loans. þ The agency may
use collection agencies to collect loans when appropriate.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


       Copyright 1996 The Bismarck Tribune, a division of Lee Enterprises
                              All Rights Reserved


                             253 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The American Banker

Farm Credit Banks Turn Up Heat in Agriculture Lending

                          January 14, 1998, Wednesday

By JOANNA SULLIVAN


Bankers can expect a fresh blast of competition from the Farm Credit System.

Eleven years after nearly collapsing during a farm crisis, the
government-sponsored system is back on its feet and launching an aggressive
drive to boost its 25% share of the agricultural lending market.

"It's time now to develop some business," said Marsha Pyle Martin, chairman and
chief executive of the Farm Credit Administration, the system's top regulator.

Commercial banks, which have long viewed the system warily, already are feeling
the heat.

"They're getting tougher all the time-they're getting bolder," said Duane W.
Foelske, senior vice president at $110 million-asset State Bank of Waverly in
Iowa.

Adds John M. Blanchfield, manager of agricultural banking for the American
Bankers Association: "They're doing a lot of stuff-and our guys don't like any
of it."

The system, started in 1916 to increase credit to farmers, is made up of 213
borrower-owned cooperative banks and associations that operate throughout the
United States and Puerto Rico. Six Farm Credit banks and one agricultural credit
bank distribute low-cost funds to the associations through a variety of
intermediaries. Through Sept. 30, the system held about $63 billion of farm
loans.

In the view of many bankers, the system is an unfair competitor. They see it as
a monolithic government agency bent on stealing customers. And they point out
that the system is able to fund itself with bonds that carry the implicit
backing of the government.

"We're competing with our own government," said Dennis H. White, chairman of
First Bankshares, Valley City, N.D. "They compete head to head with us for
agricultural operating loans and cattle loans and real estate loans. But they're
able to buy their money a lot cheaper than we can."

Ms. Martin brushes off such criticisms, saying the system is simply an easy
target for banks. The system "gets a little more than its fair share of
criticism," she said.

Ultimately, she says, the Farm Credit System helps keep food prices down, by
giving farmers and ranchers another funding option. She maintains that the cost
of credit would rise one percentage point in most markets if the system
disappeared tomorrow.

"They are a vital part of the rural credit landscape," said Bret Healy,
legislative assistant to Sen. Tim Johnson, D-S.D., who specializes in
agriculture and international trade.

Though commercial banks hold a majority of farm debt-about 40%-the industry lost
some ground to the Farm Credit System in 1996. It was the first time in 14 years
that commercial banks had lost market share.

Meanwhile, the system has been gaining share of farm debt since 1994, after
falling steadily from a high of 34% in 1982. An aggressive cost- cutting
program, including the closure of 31 Farm Credit banks and associations, helped
revive the organization.

Ms. Martin says the government-sponsored enterprise is determined to grow
stronger and adds that Congress won't bail it out again. Congress had to step in
and save the Farm Credit System in 1987. Since then, the system has been on a
capital-building mission, increasing its capital nearly 50% in the past five
years.

Now, the agency is on the offensive, trying to drum up business nationwide.
Aggressive advertising is becoming commonplace in some markets.

Mr. Foelske, the Iowa banker, said Farm Credit banks in the Midwest are
pummeling commercial banks by advertising five-year, fixed-rate agricultural
loans and 15-year, fixed-rate farm real estate loans at 7.75%. He said his bank
can offer the five-year loan at no lower than 8.5%.

"We're doing the best we can," he said. "We've been able to hold our loans
steady. But we're not really expanding our loan volume."

Meanwhile, bankers are anxious about some recent moves by the system to move
beyond its traditional turf.

For example, the system has launched a program aimed at giving agribusinesses,
such as seed dealers and farm equipment manufacturers, equipment and operating
loans and accounts receivable financing. Previously, the system served mainly
farmers and ranchers.

The ABA and Independent Bankers Association of America claim Farm Credit's foray
into agribusiness lending will cut further into banks' business. The groups are
debating whether to appeal a U.S. District Court judge's decision allowing the
practice to continue.

"The issue is what role should they play," said Mark Scanlan, IBAA's
agricultural lobbyist. "They seem to see their role as one of continually
expanding into new markets. That's what the commercial banking industry is
objecting to."

To help its members meet the increased competition, the trade group is backing
federal legislation that would let banks with less than $500 million of assets
join the Federal Home Loan Bank System without meeting the requirement that 10%
of assets be in mortgage-related holdings. Under the plan, the banks would be
able to use long-term advances from a Federal Home Loan Bank for funding
agricultural loans.

The proposed changes are part of the sweeping financial reform bill awaiting a
possible House vote.

In another step to become more competitive, a growing number of banks are using
the rejuvenated Farmer Mac program, a government-sponsored enterprise that buys
agricultural loans from banks. Bankers are using the Farmer Mac program to gain
liquidity and provide better interest rates.

Ms. Martin of the Farm Credit Administration said commercial banks could use the
system's banks and associations to solve their liquidity problems by
participating in loans with them. But she said many commercial banks,
particularly in the Upper Midwest, are fearful of such joint efforts because
they might lose customers.

John H. Colvin, president and CEO of North Salem State Bank in Indiana, said it
has worked with the Farm Credit System to offer credit to farmers who couldn't
qualify on their own. Farm Credit has made the long-term real estate loan, and
the bank offers the customer a line of credit.

"I think they keep us all honest," he said of the system. "They're good ,
they're tough. There's a place for them."

J.R. "Bob" Jamison, chairman of Dayton (Tex.) State Bank, puts some of the blame
for his Farm Credit competition on his own industry.

"If they were not around, I think there would be fewer farmers because I don't
think banks have done a really good job in agriculture," he said.

Copyright c 1998 American Banker, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
http://www.americanbanker.com

SECTION: COMMUNITY BANKING; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1085 words

LOAD-DATE: January 13, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1998 American Banker, Inc.

                         The Pendleton Record (Oregon)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 March 27, 2014

Farm Loan Program Modifications Create Flexibility for New and Existing Farmers
and Ranchers Alike

BYLINE: The Pendleton Record staff

LENGTH: 356  words


Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsackhasannounced increased opportunity for
producers as a result of the 2014 Farm Bill. A fact sheet outlining
modifications to the U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) Farm Service Agency
(FSA) Farm Loan Programs is available here.

"Our nation's farmers and ranchers are the engine of the rural economy. These
improvements to our Farm Loan Programs will help a new generation begin farming
and grow existing farm operations," said Secretary Vilsack. "Today's
announcement represents just one part of a series of investments the new Farm
Bill makes in the next generation of agriculture, which is critical to economic
growth in communities across the country."

The Farm Bill expands lending opportunities for thousands o\ farmers and
ranchers to begin and continue operations, including greater flexibility in
determining eligibility, raising loan limits, and emphasizing beginning and
socially disadvantaged producers.

Changes that will take effect immediately include:

Elimination of loan term limits for guaranteed operating loans Modification of
the definition of beginning farmer, using the average farm size for the county
as a qualifier instead of the median farm size.

Modification of the Joint Financing Direct Farm Ownership Interest Rate to 2
percent less than regular Direct Farm Ownership rate, with a floor of 2.5
percent Previously, the rate was established at 5 percent.

Increase of the maximum loan amount for Direct Farm Ownership down payments from
$225,000 to $300,000.

Elimination of rural residency requirement for Youth Loans, allowing urban youth
to benefit Debt forgiveness on Youth Loans, which will not prevent borrowers
from obtaining additional loans from the federal government.

Increase of the guarantee amount on Conservation Loans from 75 to 80 percent and
90 percent for socially disadvantaged borrowers and beginning farmers.

Microloans will not count toward loan term limits for veterans and beginning
farmers.

Additional modifications must be implemented through the rulemaking processes.
Visit the FSA Farm Bill website for detailed information and updates to farm
loan programs.

LOAD-DATE: November 22, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Agriculture

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             255 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


               National Post (f/k/a The Financial Post) (Canada)

                           November 21, 2015 Saturday
                            All_but_Toronto Edition

A sour taste for prefs

BYLINE: Barry Critchley, Financial Post

SECTION: NEWS; Off The Record; Pg. FP2

LENGTH: 567 words


The long and unpleasant times for preferred shareholders at Dominion Citrus
Income Fund, a public entity since early 2006, continue.

The latest blow - the preferred shares were issued in late 2002 by Dominion
Citrus Ltd. to help finance a takeover - occurred this month when investors were
told Dominion Citrus Ltd. (the operating company) had defaulted on a $19.258
million loan it had taken out with the income fund.

That loan - technically 10-year participating notes with very attractive terms
to the provider - was made when the income fund was formed. The notes mature on
Jan. 1, 2016. For some reason the preferred shares remained outstanding when the
income fund was formed. It's understood no income fund and few REITs have issued
preferred shares.

A few days after news of the default, the other shoe dropped: The income fund
indicated it would exercise its option to acquire Dominion Farm Produce from
Dominion Citrus Ltd. The fund secured that option in early 2014 when it agreed
to waive payments on the participating notes for 18 months. That option -
whereby the fund would pay fair market value - expired on July 1, 2015. One
obvious question: Did the operating company get a high enough price for agreeing
to that option?

The transfer - with the fund agreeing to pay fair market value - is set to close
at the end of the month. Klein Farber Corporate Finance will determine fair
value.

The fund will pay for the purchase of the farm produce division from the
outstanding interest owed on the notes and by cancelling part of the loan owed.
Calls to the fund and the operating company seeking a comment on the possible
price weren't returned. One source placed an estimate of $7 million on the unit
being acquired.

Because of the impending purchase of Dominion Farm Produce Ltd. by the income
fund there's a weakening in the underlying assets of the operating company. That
change makes the situation worse for preferred shareholders - whose claim is on
the assets of the operating company.

The looming asset sale is the latest in a series of knocks for the preferred
shareholders. For instance:

They have hardly received any dividend payments since June, 2009. At last
report, $696,000 is owing on the prefs. Because so many payments have been
missed, holders now own voting securities of the income fund;

While the prefs are in theory retractable, in practice they aren't, because the
company has invoked a section of the Business Corporations Act. That section,
Dominion said, precludes paying out the pref holders if the realizable value of
the company's assets "would be less than the aggregate of its liabilities and
stated capital of all classes."

To redress the situation, a series of lawsuits have been launched, one of which
is working its way through the courts.

The attractive terms attached to the notes - and approved by a court under a
plan of arrangement almost 10 years back - also irks the preferred shareholders.
In 2006, the base rate on the notes was set at 13 per cent with the option for
additional interest that could equal the company's taxable income. A literal
reading of the terms would indicate none of the cash could flow to the pref
holders.

No wonder they are upset at the issuer, at the courts, which approved the
transaction, and the regulators, which show no inclination to act.

bcritchley@nationalpost.com !@COPYRIGHT=© 2015 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights
reserved.

LOAD-DATE: November 21, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Column

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                          Copyright 2015 National Post
                              All Rights Reserved

             National Post's Financial Post & FP Investing (Canada)

                           November 21, 2015 Saturday
                                National Edition

A sour taste for prefs

BYLINE: Barry Critchley, Financial Post

SECTION: FINANCIAL POST; Off The Record; Pg. FP2

LENGTH: 568 words


The long and unpleasant times for preferred shareholders at Dominion Citrus
Income Fund, a public entity since early 2006, continue.

The latest blow - the preferred shares were issued in late 2002 by Dominion
Citrus Ltd. to help finance a takeover - occurred this month when investors were
told Dominion Citrus Ltd. (the operating company) had defaulted on a $19.258
million loan it had taken out with the income fund.

change makes the situation worse for preferred shareholders - whose claim is on
the assets of the operating company.

shareholders. For instance: ..They have hardly received any dividend payments

fund; ..While the prefs are in theory retractable, in practice they aren't,

No wonder they are upset at the issuer, at the courts, which approved the
transaction, and the regulators, which show no inclination to act.

                                American Banker

                          September 21, 2006 Thursday

Will Farm Agency Increase Its Fees for Loan Guarantees?

BYLINE: Ben Jackson

SECTION: COMMUNITY BANKING; Pg. 5 Vol. 171 No. 182

LENGTH: 636  words


The federal government's new fiscal year is less than two weeks away, but

the Agriculture Department has not decided whether to raise fees on a loan

guarantee program popular with farmers and ranchers -- and their lenders.

Borrowers, lenders, and both houses of Congress oppose a fee hike, but if

Congress does not pass an Agriculture Department appropriations bill before

adjourning to campaign for midterm elections, the department would have the

authority to raise fees on loans guaranteed by its Farm Service Agency.

If the fees are raised, borrowers who could least afford it would be

paying considerably more for loans, said Jeff Wolfgram, a vice president at

the $623 million-asset First Dakota National Bank in Yankton, S.D.

He said his bank uses the guarantees to help farmers who have run into

troubles because of higher energy costs and bad weather.

"Some of the user fee increases ... [the Agriculture Department] is

talking about implementing could be a huge hurdle to the borrower," Mr.

Wolfgram said. "We're talking about paying the government two to three times

more" to use the agency's program.

So far the Farm Service Agency is not tipping its hand. Stevin Wescott, a

spokesman for the agency, would not discuss the matter, except to say, "A

final decision is pending on the fee increase."

The agency guarantees up to 95% of a loan that a bank makes to a farmer

or a rancher. As of Aug. 31 it had guaranteed more than 9,300 farm ownership

and operating loans valued at more than $2 billion this fiscal year.

Historically, the agency's loan losses have been covered through a

congressional appropriation, but a proposal in the Bush administration's

fiscal 2007 budget would fund the losses with higher user fees instead.

The increase was proposed to make the program self-funding and reduce its

costs to the government. The change is modeled after one made to the Small

Business Administration's funding in 2004.

The American Bankers Association estimates that the Farm Service Agency's

fees, currently 90 basis points on the amount borrowed, would rise to 150

basis points for farm ownership loans and 200 basis points for operating

loans.

Bankers have been lobbying against a fee increase since it was proposed

in February.

Both the House and the Senate Agriculture Department appropriations bills

include provisions that would prohibit any future fee increases without

congressional approval. However, the two bills have not been reconciled, and

it is unlikely they will be by the time the new fiscal year begins Oct. 1.

As the law stands now, the Agriculture Department has the authority to

raise or lower fees as it sees fit.

Congress is likely to approve an appropriations bill when it returns for

a lame-duck session in November, but under the current bills it would have

the authority only to prevent future fee increases.

Still, Nancy Baerwald, a vice president with the $39 million-asset

CountryBank USA in Cando, N.D., said she hopes that the Agriculture

Department abandons the idea to raise fees in the face of congressional

opposition.

All of North Dakota's counties have been declared disaster areas, because

some parts of the state have gotten too much rain, while others have not

received enough, she said.

"A lot of the help is coming across in low-interest loans or guaranteed

loans. Assessing a [higher] fee is just penalizing the very people who are

struggling to survive as it is," Ms. Baerwald said.

Gary Sipiorski, the president of the $111 million-asset Citizens State

Bank of Loyal, Wis., said his dairy farmer customers are getting 1975 prices

for their milk but are facing 2006 costs.

The Farm Service Agency's guarantees let banks like his make low-interest

loans to risky borrowers, and higher fees would make it harder for borrowers

to pay off their loans, he said.

http://www.americanbanker.com http://www.sourcemedia.com

                                  Farm Weekly

                             May 28, 2015 Thursday

Last chance looms for concessional loans

SECTION: EARLY GENERAL NEWS; Pg. 24

LENGTH: 194 words


WA Agriculture and Food Minister Ken Baston has urged farm businesses to act
soon on farm concessional loans.

The application period for Farm Finance and the Drought Concessional Loans,
funded by the Australian Government and administered in WA by the State's Rural
Business Development Corporation, close on June 30.

Mr Baston said Drought Concessional Loans could be used for debt restructuring,
operating expenses and drought recovery and preparedness activities, while Farm
Finance Concessional Loans could be used for debt restructuring and productivity
enhancements.

"These loans are designed to assist businesses that are experiencing tough
financial conditions," Mr Baston said.

"I remind farm business owners and operators who are interested in applying not
to self-assess their eligibility, but make the free phone call to assessors."

The schemes offer eligible farm businesses loans of up to $1 million at
concessional rates.

Eligible farming activities include broadacre, pastoral, horticulture, dairy,
intensive agriculture and aquaculture.

Loan applications for both schemes will close at 5pm on June 30, or when funds
are fully committed, whichever is sooner.

LOAD-DATE: May 27, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             259 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            August 3, 2016 Wednesday

Washington: Hoeven Working to Ensure EAS for Dickinson, Support Farmers and
Ranchers, Create Strong Business Climate, Advance Energy Industry

LENGTH: 1095  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office of the Senator John Hoeven has issued the following news
release:



 Senator John Hoeven today hosted a roundtable discussion with the Dickinson
Area Chamber of Commerce to brief community leaders on his efforts in Washington
and to gather input from chamber members on their priorities. He outlined his
work to ensure continued air service to Dickinson; help North Dakota farmers and
ranchers; create a strong business climate for small business; and advance the
energy industry in North Dakota.





 - WORKING TO ENSURE ESSENTIAL AIR SERVICE FOR DICKINSON AIRPORT



 Hoeven has requested expedited approval from the federal Department of
Transportation (DOT) and encouraged United Airlines to apply for Essential Air
Service (EAS) to ensure that Dickinson continues to have service to Denver. On
June 29, 2016 United Airlines filed notice of its intent to terminate commercial
air service at Dickinson effective September 27, 2016. The DOT requested
proposals from eligible airlines interested in providing EAS at Dickson and
issued an order prohibiting United from terminating service until the conclusion
of the Essential Air Service selection.



 The senator subsequently wrote to DOT Secretary Anthony Foxx asking him to
expedite awarding an EAS contract to ensure that there is not a disruption in
air service at Dickinson Airport. The senator followed up this week with a call
to United Airlines officials encouraging them to apply for EAS service at
Dickinson by the submission deadline, August 15.



 - WORKING TO HELP NORTH DAKOTA FARMERS AND RANCHERS



 Capital for Farmers and Ranchers Act



 Hoeven last month introduced the Capital for Farmers and Ranchers Act with
cosponsor Senator Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.). The legislation will:



 o Increase the maximum loan amount that an individual farmer or rancher is able
to receive under the Farm Service Agency's Direct and Guaranteed Loan Programs
for Farm Operating Loans and Farm Ownership Loans.

 o Help producers weather the downturn. For example, it increases the FSA loan
guarantee amount, which will now cover up to $2.5 million, up from $1.39
million. The bill will also double the amount on Direct Operating and Direct
Farm Ownership Loans from $300,000 to $600,000.



 - CREATING A GOOD BUSINESS CLIMATE FOR FARMERS, RANCHERS AND SMALL BUSINESS



 o Waters of the U.S. (WOTUS): The Fiscal Year (FY) 2016 funding bill prevented
the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) from reinstating the Waters of the
U.S. Interpretive Rule, which preserves the general ag exemption from the Clean
Water Act for farmers and ranchers. As an Appropriations Committee member,
Hoeven included language in the FY 2017 appropriations bill for the Dept. of
Interior and Environmental Protection Agency preventing the EPA from
implementing its WOTUS rule next year as well. Last week, the senator called on
the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to comply with the nationwide stay on
implementing the WOTUS rule by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit.

 o Worked to Secure More Than $680 Billion in Tax Relief in the FY 2016 funding
bill: Permanently extends Section 179 with the $500,000 limitation, a provision
of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) tax code that allows farmers, ranchers and
other small businesses to expense the purchase of equipment they need to run
their operations. In addition, the measure extends the bonus depreciation
allowance for five years.



 - WORKING TO ADVANCE THE ENERGY INDUSTRY IN NORTH DAKOTA



 o Lifted the Ban on Oil Exports - Hoeven, who serves on the Energy Committee,
cosponsored bipartisan legislation lifting the ban and worked to include it in
the year-end funding bill.

 o The Energy Policy Modernization Act of 2016 includes the following Hoeven
provisions. The measure has passed both chambers and is now in conference
committee.



 o Bureau of Land Management (BLM) Spacing Act - The legislation directs BLM to
establish a pilot program wherein a federal permit is not required when 25
percent or less of the minerals are owned or held in trust by the federal
government and there is no federal surface land.

 o All-of-the-Above Federal Building Energy Act - Improves the energy efficiency
of federal buildings by allowing the continued use of efficient fuels like
natural gas, which would otherwise be phased out.

 o Homeowners Furnace Flexibility Act - Allows newly installed gas furnaces to
be vented through a chimney, rather than a wall, as required in a new proposed
rule by the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE). The DOE's proposed rule would have
increased the cost of purchasing a new furnace by $350 and the cost of
installing a new furnace by $1,500 to $2,200. This legislation will save
homeowners that additional expense.

 o Non-Profit Energy Efficiency - Introduced by Hoeven and Senator Amy
Klobuchar, this bill creates a new pilot program at the DOE to provide matching
grants up to $200,000 to non-profit organizations to help make buildings they
own and operate more energy efficient.



 - WORKING TO ADDRESS THE OPIOID EPIDEMIC



 o This week, Hoeven unveiled legislation he authored to keep harmful and
addictive synthetic drugs from being sold in the United States. The Illegal
Synthetic Drug Safety Act of 2016, which Hoeven recently introduced with Senator
Chris Coons (D-Del.) closes a loophole in current law that enables companies to
circumvent the law and sell synthetic variations of drugs, like the powerful
drug fentanyl, by labeling the products as "not for human consumption."

 o Laboratories, many of which are found in China, are altering the molecular
structure of fentanyl and other controlled drugs to make substances that are
technically different, but with the same dangerous risks as the original drug.
These chemically altered substances are known as analogues.

 o For example, fentanyl is a synthetic opioid drug that is medically used as a
pain killer. The Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) estimates that it is 50
times more potent than heroin and 100 times more potent than morphine. While
fentanyl is a controlled substance, laboratories are altering its molecular
structure to make variations of the drug that are technically different, but
just as dangerous. Companies are then able to sell the variations, or analogues,
under a "not for human consumption" label.

 o The Illegal Synthetic Drug Safety Act of 2016 closes that loophole.

 o The measure has been endorsed by the Federal Law Enforcement Officers
Association.

                    FEDERAL FARM CREDIT BANKS FUNDING CORP.

                             101 Hudson St Ste 3505
                          JERSEY CITY,  NJ 07302-3944
                                 UNITED STATES

URL: http://www.farmcreditfunding.com

* * * * * * * * * * COMPANY IDENTIFIERS * * * * * * * * * *
DISCLO NUMBER: F178988375
WORLDSCOPE NUMBER: C840C08L0

* * * * * * * * * * COMPANY INFORMATION * * * * * * * * * *
OPERATING STATUS: ACTIVE
EMPLOYEES: 13,336

* * * * * * * * * * EXECUTIVES * * * * * * * * * *
OFFICERS:

     ·    J. Less Guthrie, Chairman
     ·    Robert B. Engel, Vice Chairman
     ·    Jamie B. Stewart, President & Chief Executive
     ·    Allison M. Finnegan, Senior Vice President, Secretary & General
          Counsel


* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

   Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation specializes in providing
financing and related services to eligible, creditworthy borrowers in the
agricultural and rural sectors, to certain related entities, and to domestic or
foreign parties in connection with international agricultural trade
transactions. The Company makes credit available in all 50 states, the
Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and the United States territories. The Farm Credit
System is a federally chartered network of interdependent, borrower-owned
lending institutions (Banks and Associations) and affiliated service
organizations. As of December 31, 2009, the System consisted of four Farm Credit
Banks (AgFirst FCB; AgriBank, FCB; FCB of Texas; and U.S. AgBank, FCB) and their
affiliated Associations, one Agricultural Credit Bank (CoBank, ACB) and its
affiliated Associations, the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation
(Funding Corporation) and various service and other organizations.
INDUSTRY TYPE: OTHER FINANCIAL

* * * * * * * * * * MARKET AND INDUSTRY * * * * * * * * * *
SIC CODES:
6141 - Personal credit institutions
6231 - Security and commodity exchanges
WORLDSCOPE INDUSTRY GROUP:
4390 - PERSONAL LOAN

* * * * * * * * * * FINANCIALS * * * * * * * * * *

                              KEY FINANCIALS (USD)

                         Heppner Gazette-Times (Oregon)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 March 26, 2014

Agriculture secretary announces more opportunity for producers in new Farm Bill

BYLINE: Heppner Gazette-Times staff

LENGTH: 250  words


WASHINGTON-- Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack Monday announced increased
opportunity for producers as a result of the 2014 Farm Bill.

The Farm Bill expands lending opportunities for many of farmers and ranchers to
begin and continue operations, including greater flexibility in determining
eligibility, raising loan limits, and emphasizing beginning and socially
disadvantaged producers.

Changes that will take effect immediately include:

Elimination of loan term limits for guaranteed operating loans;

Modification of the definition of beginning farmer, using the average farm size
for the county as a qualifier instead of the median farm size;

Modification of the Joint Financing Direct Farm Ownership Interest Rate to two
percent less than regular Direct Farm Ownership rate, with a floor of 2.5
percent Previously, the rate was established at five percent;

Increase of the maximum loan amount for Direct Farm Ownership down payments from
$225,000 to $300,000;

Elimination of rural residency requirement for Youth Loans, allowing urban youth
to benefit;

Debt forgiveness on Youth Loans, which will not prevent borrowers from obtaining
additional loans from the federal government;

Increase of the guarantee amount on Conservation Loans from 75 to 80 percent and
90 percent for socially disadvantaged borrowers and beginning farmers;

Microloans will not count toward loan term limits for veterans and beginning
farmers.

Visit the FSA Farm Bill website for detailed information and updates to farm
loan programs.

LOAD-DATE: November 19, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Agriculture

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: HGT

                               All Rights Reserved
                             SmallTownPapers, Inc.
                      Copyright 2014 Heppner Gazette-Times


                             262 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                         Deming Headlight (New Mexico)

                             April 14, 2014 Monday

New farm bill adds opportunity for NM farmers

BYLINE: For the Headlight

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 292 words


WASHINGTON >> Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack announced increased opportunity
for producers as a result of the 2014 Farm Bill. A fact sheet outlining
modifications to the U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) Farm Service Agency
(FSA) Farm Loan Programs is available at: www.fsa.usda.gov/FSA/ .

"Our nation's farmers and ranchers are the engine of the rural economy. These
improvements to our Farm Loan Programs will help a new generation begin farming
and grow existing farm operations," said Secretary Vilsack. "Today's
announcement represents just one part of a series of investments the new Farm
Bill makes in the next generation of agriculture, which is critical to economic
growth in communities across the country."

The Farm Bill expands lending opportunities for thousands of farmers and
ranchers to begin and continue operations, including greater flexibility in
determining eligibility, raising loan limits, and emphasizing beginning and
socially disadvantaged producers.

Changes that will take effect immediately include:

Elimination of loan term limits for guaranteed operating loans.

Modification of the definition of beginning farmer, using the average farm size
for the county as a qualifier instead of the median farm size.

Modification of the Joint Financing Direct Farm Ownership Interest Rate to 2
percent less than regular Direct Farm Ownership rate, with a floor of 2.5
percent. Previously, the rate was established at 5 percent.

Increase of the maximum loan amount for Direct Farm Ownership down payments from
$225,000 to $300,000.

Elimination of rural residency requirement for Youth Loans, allowing urban youth
to benefit.

Debt forgiveness on Youth Loans, which will not prevent borrowers from obtaining
additional loans.

LOAD-DATE: April 15, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Vilsack

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                             263 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                    Clinch Valley Times (St. Paul, Virginia)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 April 10, 2014

Increased opportunity for producers as part of the New Farm Bill for 2014

BYLINE: Clinch Valley Times staff

LENGTH: 357  words


WASHINGTON -- Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack announced increased opportunity
for producers as a result of the 2014 Farm Bill. A fact sheet outlining
modifications to the U.S. Department of

Agriculture's (USDA) Farm Service Agency (FSA) Farm Loan Programs is available
here.

"Our nation's farmers and ranchers are the engine of the rural economy. These
improvements to our Farm Loan Programs will help a new generation begin farming
and grow existing farm operations," said Secretary Vilsack. "This announcement
represents just one part of a series of investments the new Farm Bill makes in
the next generation of agriculture, which is critical to economic growth in
communities across the country."

The Farm Bill expands lending opportunities for thousands of farmers and
ranchers to begin and continue operations, including greater flexibility in
determining eligibility, raising loan limits, and emphasizing beginning and
socially disadvantaged producers.

Changes that will take effect immediately include:

-Elimination of loan term limits for guaranteed operating loans.

-Modification of the definition of beginning farmer, using the average farm size
for the county as a qualifier instead of the median farm size.

-Modification of the Joint Financing Direct Farm Ownership Interest Rate to 2
percent less than regular Direct Farm Ownership rate, with a floor of 2.5
percent. Previously, the rate was established at 5 percent.

-Increase of the maximum loan amount for Direct Farm Ownership down payments
from $225,000 to $300,000.

-Elimination of rural residency requirement for Youth Loans, allowing urban
youth to benefit.

-Debt forgiveness on Youth Loans, which will not prevent borrowers from
obtaining additional loans from the federal government.

-Increase of the guarantee amount on Conservation Loans from 75 to 80 percent
and 90 percent for socially disadvantaged borrowers and beginning farmers.

-Microloans will not count toward loan term limits for veterans and beginning
farmers.

Additional modifications must be implemented through the rulemaking processes.
Visit the FSA Farm Bill website for information and updates to farm loan
programs.

LOAD-DATE: November 25, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Local Government

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: CVT

              The Lake Metigoshe Mirror (Bottineau, North Dakota)

                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                 April 9, 2014

Farm Bill increases opportunities for farmers

BYLINE: The Lake Metigoshe Mirror staff

LENGTH: 356  words


Agriculture Secretary Tom Vil-sack announced increased opportunity for producers
as a result of the 2014 Farm Bill. A fact sheet outlining modifications to the
U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) Farm Service Agency (FSA) Farm Loan
Programs is available here.

"Our nation's farmers and ranchers are the engine of the rural economy," said
Secretary Vilsack. "These improvements to our Farm Loan Programs will help a new
generation begin farming and grow existing farm operations. This announcement
represents just one part of a series of investments the new Farm Bill makes in
the next generation of agriculture, which is critical to economic growth in
communities across the country."

The Farm Bill expands lending opportunities for thousands of farmers and
ranchers to begin and continue operations, including greater flexibility in
determining eligibility, raising loan limits, and emphasizing beginning and
socially disadvantaged producers.

Changes that will take effect immediately include:

Elimination of loan term limits for guaranteed operating loans.

Modification of the definition of beginning farmer, using the average farm size
for the county as a qualifier instead of the median farm size.

Modification of the Joint Financing Direct Farm Ownership Interest Rate to two
percent less than regular Direct Farm Ownership rate, with a floor of 2.5
percent. Previously, the rate was established at five percent.

Increase of the maximum loan amount for Direct Farm Ownership down payments from
$225,000 to $300,000.

Elimination of rural residency requirement for Youth Loans, allowing urban youth
to benefit.

Debt forgiveness on Youth Loans, which will not prevent borrowers from obtaining
additional loans from the federal government.

Increase of the guarantee amount on Conservation Loans from 75 to 80 percent and
90 percent for socially disadvantaged borrowers and beginning farmers.

Microloans will not count toward loan term limits for veterans and beginning
farmers.

Additional modifications must be implemented through the rulemaking processes.
Visit the FSA Farm Bill website for detailed information and updates to farm
loan programs.

LOAD-DATE: November 26, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Agriculture

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: LMT

                             266 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The American Banker

Illinois, Indiana Offer Loan Programs for Drought-Hit Farmers

                             July 15, 1988, Friday

By ANDREA BENNETT, Midwest Bureau

DATELINE: CHICAGO


Two Midwest states have allotted funds for low-interest rate loans to help
farmers hurt by the drought.

Illinois Treasurer Jerry Cosentino said this week he is making $50 million in
state funds available for the low-interest-rate loans.

Under the special program, the state will deposit money in banks in rural areas
at 6.5%, one percentage point below the prevailing rate on state deposits. In
return, the banks must agree to loan the money to cash strapped farmers at no
more than three percentage points above the rate paid on the deposit, or 9.5%.
That rate is below the market rate on farm operating loans in the area, which
was 11% at the end of the first quarter.

Separately, Indiana Treasurer Marjorie O'Laughlin made an additional $10 million
in state funds available for an existing farm loan program. Several loan
requirements were also waived to make the program more accessible to farmers
affected by the drought.

The $10 million addition brings to $72 million the total being deposited in
Indiana banks and production credit associations this year for low-interest-rate
farm loans, said Andrew Stoner, communications director for the treasurer's
office. Eight production credit associations and 117 Indiana banks used the
program last year, and a similar number are expected to take advantage of it in
1988, he said.

Illinois has had a low-interest-rate farm loan program since 1980, said James
Stapleton, chief fiscal officer in the treasurer's office. However, loans made
under the existing program could only be used for farm operating expenses, he
said.

In contrast, the additional $50 million can be loaned to farmers for any
drought-related expense, or to refinance or roll over current loans, he said.

Additional funds also may be made available later in the summer if needed, said
Mr. Stapleton.

"The $50 million is one step in the right direction," said Morris Peine,
chairman of the First Farmers State Bank of Minier in central Illinois. "I don't
think it is enough money . . . but I really appreciate anyone who is going to
help us at all."

Mr. Peine was a member of a special Illinois Bankers Association drought task
force that asked for modifications in the deposit program. Other recommendations
for dealing with the drought at the state and federal level include development
of guarantee programs for debt carried over from 1988.

The banking trade group also expects to meet with state and federal bank
regulators to clarify how drought-related loan problems will be handled, a
spokeswoman said.

SECTION: Pg. 13

LENGTH: 425 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1988 American Banker, Inc.

                             269 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


               National Post (f/k/a The Financial Post) (Canada)

                            August 12, 2014 Tuesday
                                National Edition

Overgrown farm credit giant

BYLINE: Morris W Dorosh, Financial Post

SECTION: FP COMMENT; Pg. FP9

LENGTH: 790 words


The recipients of a subsidy seldom complain about it, and so Farm Credit Canada,
the government farm lender, remains, as it has for years, well liked and
patronized by farmers and uncriticized in political circles. FCC has about a
third of the farm lending market, which happens to be the most desirable third.
Its entire operation is subsidized by the government by means of virtually free
capital. Hardly anyone is aware of the size of this subsidy, or its impact on
private-sector, taxpaying financial institutions in the agricultural segment.

The FCC issued its 2013-14 annual report last month, a 52-pager in which
self-congratulation and self-promotion approached anything ever put out by the
old Canadian Wheat Board. Simultaneously it issued a press release chronicling
its achievements, such as the $1-million it contributed to rural community
causes, its Drive Away Hunger campaign for country food banks, the 126 learning
events it sponsored for farmers and, believe it or not, its "financial
strength."

The FCC has only a nominal cost of loanable funds and no requirement to maintain
asset-lending ratios. It "borrows" $22.8-billion from the federal treasury, for
which it incurred an interest expense of $259-million last year, or about 1.1%.
It uses the money to make loans which at March 31 stood at $25.8-billion. It
realized "net income" of $642-million during the year, paying a "dividend" to
its "shareholder" (the federal government) of $50-million. The average cost of
federal government borrowings is currently just under 5% for long and short-term
debt. The $22.8-billion of federal government assets tied up in the FCC
therefore costs Canadian taxpayers almost $1-billion a year to finance, and
approximately equals the annual federal budget deficit of recent times.

Private institutions, including credit unions, face very unfair competition from
this crown entity. They must raise funds from depositors and other sources at
market rates. The interest expense of the eight largest banks is about 34% of
interest income; the FCC's is 22%. Financial institutions must observe stringent
guidelines, to be further tightened starting in 2015, to assure their stability
under any economic circumstances. Banks, like all shareholderowned entities,
must produce competitive earnings, growth and dividends.

The FCC's share of the Canadian farm credit market was 29% in 2013-14, compared
to chartered banks' at 36% and credit unions' 16%. At the end of its last fiscal
year it had 160,000 loans to 100,000 clients, about three times the number of
professional, viable-scale farms in Canada. (Fewer than 20% of farms account for
over 80% of agricultural production). The average interest rate it charged
borrowers during the year was 4.64% on fixed-rate loans and 3.98% on
variable-rate loans. The prime rate is 3.0%. Commercial loans of any kind at as
little as 1% to 1.5% above prime are rare and require lead-pipe security and a
realistic default risk of zero. The FCC can do it only because it freely
accesses public funds.

The FCC skims off the top layer of borrowers, leaving the private sector with
the more risky, less straightforward end. To get their business it low-balls
interest rates and is the first to make concessions to borrowers if obstacles to
timely repayment appear. Its bad-loan write-offs last year were just $42-million
or 0.2% of loans receivable. For the same reason its operating costs relative to
assets and loan activity are low, just $366-million last year. Management
challenges and talent needs are modest because operating from the FCC's
subsidized, competition-proof position borders on a no-brainer.

In 1992 the FCC's legislation was extensively amended to allow it to lend to
nonfarmer clients, engage in leasing and also in venture capital financing. The
annual report conveniently omits all information that could be used to assess
its experience as an agribusiness lender, except that impaired loans to
agribusiness and agri-food borrowers were $47.5-million as of last March
compared to $18.8-million to grain and oilseed farmers.

Government involvement in agricultural credit exists in other countries.
Normally it is limited to borrowers who do not qualify for or cannot afford
commercial credit. In Canada this is reversed: The government entity serves the
most credit-worthy.

Anything that improves the profitability and viability of primary producers
helps the whole agricultural economy, even if it is a billion-dollar public
subsidy, and more power to FCC customers. However, the size and nature of the
FCC's burden on the national treasury, and on tax-paying privatesector financial
institutions, should be acknowledged.

Morris W Dorosh is editor and publisher of Winnipeg-based AGRIWEEK.

                              The American Banker

Farm Belt Resurgence Heartens Local Bankers

                            June 16, 1988, Thursday

By ANDREA BENNETT, Midwest Bureau

DATELINE: WALNUT, Ill.


Despite a shortage of rain darkening the outlook for this year's harvest,
bankers report that better times have come to the Farm Belt, which is rebounding
from its worst financial crunch in 50 years.

After six years of losses, Citizens First State Bank posted a $200,000 profit in
1987, for a return on assets of 0.76%. Executives at the Walnut, Ill.-based bank
expect this year to be even better.

The bank's once suspect loan portfolio is in tip-top shape. "Right now," said
James Watson, the bank's president, "we can't identify a loan problem to speak
of." Citizens First, 8% of whose loans were nonperforming in 1985, now has no
nonperforming loans and only two or three that are past due, "none by more than
a few weeks."

Agricultural lenders, after six years of desperation, now are feeling more
upbeat.

Their principal borrowers, the farmers, returned to the fields this spring after
receiving $23 billion in government subsidies in 1987. Those subsidies helped
push net farm income to $45 billion, a level the U.S. Department of Agriculture
projects may be matched this year.

Farmers are also enjoying lower levels of debt, lower interest rates than in
previous years, reduced expenses, and increasing land values. Also helping
farmers is the falling dollar, the primary reason for an expected 16% surge in
agricultural exports for the fiscal year ending Oct. 1.

Robert A. Meyer, executive vice president of $13 million-asset Glasford State
Bank, Glasford, Ill., shares the optimism of farm bankers. "You just get the
feeling it's going to be fun again. We're going to make some money," he says.

Because of the drought, the fun may not come this year. But experts say barring
a total crop failure, the drought conditions should not cause too much trouble.
"I don't think it is necessarily fair to say that one year of dry weather will
tip us back to the farm financial crunch," said Mark Drabenstott, an economist
at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City.

IN addition, experts caution that the recovery will be slow, and that not all
farmers will share in it. Moreover, the strength of the recovery rests firmly on
government support programs, which Duff & Phelps Inc., a Chicago based rating
agency, estimates will dip to about $20 billion in 1988 from $23.1 billion in
1987.

Despite the cautions, there is no doubt farm bankers have benefited from the
recovery. In 1987, according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., 55
agricultural banks failed, four fewer than in 1986. But the proportion of farm
bank failures to total failures has dropped considerably.

In 1985, 52% of the 120 banks that failed were farm banks; by 1987, the
percentage had dropped to 30%. Through April 18, 11 of the 53 failures, or 21%,
were agricultural banks.

The number of Midwest farm banks reporting losses is on the decline. Federal
Reserve Bank of Chicago data show that 265 farm banks reported a loss in 1987,
compared with 504 in 1986.

Midwest farm banks as a whole posted a return on assets of 0.66% in 1987,
substantially better than 0.26% in 1986.

The Fed study of 1,735 farm banks in the Federal Reserve districts of Chicago,
St. Louis, Minneapolis, and Kansas City - which make up much of the agricultural
heartland - pinpointed improved asset quality as the major reason for improved
earnings.

Net chargeoffs fell nearly 50% to 1.58% of total loans in 1987, from 3.03% in
1986. At yearend 1987, the ratio of nonperforming assets to total loans stood at
3.6%, down from 5.1% at the end of 1986.

CAPITAL levels, despite the earlier years of mounting loan losses, remain
strong. Agricultural banks in the Midwest ended 1987 with a capital-to assets
ratio of 10.3%, well above the 8.1% recorded by their nonagricultural
counterparts in the area, according to the Fed study.

The agricultural recovery is spread among the small rural banks and the larger
banks in midwestern cities. In Iowa, two of the largest Des Moines based bank
holding companies reported record quarterly profits in the first three months of
the year.

The $912 million-asset Brenton Banks Inc. said net income surged 59% in the
first quarter to a record $1.9 million. The $2.4 billion-asset Banks of Iowa
Inc. had record earnings of $4.6 million in the first three months of 1988, up
24% from the same period in 1987.

An improved outlook is in store for Glasford State Bank, a $13 million asset
institution in a small Illinois farm town of about 1,200 people. "The area is
going to have a good year, and the bank ought to enjoy a stable to good year,"
said Mr. Meyer, an executive vice president.

At the height of the agricultural recession, many Glasford residents, who worked
at Caterpillar Inc. in the nearby cities of Peoria and Canton, Ill., were laid
off. Many have returned to work, and residents who received about $7,000 from
unemployment benefits now have salaries of $25,000 to $30,000, said Mr. Meyer.

With higher incomes, the residents are buying more, including big ticket items
such as cars. And houses that were on the market for two and three years now
attract buyers. "There seems to be more confidence in what's going on," Mr.
Meyer said.

Farmers also show interest in buying farmland, which Mr. Meyer describes as the
"best in the world" for the local crops of corn, wheat, and soybeans. During the
crisis, however, the price of even the best farmland fell. "All of a sudden,
they're jumping in. The land seems to be stabilizing," he said.

The value of farmland is a critical measure of a farmer's worth, because land
represents an estimated 75% of farm assets. Land value also is a critical
measure for bankers because land is often used as collateral.

A survey by Norwest Corp., Minneapolis, shows that farmland prices began to
increase in 1987 after a five-year decline, rising about 10% across the Midwest.

Mr. Meyer attributes the recent agricultural revival in the Glasford area to
abundant government subsidies, which an estimated 95% of area farmers receive.
Three years ago, the figure was closer to 20%.

The subsidies have improved the financial condition of farmers seeking spring
planting loans, Mr. Meyer said. Other Illinois bankers also say they are
rejecting far fewer loan customers than in previous years, although Mr. Meyer
said the level of loan rejections at Glasford State Bank is fairly stable.

Unfortunately for banks, their earnings have not rebounded as quickly as the
farm economy. "The economic pickup has just started. The guy who was not coming
in last year is making purchases and borrowing money this year. We're going to
be lagging," Mr. Meyer said. The drought won't help, with bankers worrying that
it will turn farmers cautious about making purchases again.

Slow loan growth, which squeezes net interest margins, is the primary reason for
the lag in earnings. Net interest margins at Midwest farm banks shrank to 3.11%
in 1987 from 3.46% in 1985, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

"We have the same problem facing every bank in the country - the margin
problem," said Mr. Watson of Citizens First in Walnut. "Our margins were
actually better back in 1983 and 1984. Our problems then were related to loan
losses and high overhead related to loan collections. If we had the margins now
we had then, we could have earned another 10% to 12% in 1987."

AMID the signs of recovery, Mr. Watson isn't entirely happy. His bank's
agricultural loan portfolio as of the end of February shrank to about 16% of the
bank's total loans from 50% of total loans in the early 1980s, Mr. Watson said.

The decline was not because the bank was backing away from making farm loans,
but because many farmers, with the memory of hardship from unbearable debt loads
still fresh, are reluctant to increase their borrowing. "The demand (for farm
loans) is not there," Mr. Watson said.

Mr. Watson, like Mr. Meyer in Glasford, has witnessed a dramatic decline in
total loans in the 1980s. Citizens First's loan-to-deposit ratio is 37%. Mr.
Watson is aiming for 45% this year "if we're wildly successful." The bank has
about $10.6 million in loans.

"I'm not optimistic," Mr. Watson said about the chances for a pickup in loan
volume. "That same customer base will never supply us with the loans they did in
the 1970s and early 1980s. Toss it all into a pot, and people aren't as
aggressive as they used to be."

Mr. Watson attributes the decline in loan demand to generous government
payments. Although farmers' income is improving and they are willing to make
some purchases, that willingness "is more than offset by the government stream
to farmers from farm programs," Mr. Watson said.  Government payments "cut their
needs for borrowing for operating purposes." According to the Federal Reserve
Bank of Chicago, non-real-estate farm debt declined by 22% to $30.6 billion at
the nation's commercial banks over a two-year period ended last Sept. 30.

Bankers have labored to make up the difference in a variety of ways. Mr. Watson
said Citizens First is trying to wring more yield out of its investment
portfolio and to find new places to put excess money, a search that is meeting
with "only moderate success."

CITIZENS First also is more aggressive about seeking new lending opportunities.
One source of new business is the secondary market for real estate loans.
Traditionally, banks have made short-term operating loans, while the Farm Credit
System made the bulk of the longer-term farmland loans.

Even without a secondary market, banks have increased farmland loans 28% to
$14.1 billion over the past two years, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of
Chicago. During that same period, the land loan portfolio of the financially
troubled Farm Credit System has declined 24% to $35.1 billion.

Many banks see opportunity in the secondary farmland market. The $20.4 billion
Norwest Corp., Minneapolis, for example, recently hired Jay I. Mann, a former
president of a Federal Land Bank in Sheldon, Iowa, as vice president and manager
of agricultural real estate lending. The appointment "affirms our intention to
be a major player in the 'Farmer Mac' program as it evolves over the next
several months," said C.P. Moore, chairman of Norwest Agricultural Credit.

Smaller farm banks also are trying to position themselves. Citizens First hired
a loan officer who travels almost full time seeking new farmland loan business.
But the expectation of finding 20 to 30 farmers each week wanting such loans
hasn't been met.

"We've made more than a handful (of farmland loans) but not enough to replace
the lost operating loans," he said.

Mr. Watson said the bank is doing a number of other things to survive. It
reduced its assets by about 12% over the past five years. It is trying to
diversify the loan portfolio. And the bank has stretched its market area to 60
miles to scout new business.

"We recognized what had happened to our community and service area and we
reacted to it," Mr. Watson said. "We didn't anticipate it."

SECTION: AN AMERICAN BANKER SPECIAL REPORT; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1834 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1988 American Banker, Inc.


                             272 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                        Manawatu Standard (New Zealand)

                             March 5, 2013 Tuesday

Low-cost loans to enable compliance

BYLINE: Jill Galloway

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 319 words


ASB is launching New Zealand's first Rural Environmental Compliance Loan, so
farmers can meet regulatory requirements.

The bank's rural general manager, Mark Heer, said the loan limit would be a
maximum of $200,000 over five years.

"For example, it might be effluent on- farm systems, which are required by
regulation," Heer said. "But it could be the right thing to do - for instance
fencing of waterways - something that could be an industry requirement."

He said the "low-cost loan" would have no additional customer margin applied to
ASB's cost of funding.

"It is all about getting the balance right between productivity and
environmental sustainability."

Heer said it was exciting as the farming sector was the driving force of the New
Zealand economy and it was important that New Zealand's farmers got the balance
right between productivity and environmental sustainability.

He said it was developed in response to feedback from rural customers.

"Farmers consistently tell us that they are doing their best to ensure that
their farms are operating to the highest environmental standards.

"However, the reality is that there can be considerable costs associated with
upgrading systems, including the fencing of waterways, which are all part of
operating an environmentally responsible farm."

Heer said that, at the same time, local- body regulations had been tightening
around the management of effluent, nitrate leaching and water usage on farms.

Heer said the balance between productivity and the environment was one that must
be met, as the urban communities were very loud with their concerns about water
quality.

"The ASB wants to be part of the solution and so it is offering this funding
package."

Heer said farmers must ensure they were compliant with regulations, or risk
fines. "Farmers are facing all these pressures while at the same time trying to
focus on the productivity and profitability of their business."

LOAD-DATE: March 5, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper
