                        The Superior Express (Nebraska)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                                August 16, 2012

Emergency loans available from FSA for drought loss

BYLINE: The Superior Express staff

LENGTH: 255  words


Farmers in Jewell County, who suffered crop or livestock losses because of the
current drought may now apply for Farm Service Agency (FSA) emergency loans.

Smith, Mitchell, and Republic counties also became eligible under the same
designation. Applications for assistance will be accepted by FSA until April 8,
2013.

Loans covering physical production losses are scheduled for repayment as rapidly
as feasible, consistent with the applicant's reasonable ability to pay. The
current interest rate is 2.25 percent but is subject to monthly changes until
the loan is approved.

FSA loans covering physical losses may be used to replace installations,
equipment, livestock or buildings (including homes), lost through this disaster.

FSA loans covering production losses may be used to buy feed, seed, fertilizer,
livestock or to make payments on real estate and chattel debts. Funds can also
be used for other essential operating and living expenses.

To be eligible for an emergency disaster loan, an applicant must be operating a
family size farm or ranch, must be unable to get credit elsewhere and must have
suffered a qualifying physical or production loss from the disaster.

Farmers, who suffered at least a 30 percent reduction to at least one cropping
enterprise, may have a qualifying production loss. Emergency disaster production
loss loans cover 100 percent of qualifying losses.

Farmers and ranchers that think they may be eligible should contact the FSA
County Office in Smith Center or call 785-282-6618 for additional information.

CURRENT SHARES OUTSTANDING: EUR 93,125

LOAD-DATE: March 6, 2017


                             390 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

            ELDON H. DAHL AND JEANETTE M. DAHL v. THE UNITED STATES

                                   No. 599-77

                         United States Court of Claims

                          1982 U.S. Cl. Ct. LEXIS 2539


                                January 25, 1982

CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff borrowers filed an action against defendant United
States (government) seeking damages for breach of contract and abuse of
administrative discretion due to the government's refusal to advance funds from
a farm operating loan and unilaterally terminating it by withdrawing the funds
from a supervised back account, pursuant to 7 C.F.R. § 1803.10(d) (1977).

OVERVIEW: The borrowers were approved for a government loan. A bank provided the
borrowers with an interim loan pending the release of the funds. The government
refused to release the funds until the bank loan was satisfied. The borrowers
put a second mortgage on their house, thereby, satisfying the bank. The
government disapproved of the subsequent debt and terminated the loan. The
borrowers filed a cause of action against the government, and the court found
for the borrowers. The court found that the loan constituted a contract between
the borrowers and the government. The court held that the government breached
the contract when it terminated the loan, and that the breach constituted an
abuse of administrative discretion. The court also held that because there was
no bad faith, intent to deceive, or misuse of the bank or government funds by
the borrowers, the government was in breach for repudiating its contract
obligations. The court further held that no where in the governing statutes,
regulations, or other contractual documents was there a prohibition against the
borrowers incurring subsequent debt. The court awarded the borrowers foreseeable
losses resulting from the breach.

OUTCOME: The court found in favor of the borrowers in their breach of contract
and abuse of administrative discretion action, and awarded them foreseeable
damages from the government.

CORE TERMS: farm, personal property, borrower, cow, interim, sba, mortgage, golf
course, farming, real estate, loan funds, milk, down payment, supervised,
settlement, bank account, county supervisor, state director, farmer, real
estate, machinery, unilaterally, dairy, loan proceeds, negotiations, crop,
terminated, default, misuse, net income


                            LexisNexis(R) Headnotes


Governments > Agriculture & Food > General Overview
Public Contracts Law > Business Aids & Assistance > General Overview
[HN1] The Farmers Home Administration is responsible for several loan and grant
programs.  7 C.F.R. § 1800.1 (1977). Among them are farm operating loans, 7
U.S.C.S. §§ 1941-47. Operating loan funds may be used for such things as the
purchase of livestock, farm equipment, and feed.  7 C.F.R. § 1831.9 (1977).

Banking Law > Bank Activities > Bank Accounts > General Overview
Public Contracts Law > Business Aids & Assistance > General Overview
[HN2] Supervised bank accounts may be closed by unilateral action of the state
director for the following reasons: death of borrowers, borrower in default,
inactive borrower, or when the borrower is paid up.  7 C.F.R. §
1803.10(d)(1)-(4) (1977).

Contracts Law > Defenses > Ambiguity & Mistake > General Overview
Governments > Federal Government > Claims By & Against
Governments > Federal Government > Employees & Officials
[HN3] The mistaken beliefs of the various federal employees cannot serve to
protect the government from liability.

Contracts Law > Breach > General Overview
Contracts Law > Defenses > Ambiguity & Mistake > General Overview
[HN4] One may not repudiate his contract obligations upon the ground that he
reasonably, though mistakenly, believed that the other party to the contract had
breached it.

Governments > Federal Government > Employees & Officials
[HN5] Procurement officials have to exercise judgment in terminating an
agreement for default.

Governments > Federal Government > Employees & Officials
Public Contracts Law > Business Aids & Assistance > General Overview
[HN6] The government may not use its discretionary power of unilateral
termination under 7 C.F.R. § 1803.10(d) as a useful pretext for the taking of
action felt to be necessary on other grounds unrelated to the borrower's
performance without making a judgment as to the merits of the case. Such
abdication of responsibility is not sanctioned when there is administrative
discretion under a contract.

Public Contracts Law > Business Aids & Assistance > General Overview
[HN7]  7 C.F.R. § 1802.2 (1977) provides: (a) All loans made by the Farmers Home
Administration are designed to assist individual borrower families to attain
specific objectives. Therefore, each borrower family will be provided the
supervision necessary to achieve those objectives and to protect the financial
interest of the government.

Public Contracts Law > Business Aids & Assistance > General Overview
Public Contracts Law > Contract Interpretation > Ambiguities & Contra
Proferentem > General Overview
[HN8] No where in the Farmers Home Administration's governing statutes,
regulations or the other contractual documents is there a prohibition against
the plaintiffs incurring subsequent debt.

Contracts Law > Remedies > Foreseeable Damages > Lost Profits
[HN9] The loss of anticipated profits is a recognized measure of damages, where
the loss is the proximate result of the breach and the fact that there would
have been a profit is established, and there is some basis on which a reasonable
estimate of the amount of the profit can be made.

Contracts Law > Remedies > Foreseeable Damages > General Overview
[HN10] The court will not allow a party to be wronged without at least
attempting to put him in as good a position pecuniarily as he would have been in
if the contract had been completed. Merely because the plaintiffs fail to
establish exact damages with mathematical precision will not defeat their right
to recover. If there is enough evidence adduced to enable the court to make a
fair and reasonable approximation of damages, that will suffice.

Contracts Law > Remedies > Foreseeable Damages > General Overview
[HN11] A plaintiff can get a judgment for damages measured by his resulting
injury so far as the defendant has reason to foresee such injury when the
contract was made.

Contracts Law > Remedies > General Overview
[HN12] The ascertainment of damages is not an exact science, and where
responsibility for damage is clear, it is not essential that the amount thereof
be ascertainable with absolute exactness or mathematical precision. It is enough
if the evidence adduced is sufficient to enable a court or jury to make a fair
and reasonable approximation.

Public Contracts Law > Business Aids & Assistance > General Overview
[HN13]  7 C.F.R. § 1831.32(b) (1977) provides: (ii) If it is found, after an
applicant has been certified as eligible, that there will be a major change in
operations or that an amount of credit in excess of the maximum previously
established by the County Committee will be required for the designated corp or
operating year, it will be necessary for the County Committee again to certify
the applicant as eligible on the basis of the changed circumstances if a loan is
to be made.

COUNSEL:  [*1]  Charles A. Bird, attorney of record for plaintiffs.

Frank M. Rapoport, with whom was Acting Assistant Attorney General Thomas S.
Martin for defendant.

OPINION BY: YOCK

OPINION

OPINION *

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - Footnotes - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

* The recommended decision and findings of fact are submitted in accordance with
Rule 134(h).
- - - - - - - - - - - - End Footnotes- - - - - - - - - - - - - -

YOCK, Trial Judge: The plaintiffs, Eldon H. and Jeanette M. Dahl, are husband
and wife.  They reside in southeastern Minnesota near Rushford, which is located
in Fillmore County.  The defendant is the United States of America acting
through the Farmers Home Administration (FmHA), an agency within the Department
of Agriculture.  Jurisdiction is founded on 28 U.S.C.  § 1491 (Supp. III 1979).

The plaintiffs claim damages for the defendant's breach of a contract to loan
money.They claim that the defendant made a farm operating loan to them under the
authority of 7 U.S.C.  §§ 1941-47 (Supp. IV 1950).  Later, however, the
defendant refused to advance the funds and unilaterally terminated the loan by
withdrawing funds from a supervised bank account, thereby breaching the contract
to loan money.  Further, the plaintiffs claim that this unilateral termination
was an abuse of administrative discretion.  [*2]  In addition, they ask for the
return of interest paid on the loan proceeds.

For the reasons set forth herein, it is concluded that the plaintiffs are
entitled to recover.

Facts

The FmHA makes low-interest loans to farmers who are unable to obtain credit
elsewhere from commercial sources.  The loans are designed to assist in the
continuation of the farmily farm or the creation of family farm units in the
United States.   [HN1] The FmHA is responsible for several loan and grant
programs.  7 C.F.R.  § 1800.1 (1977).  Among them are farm operating loans, 7
U.S.C.  §§ 1941-47 (Supp. IV 1980), and farm real estate purchase loans, 7
U.S.C.  §§ 1922-34 (Supp. IV 1980).  Operating loan funds may be used for such
things as the purchase of livestock, farm equipment and feed.  7 C.F.R.  §
1831.9 (1977).

Although the programs are national in scope, FmHA loans are made through local
county offices which are run by a county supervisor. The county supervisor in
turn reports to a district director.  The program in each state is run by a
state director.

The FmHA county office keeps a file on the transactions of each borrower. Part
of this file is the running record in which all borrower [*3]  contacts or
borrower-related contacts are to be noted.  The running record in the Dahl file
is incomplete as to many of the contacts; entries were made after the fact;
entries are undated or misdated; and parts of the pages in the running record
were torn off, or otherwise mutilated or unreadable.  Thus, the running record
in this case does not provide the complete picture of what occurred in this
transaction.

During the winter of 1975-76, the plaintiff, Mr. Eldon Dahl, first came into
contact with Mr. Lynn Peterson, the FmHA County Supervisor serving Houston and
Fillmore Counties in southeastern Minnesota.  On one occasion, Mr. Peterson
spoke before a farm management vocational class attended by Mr. Dahl at the
Winona Area Technical Institute in Winona, Minnesota.  At that time, Mr.
Peterson explained to the class the various farm loan assistance programs
offered by the FmHA and available to local farmers. Specifically, he pointed out
that to receive a farm operating loan, a farmer makes a written application to
the county office and submits a Farm and Home Plan (farm plan).  The farm plan
consists of a balance sheet presentation of assets and liabilities, cash flow
analysis and [*4]  the proposed use of the loan funds.

On May 17, 1976, Mr. Dahl went to see Mr. Peterson at the FmHA office in
Preston, Minnesota, to discuss securing an operating loan to purchase livestock
and machinery in connection with a possible purchase of a 160-acre farm owned by
Mr. Merle Hatleli and his wife.  The plaintiffs intended to sell their house
located adjacent to a golf course near Rushford, Minnesota, (golf course house)
to raise the proceeds for a down payment on the Hatleli farm. Mr. Dahl, with the
assistance of Mr. Peterson, filled out a farm plan and completed a FmHA
application for an operating loan.  Sale negotiations subsequently fell through
and no sale of the Hatleli farm was completed at that time.

However, in late August or early September of 1976, the Hatlelis again contacted
the plaintiffs and indicated their renewed desire to sell their farm. One
necessary term was that there be one sale of both the real estate and the
personal property located on the farm such as the cows, machinery and feed.

Mr. Dahl again contacted Mr. Peterson in September of 1976 and arranged to meet
him at the Hatleli farm. On September 21, 1976, Mr. Peterson and Mr. Dahl
together [*5]  visited the Hatleli farm for the purpose of assessing the value
of the farm and the personal property. The Hatlelis were asking $ 160,000 for
the farm real estate and $ 48,500 for the personal property located on the farm.
After the visit, Mr. Peterson and Mr. Dahl discussed the terms in Peterson's
car.  Mr. Peterson thought that the Hatlelis were getting maximum value for
their farm, but because the barn and house were in excellent shape, the farm
all-in-all would make a good purchase.  Mr. Peterson recommended that if the
Dahls wanted to go into farming and wanted the farm, they should buy it.  Also
he indicated there would be no problem getting approval of a FmHA operating
loan, because of the Dahls' background in family farming and Mr. Dahl's
vocational training in farm management.  Both parties agreed that the Hatlelis'
Brown Swiss cows should be sold in the coming spring and new Holstein cows
purchased in their place.  They also agreed that some other equipment, including
a tractor, should be sold and replaced.  Both parties then left the Hatleli farm
. On September 24, 1976, Mr. Dahl returned to Mr. Peterson's office in Preston
to fill out a new farm plan and reactivate the [*6]  original application for an
operating loan.

On September 27, 1976, the plaintiffs signed an earnest money contract on the
Hatleli farm and personal property. The terms were $ 48,500 for the personal
property and $ 160,000 for the real estate. Of the $ 16,000 cash down payment, $
1,000 was applied to the real estate and $ 15,000 was applied to the personal
property. Payment of the balance due on the personal property and closing of the
personal property were set for November 1, 1976.  Possession of the farm was
also set for November 1, 1976.  The sale of the real estate was on a 20-year
installment contract for deed.  An additional $ 39,000 was due on the real
estate down payment on January 1, 1977, the date set for the real estate
closing.

On October 4, 1976, Mr. Dahl submitted the completed farm plan to Mr. Peterson,
who reviewed the plan and application as required by 7 C.F.R.  § 1801.3(b)
(1977).  The time period for the farm plan was February 1, 1977 to February 1,
1978.  One essential element of the October 4 farm plan was the intention to
sell the Hatlelis' Brown Swiss cows and replace them the following spring with
the better milk-producing Holstein cows. The balance [*7]  of the operating loan
funds was to be used to purchase a bulk tank for milk storage and a half
interest in a tractor.  The second essential element was that the Dahls intended
to sell their golf course house to realize the equity of approximately $ 27,000.
This equity was to be used towards the down payment on the real property portion
of the Hatleli contract.  Since the Dahls would be living in the Hatleli farm
house, there would be no need to keep their golf course house.

Both Eldon and Jeanette Dahl were born and raised on family farms located in and
around Fillmore County, Minnesota.  They both grew up with other siblings in the
family and assisted their parents in operating the family farm. In addition,
they had previously lived on a family farm as a married couple.

After reviewing the Dahls' farm plan and application and determining that the
Dahls were or could be the type of farm family that the loan program was
designed to assist (farm background, education, etc.), Mr. Peterson sent the
file to the County Committee.  The County Committee is composed of three
individuals residing in the county, at least two of whom make their living
principally by farming. They determine [*8]  if an applicant is eligible for a
loan.  The determination of eligibility encompasses a review of the borrower's
financial status to determine, among other things, that the borrower is unable
to secure a loan elsewhere from normal commercial sources and that the borrower
has a reasonable prospect of success in the proposed operation.  7 C.F.R.  §§
1801.3(a)(2), 1831.5 (1977).  If a borrower is eligible, the County Committee
certifies the eligibility and establishes the maximum amount of credit which may
be extended to the borrower to meet actual needs.  7 C.F.R.  § 1831.7 (1977).
On October 27, 1976, the County Committee certified that Mr. Dahl was eligible
and recommended that the Dahls be granted a farm operating loan not to exceed $
35,000.

After certification, it is the responsibility of the county supervisor to decide
whether or not to approve a loan.  This administrative determination includes
whether:

(1) The applicant is eligible and likely to be successful in the proposed
operations and to achieve the objectives of the loan.

(2) The applicant has available, under satisfactory tenure arrangements, a unit
adequate in size and productivity to reasonably expect success,  [*9]  taking
into consideration farm and other income including income from a recreational or
other nonfarm enterprise.

(3) Plans have been made and documented for:

(i) A suitable system of farming or type of recreation or other nonfarm
enterprise.

(ii) The crucial adjustments and improvements and key practices essential for
the applicant's success.

(iii) Effective supervision and corrective action.

(4) The proposed farm and home operations, and recreational or other nonfarm
enterprise(s) of the applicant are feasible.

(5) The loan is feasible and can be repaid from income as scheduled, except as
provided in § 1831.11(a)(4), with respect to the last installment.

(6) The amount of the loan and the purposes for which the funds are to be used
are consistent with the applicant's needs and are for authorized purposes.

(7) The security requirements can be met.

(8) The certifications required of the applicant and County Committee have been
made and are a part of the loan docket.

(9) The loan meets all other FmHA requirements.

7 C.F.R.  § 1831.14 (1977).

Shortly after the County Committee certification, Mr. Peterson made an undated
entry in the running record [*10]  which stated:

To enable young man to purchase livestock & mach. he will sell cattle on farm
(Brown Swiss) & use our money to purchase machinery & cattle in spring.

Loan approved [signed] Lynn R. Peterson c/s

On November 8, 1976, Mr. Peterson formally approved the $ 35,000 operating loan
to the Dahls, repayable over 7 years.  He forwarded the appropriate obligational
documents to the FmHA national finance office for processing of the loan check.

The loan approval document states:

I HEREBY CERTIFY that all of the committee and administrative determinations and
certifications required by law or regulations prerequisite to providing
assistance of the type indicated above have been made and that evidence thereof
is in the docket, and that all requirements of pertinent regulations and laws
have been complied with.  I hereby approve the above-described assistance in the
amount set forth above, and by this document, subject to the availability of
funds, the Government agrees to advance such amount to the applicant for the
purposes of and subject to the conditions prescribed by the laws and regulations
applicable to this type of assistance. [Emphasis added.]

Processing of [*11]  loan checks takes approximately 6 weeks from loan approval.
In order for the balance of the personal property down payment to be made to the
Hatlelis, interim financing was arranged through the First National Bank of
Rushford, Minnesota (the bank).  Sometime after October 27, 1976, Mr. Peterson
and responded to a call from Mr. Albert Spande, an officer of the bank.  Mr.
Peterson told Mr. Spande that the Dahl farm operating loan would be approved.Mr.
Spande requested a letter confirming this, which Mr. Peterson forwarded on
November 12, 1976, stating:

We have approved a $ 35,000 loan to enable Mr. Dahl to purchase livestock and
machinery. If it becomes necessary for Mr. Dahl to purchase items included in
our loan, we will be glad to pay them off at the time we get our funds.

It was the custom and practice in the southeastern Minnesota banking community
to grant FmHA borrowers interim unsecured loans when the FmHA had obligated
itself to the borrower, but the funds had not yet been received at the local
FmHA office.  The November 12 letter written by Mr. Peterson to the bank
informing it that a FmHA loan had been approved for the Dahls was a part of the
custom and practice established [*12]  by the banks in cooperation with the
FmHA.  What legal implications such a letter had, however, were in sharp dispute
in this case.  The bank viewed the letter as a guarantee and that the FmHA had a
legal and moral ogligation to make the interim loan good in the event the
borrower defaulted.  The FmHA took the position that there was no legal or moral
commitment (nor legal authority to pay) contained in the letter of November 12.
The letter was merely an informational letter that the bank could use for
whatever purpose it chose.

On or about November 2, 1976, Mr. Dahl took possession of the personal property
on the Hatleli farm. He immediately discovered that many of the cows had been
misrepresented as being pregnant.  He also discovered that the quantity of feed
and crops was too low to adequately feed the cows over the winter because the
Hatlelis had been using the feed in the barn instead of pasturing the cows.
There were also mechanical problems with the farm machinery. Throughout November
1976 these facts were relayed by Mr. Dahl to Mr. Peterson and were brought to
the attention of the Dahls' attorney, Mr. David Joerg, of Preston, Minnesota.

On November 5, 1976, an employee [*13]  of the bank went to the Dahl residence
and the plaintiffs executed an unsecured promissory note for $ 35,000 payable to
the bank on December 15, 1976, the approximate date of the FmHA loan closing.
The bank did not seek or take any security for this interim loan transaction.
However, the note did indicate on its face that the purpose of the loan was for
a "down payment on the farm." The plaintiffs used the proceeds of the loan to
pay the required $ 35,000 balance for the personal property. Although the
contract with the Hatlelis required that the real estate down payment and the
payment for the personal property be placed in a trust account at the Rushford
State Bank until January 1, 1977, the Hatelis apparently received all or a
significant portion of the money directly in November 1976.  Thus, at the time
of the initial bank interim financing, the bank's funds were used for an
authorized FmHA operating loan purpose, i.e., the purchase of the Hatleli
personal property.

Mr. Dahl's dissatisfaction with the Hatleli personal property led him to consult
his attorney on November 10, 1976 for the purposes of seeking a settlement of
the personal property problem.  On December 2, 1976,  [*14]  his attorney sent
the Hatlelis a formal notice of rescission of the sale of the personal property
part of the transaction.  It was the Dahls' intention throughout this settlement
process to attempt to rescind the personal property portion of the Hatleli
transaction while still preserving and continuing with the purchase of the real
estate portion of the transaction.  Settlement negotiations with the Hatlelis
continued throughout November and December because they would not return the $
51,000 paid by the Dahls.  Mr. Peterson was kept apprised of these negotiations
by Mr. Dahl.

Meanwhile on November 26, 1976, Mr. Peterson had notified the Dahls that the
FmHA loan check had been received and that closing on the FmHA operating loan
was scheduled for December 3, 1976.  However, the loan closing was later
rescheduled for December 13, 1976.

On December 13, 1976, the FmHA farm operating loan for $ 35,000 was closed at
the FmHA office in Preston, Minnesota.  Interest began to accrue on the loan
proceeds as of that date.  The loan provided for repayment in seven annual
installments due on January 1 of each succeeding year.  At the closing,
plaintiffs signed a promissory note, a security [*15]  agreement and a deposit
agreement for a supervised bank account.

The proceeds of the FmHA loan were deposited in a supervised bank account at the
First National Bank of Rushford.  This is the normal financial arrangement in
loans of this type, where the FmHA supervises the borrower to make certain that
the loan proceeds are used for the intended purposes of the farm plan and that
the borrower is not taken advantage of by unscrupulous vendors.  Withdrawals may
be made only with the joint signatures of the county supervisor and the
borrower. 7 C.F.R.  § 1803.1-.11 (1977).  The security agreement provided that
the FmHA would take an immediate security interest in the plaintiffs' crops in
the field or in storage.  No specific security interest was taken in the
machinery and farm animals except as to those items that might thereafter be
acquired.  Nothing was listed because the personal property part of the
transaction was still in the process of settlement negotiations.

When the loan was closed on December 13, 1976, Mr. Peterson, the county
supervisor and authorized agent of the defendant, knew that the Hatleli personal
property was being rejected and that there were problems getting [*16]  the
Hatlelis to return the money paid for the personal property, including the
bank's interim loan proceeds.  Despite this knowledge, Mr. Peterson closed the
loan on behalf of the FmHA.  He further encouraged Mr. Dahl to continue with the
real estate portion of the contract and to resolve his problems with the
Hatlelis as to the personal property portion of the transaction.  As of the
December 13, 1976 loan closing, the FmHA made a contract to lend the plaintiffs
the funds for the purposes provided in the October 4, 1976 farm plan.

On December 15, 1976, the due date of the Dahls' promissory note to the bank on
the interim loan, Messrs. Dahl, Peterson and Spande met in Mr. Spande's office
at the bank.  The purpose of the meeting was for all parties concerned with the
Dahls' interim, loan to be apprised of the status of the loan and the underlying
Hatleli settlement negotiations. Mr. Spande made it clear to Mr. Dahl and Mr.
Peterson that he expected payment on the interim loan as soon as possible from
either Mr. Dahl or from he FmHA loan proceeds now in the supervised bank account
(sba).  Mr. Peterson indicated that the FmHA could not release the sba funds to
the bank until such time [*17]  as the Hatleli legal tangles had been cleared up
so that the FmHA could be sure that the funds would be spent for the authorized
farm plan purposes.  Mr. Dahl indicated that he was in no position to repay the
interim loan until the Hatleli settlement on the personal property had been
achieved.  Mr. Dahl indicated that the negotiations appeared to be going well.
He advised that it was his intention to rescind the personal property part of
the Hatleli transaction and to go forward with the purchase of the real estate
portion.  If such a settlement did work out, then he would be in a position to
sell the golf course house and use those funds to pay off the bank or otherwise
release the FmHA funds to the bank and use the house equity funds for the
purchase of the personal property. All parties agreed that the Hatleli problems
had to be resolved first and then the loan repayment would be resolved.  The
meeting ended with this understanding.  All parties agreed to work together to
achieve this goal.  At that time, Mr. Spande extended the due date on the Dahls'
promissory note from December 15, 1976 to February 15, 1977.

On January 3, 1977, the Hatlelis and the Dahls signed a new sales [*18]
contract for the purchase of only the real estate. This settlement agreement,
obtained within 60 days of when the personal property misrepresentation was
first discovered by Mr. Dahl, solved the legal problems with the personal
property. This new contract for deed delayed the first installment payment until
December 1, 1977.  It also raised the sales price by $ 5,000; however, this was
not payable until the end of the 20-year contract for deed term.  As a down
payment, the Hatlelis retained $ 40,000 from the $ 51,000 originally paid for
the combined real estate and personal property transaction.

On January 4, 1977, the Dahls made the first scheduled payment due on the FmHA
loan.  The payment of $ 303.00 was applied as follows: $ 118.41 to principal and
$ 184.59 to interest.

On January 6, 1977, with the money returned by the Hatlelis, the Dahls made an $
8,000.00 payment to the bank on the interim loan.  It was applied as follows: $
7,426.39 to principal and $ 573.61 to interest.  This left the principal balance
of the interim loan that the Dahls still owed the bank at $ 27,573.61.

Under the October 4, 1976 farm plan and the original contract, it was necessary
for the Dahls [*19]  to sell their golf course house to make the down payment on
the Hatleli real estate. At that time, they took all necessary steps to list and
sell the house.  After discovering the defects in the Hatleli personal property,
they took the home off the market awaiting the outcome of the Hatleli settlement
negotiations. If the Hatleli sale were to fall through entirely, then they
would, of course, need a house to live in.  Such actions were entirely
reasonable under the developing circumstances.

The Dahls promptly relisted their house for sale upon the signing of the new
real estate contract with the Hatlelis on January 3, 1977.  Despite having been
used originally to purchase the Hatleli personal property, part of the bank's
interim loan money went towards the down payment on the real estate when the
Hatleli personal property contract problem was settled.  The bank's moines were
substituted for the funds that had been expected from the sale of Dahls' house.

On January 26, 1977, Mr. Peterson wrote Mr. Dahl:

Please stop at our office some Monday in the near future to clarify the
following:

1.  If our FmHA money is to be used to to buy livestock, how are you going to
pay the First [*20]  National Bank back for the advance they made which we all
felt was for chattels, but apparently was used for farm downpayment?

2.  We would like to have a copy of the contract for deed on the farm.

Please take care of this in the near future (within two weeks).

In early February of 1977, Mr. Dahl requested that the FmHA release some of the
funds in the sba to purchase dairy cows as listed in the farm plan, which
covered the period of time from February 1, 1977 to February 1, 1978.  Mr.
Peterson refused to release the funds until the bank was repaid or secured by
the Dahls.  A similar request to release funds to purchase the half interest in
a tractor was likewise refused.  This was done, even though the Dahls had
actually repaid approximately $ 7,500 of the $ 35,000 interim bank loan.

In addition, although Mr. Peterson took the position that the FmHA had no legal
obligation to the bank (notwithstanding his November 12, 1976 letter,
characterized by the bank as a "letter of guarantee"), the FmHA was
"encouraging" the Dahls to sell their golf course house and repay the bank's
interim loan in order that the FmHA might keep cordial business relations with
the bank.  The "encouragement"  [*21]  to sell the house and repay the bank was
enforced by Mr. Peterson's (and his successor's) refusal to release any of the
sba funds for use by the Dahls to purchase the necessary operating personal
property.

At this point, the Dahls clearly were getting into a financial bind.  The real
estate market was slow and they could not sell the golf course house, which
would yield the money needed to repay the bank.  Until they repaid the bank, the
FmHA was refusing to release the farm operating loan money in the sba. Without
the operating loan money, the Dahls could not purchase the cows needed to start
their dairy herd, nor the seed to plant, nor the tractor needed to plant the
seed.  In short, spring was quickly approaching and the Dahls were stuck with a
farm but no personal property to run it and make it a financial success.  All of
the above was happening notwithstanding the FmHA's contractual obligations to
the Dahls.

On February 22, 1977, Mr. Dahl and Mr. Peterson met and Mr. Peterson filled out
the asset and liability portion of another farm plan on the Dahls' behalf.  This
showed total assets of $ 246,300 and liabilities of $ 201,090.  The Dahls' net
worth was then $ 45,210,  [*22]  which had varied only slightly from their net
worth on October 4, 1976.  During all of the meetings held between the two men
in February, Mr. Peterson was still manifesting a willingness to work with the
Dahls by urging them to continue trying to sell their house to repay the bank's
loan.  The Dahls' house was on the real estate market and the Dahls were doing
their best to sell it.

On or about February 28, 1977, Mr. Peterson resigned his position with the FmHA
to begin a new life as a dairy farmer in Wisconsin.  He made no written summary
of the events which had transpired in regard to the Dahl matter nor did he make
any written recommendations for future action by his successors.  At trial, Mr.
Peterson testified that even with all the problems that had transpired, if the
Dahls had repaid or secured the interim loan at the bank (through the sale of
the golf course house or in another manner), he would have released or
recommended that the funds in the sba be released to the Dahls so that they
could start the dairy farming operation.

On February 25, 1977, Mr. Gregory Kalinowski was appointed acting county
supervisor from February 28, 1977 to April 29, 1977.  This was a temporary [*23]
appointment because Mr. Kalinowski also was leaving the FmHA.  Early in March,
Mr. Dahl and Mr. Kalinowski met in an attempt to get the problems resolved so
that some or all of the funds in the sba could be released.  Mr. Kalinowski
reviewed the incomplete running record; however, he never attempted to contact
his predecessor, Mr. Peterson.  He concluded that the bank's funds and the FmHA
funds were the same dollars and that they had been used for an improper
purpose--to buy real estate. Thus, Mr. Kalinowski would not authorize the
release of the operating loan funds in the sba to Mr. Dahl either.

Throughout March of 1977, the bank continued to pressure Mr. Kalinokwski (just
as it had done to Mr. Peterson in January and February) to release the funds in
the sba to the bank and to secure the FmHA loan by taking a second mortgage on
the Dahls' golf course house or by converting the operating loan to a real
estate loan.  Mr. Kalinowski also continued to resist the bank's request.

On April 12, 1977, Mr. Kalinowski summarized in the running record the history
of the Dahl matter as he understood it, since he also was leaving the FmHA to
pursue a career in farming. However, he made [*24]  no recommendation as to how
he thought the Dahl matter should be handled by his successors.  Mr. Kalinowski
left FhHA employment on April 15, 1977.  He also testified at trial, that
unilateral withdrawal of loan funds by the FmHA was an extreme sanction, which
he never before had heard of being used during his 3 years of FmHA experience.
He also concluded that the Dahl matter was not that extreme or unusual a case to
justify such an extreme action.

On April 18, 1977, the district director, Mr. Bruce Bailey, after reviewing the
running record, decided that the state office should be notified of the prior
developments.  He did not contact Mr. Peterson or Mr. Dahl.  In his running
record summary forwarding the entire Dahl file to the state director, Mr. Bailey
noted that the bank wanted the FmHA to take a second mortgage on plaintiffs'
house and eventually be repaid out of the proceeds from a subsequent sale.  Mr.
Bailey also commented on the "uncomfortable" position the FmHA was in vis a vis
the bank, and that the FmHA was in this uncomfortable position due to the
borrowers' foul up.  The blame was placed squarely on the Dahls.

During the mid-1960's in connection with a previous [*25]  FmHA loan made out of
the Preston, Minnesota FmHA office, Mr. Bailey and Mr. Dahl had had some
disagreements.  It was clear that a certain amount of personal animosity existed
between the two men, although Mr. Bailey denied recommending withdrawal of the
loan funds based on any past disagreements.  The speed with which Mr. Bailey
took this action, and some of the comments appearing in the running record,
however, indicate otherwise.

The next day, on April 19, 1977, the file was reviewed in the state office by
Mr. Leslie Matts, Chief of Farmers Programs for Minnesota, then also Acting
State Director of the FmHA.  He replied to Mr. Bailey on that same day:

We have reviewed the file and also reviewed the circumstances with the National
Office.

We regret the way in which they case was handled and the comment from the County
Supervisor, however, he could not commit the U.S. Government to close the
transaction when conditions completely changed.

We would suggest that you further contact the borrower and the bank and assist
in any manner that you can so that the bank would get security on the proceeds
from the house and security in the real estate. There is no legal way we can
[*26]  release funds from supervised bank account to pay the bank for funds that
went into real estate.

The borrower should also be requested to co-sign a check withdrawing money from
the supervised bank account plus an additional amount for interest that has
accrued.

After receiving these directions from the state office, Mr. Bailey wrote
plaintiffs on April 23, 1977, requesting that they co-sign a check which would
have the effect of voluntarily terminating the farm operating loan contract and
returning the funds to the FmHA.  The plaintiffs did not comply with this
request.

On or about April 18, 1977, Mr. Spande contacted Mr. Bailey again to discuss the
Dahl problem now that Mr. Bailey had assumed acting county supervisory control
over the FmHA office in Preston, Minnesota.  He reiterated the entire history of
the case and reminded Mr. Bailey that the FmHA had agreed under Mr. Peterson and
Mr. Kalinowski to work with the Dahls and the bank.  Since the Dahls had not yet
been able to sell their golf course house, Mr. Spande suggested again that the
FmHA take a second mortgage on the house and then release the funds in the sba
to the bank.  Another alternative discussed was for the [*27]  FmHA to convert
the operating loan to a real estate loan and to take a mortgage on the farm. Mr.
Spande insisted that the FmHA had the flexibility and discretionary authority to
do either of the above.  Mr. Bailey, however, categorically refused to consider
either avenue.  From this discussion, Mr. Spande was left with the impression
that Mr. Bailey would do nothing further to assist the Dahls and the bank.  Mr.
Bailey further denied any FmHA legal responsibility to the bank based on the
November 12, 1976 "guarantee" letter.

After the above conversation, Mr. Spande contacted the Dahls to obtain security
on the interim loan.  He asked the Dahls to give the bank a second mortgage on
the golf course house and to list the house with the bank's real estate agent.
The Dahls readily agreed to both requests in order to secure the bank and get
the FmHA operating loan funds released.  On April 29, 1977, the bank took a
second mortgage for $ 28,439.11 on the Dahls' golf course house.  This mortgage
bore interest at the rate of 10 percent payable annually.  The bank was then
fully secured on its interim loan and thus no longer pressured the FmHA to bail
it out.

Shortly thereafter, Mr.  [*28]  Dahl requested an appointment with Mr. Bailey,
and on May 5, 1977, they met.  He advised Mr. Bailey that the bank was now
secured and would no longer pressure the FmHA.  Since this impediment had been
removed and the parties were back in the position contemplated by the October 4,
1976 farm plan, he requested the release of the operating loan funds so he could
begin his spring planting, buying of cows, and other farm activities.  At this
meeting, Mr. Bailey unequivocally refused to allow the plaintiffs to use the
loan proceeds.  It made no difference to Mr. Bailey that the plaintiffs had
secured the bank and that they were now in the same economic position as
presented in the October 4, 1976 farm plan.

When Mr. Dahl refused to sign a check that would have voluntarily terminated the
loan, Mr. Bailey informed him that he would forward the entire file to the state
director, with a recommendation that the loan be unilaterally terminated. The
file was forwarded on the same day, May 5, 1977.

In his cover letter to the state office, Mr. Bailey recommended that the state
director use his discretionary authority to unilaterally withdraw the funds from
the supervised bank account, thereby [*29]  terminating the loan.  This
recommendation was based upon Mr. Bailey's incorrect observations that: (1) the
plaintiffs had attempted to misuse the funds and (2) that the plaintiffs' debt
picture had changed substantially because they now had a $ 27,000 liability
which had not existed when the October 4 farm plan had been executed.  This
recommendation ignored the fact that the $ 27,000 liability was fully secured in
the equity in the Dahls' house and that this equity always had been intended to
be used toward the purchase of the Hatleli real estate. The cover letter makes
clear that Mr. Bailey wanted out of the loan contract with the Dahls because
"after what had transpired we should not become re-involved." It also indicates
that Mr. Dahl may contact his Congressman; that Mr. Dahl "has problems with
people and situations"; that he had a back injury and possibly should give up
farming; and it alludes to some "old history" of bad blood between the two men.

[HN2] Supervised bank accounts may be closed by unilateral action of the state
director for the following reasons: death of borrowers, borrower in default,
inactive borrower or when the borrower is paid up.  7 C.F.R.  §
1803.10(d)(1)-(4)  [*30]  (1977).  None of the above applies to the facts in
this case.  Unilateral terminations of loans are rarely done by the FmHA and
only in the most extreme and unusual circumstances.

On May 12, 1977, without any investigation, the state director wrote the bank
and unilaterally ordered the supervised bank account closed and the funds sent
to the FmHA.  The bank complied on May 25, 1977.  The $ 35,000.00 in the sba was
applied as follows: $ 1,187.41 to interest, $ 33,812.59 to principal.

At the time the sba was closed, the Dahls were not in default on their
promissory into to the FmHA.  They had already made the one payment that had
come due.The next payment was not due until January 1, 1978.  They had fulfilled
all their other obligations under the contract.

No funds were ever withdrawn from the sba because the FmHA would never permit
it.  The only requests for withdrawals were for the purchase of cows and
personal property as outlined in the farm plan.  No misuse of federal funds took
place, since among other reasons, none were ever expended from the sba. Despite
the fact that the plaintiffs had repaid the bank approximately $ 8,000, the FmHA
would not release any funds.  Even [*31]  after the bank's loan was secured, the
FmHA would not release the funds.

On November 19, 1977, the plaintiffs paid the FmHA an additional $ 1,114.88
under protest, as the FmHA would not release its security interest in the
plaintiffs' crops.  This payment was applied as follows: $ 45.88 to interest and
$ 1,069.00 to principal.  This closed out the entire Dahl transaction with the
FmHA.

By the middle of May of any given year, most farmers in this area of Minnesota
have already planted their crops and are well into the productive farm season.
Needless to say, without the release of the operating loan funds tied up in the
sba, the Dahls could not purchase the cows to milk, the seed to plant, nor
purchase the tractor necessary to farm the land.  The Dahls' dream of owning and
operating their own family dairly farm had quickly turned into a nightmare.  In
short, the Dahls had purchased a farm on the strength of an FmHA commitment that
they would be given a $ 35,000 farm operating loan to run it, and that
commitment was unilaterally terminated by the FmHA.  The appropriateness of that
unilateral termination forms the critical question in this case.

On December 19, 1977, plaintiffs [*32]  filed their petition in this court
alleging breach of contract, abuse of administrative discretion and asking for
appropriate damages.

Discussion

Plaintiffs claim that they had a farm operating loan contract with the FmHA
under the authority of 7 U.S.C.  §§ 1941-47 (Supp. IV 1980).  They further
assert that the FmHA breached that contract when it unilaterally withdrew the
money from the supervised bank account without legally sufficient reasons.
Plaintiffs acknowledge that the FmHA had the discretionary authority to
unilaterally withdraw funds under its regulations 7 C.F.R.  § 1803.10(d)(1)-(4)
(1977), but they argue that this case presents none of the circumstances
contained in the regulations, i.e., death of a borrower, borrower in default,
inactive borrower, or a paid up borrower. Plaintiffs even acknowledge that there
may be discretionary authority in these and other FmHA regulations to
unilaterally withdraw funds in the event of attempted misuse of FmHA funds by
borrowers. However, they hasten to add that there was no attempted misuse of
FmHA funds in this case.  In short, the plaintiffs allege that the FmHA breached
the contract to loan money when it unilaterally withdrew [*33]  the money from
the supervised bank account without having adequate legal reason under the
factual circumstances of this case.

The defendant counters the plaintiffs' claim by asserting that this is not a
typical case of a contract to loan money, but that the Government is "extending
no more than a gratutity," to borrowers. The defendant then asserts that the
state director properly exercised his discretion when he unilaterally withdrew
the funds after: (1) being apprised of the plaintiffs' misuse of the interim
bank financing; and (2) determining that the plaintiffs no longer had any
reasonable chance of success at farming in view of their new home mortgage
commitment to the bank.

As indicated earlier, for the reasons discussed herein, this court finds for the
plaintiffs.

Liability

The FmHA farm operating loan program is an expression of national public policy
enacted by Congress to encourage and assist family farming. However, operating
loans are not just an extension of a gratuity as the Government asserts.  There
was a contract in being between the plaintiffs and the defendant in this case.

The plaintiffs applied for an FmHA loan and were found eligible under all [*34]
the applicable regulations by the County Committee.  The county supervisor
approved the loan and forwarded the necessary obligational documents to the FmHA
national finance office.  The funds, in due time, were received by the local
county office and there was a loan closing.  The plaintiffs received the money
(in joint control with the FmHA) after executing a promissory note and security
agreement in favor of the FmHA.  The FmHA even received the first interest
payment when due, less than 30 days after the December 13, 1976 loan closing.
In short, promises were made and obligations assumed by both parties to this
contract.  The classical elements of a contract are present.  This court thus
finds that the series of transactions culminating in the loan closing on
December 13, 1976, was a contract to loan money to the Dahls for the purposes
outlined in the October 4, 1976 farm plan.

The critical question in this case remains, was the defendant legally justified
in unilaterally terminating the plaintiffs' farm operating loan contract.  This
court finds that it was not.

First and foremost, there was no misuse of funds by the plaintiffs as asserted
by the Government.  By contract [*35]  with the FmHA, the plaintiffs borrowed $
35,000 of federal funds as a farm operating loan.  None of that federal money
was ever used for anything--authorized or unauthorized.  The funds remained in
the supervised bank account, until the defendant unilaterally terminated the
contract.

What was used (or allegedly misused according to the Government), was the bank's
interim financing funds.  These funds were to be used, and in fact were so used,
for the purchase of the Hatleli farm machinery and cows. After this proper use,
the plaintiffs discovered that the Hatlelis had misrepresented the soundness and
value of their cows and machinery. The Dahls then took the perfectly reasonable
business approach of consulting their lawyer, and, at the same time keeping the
FmHA county supervisor apprised.  The lawyer, no stranger himself to FmHA
regulations, recommended a course of action that ultimately resulted in a
settlement with the Hatlelis in the record time of 60 days.  The settlement
agreement applied part of the original personal property payment ($ 40,000 of
the original $ 51,000 total payment) to the new real estate contract.  Part of
the remainder ($ 8,000) was repaid to the bank.  [*36]  Some of the bank's money
($ 27,000), which was applied 60 days earlier to the personal property part of
the original Hatleli transaction, was therefore applied to the real estate
portion in settlement. Thus, part of the properly used interim financing funds
ended up being used for the real estate down payment.

However, there was no bad faith, intent to deceive, or misuse of funds involved
in this settlement at all.  There was no bad faith on the part of the
plaintiffs, their lawyer, Mr. Peterson, or the bank.  It is interesting to note
that the bank never asserted that its interim loan funds had been misused.  Both
Mr. Peterson and Mr. Spande knew that the Dahls' house would yield approximately
$ 27,000 when sold that would be used to repay the bank's interim loan.  All
parties knew the situation and recognized that it was the best opportunity to
get the money back from the Hatlelis in the shortest possible time with the
minimum of legal expense.  Once the Dahls' house was sold, the Dahls could start
farming as contemplated by the farm plan.  All that was needed was some
patience, some understanding, and some supervision--all contemplated by the FmHA
regulations. While it may [*37]  have been perfectly proper for the FmHA not to
repay the bank for the interim financing on the basis that the bank's funds were
not used for an FmHA authorized purpose, the use of the bank's funds for the
real estate down payment was in no way a misuse of funds under the
circumstances.

However, things did not work out so happily.  As sometimes happens in the real
world, the Dahls could not sell their house immediately.  It was the dead of
winter in Minnesota, and the real estate market was slow.  Notwithstanding the
Dahls' best efforts, they were unable to sell their house from the time of
settlement on January 3, 1977 to May 12, 1977, when the FmHA unilaterally
terminated the contract.

During this time, the officers at the bank became increasingly impatient and
aimed most of their ire at the FmHA.  The bank thought it had a short-term
financial commitment to the Dahls that was "guaranteed" by the FmHA.  Since the
Dahls could not repay the bank, it looked to the FmHA to repay the loan.  The
FmHA could then secure itself by taking a second mortgage on the Dahls' golf
course house, or convert the farm operating loan to a real estate loan and take
a mortgage on the farm.

The [*38]  FmHA employees felt uncomfortably pressured by the bank, and
increasingly unsure of the FmHA's legal position under the November 12, 1976
"letter of guarantee." Mr. Peterson and Mr. Kalinowski admirably withstood most
of the bank pressure and continued to focus on what were the best interests of
the plaintiffs and the FmHA.  However, when Mr. Bailey assumed control, the
momentum shifted quickly and dramatically.  Mr. Bailey blamed Mr. Dahl for
placing the FmHA in this uncomfortable position with the bank.  Without
discussing the matter with either the Dahls or Mr. Peterson, Mr. Bailey
initiated the steps that led to the unilateral termination of this contract.
The evidence makes it very clear that Mr. Bailey simply wanted out of this
contract with the Dahls.

The Government has given an inadequate explantion of Mr. Bailey's reasons for
terminating the contract and of his view that the plaintiffs had misused the
funds.  There was no misuse of the FmHA funds because the FmHA never allowed
their use.  Likewise, there was no misuse of the bank's interim funds as
previously explained.  Consequently, the justification for the termination of
this contract because of the plaintiffs' "misuse [*39]  of funds," is inadequate
and mistaken.

[HN3] The mistaken beliefs of the various federal employees cannot serve to
protect the Government from liability.  Although decided on facts dealing with a
breach of a supply contract, this court has stated:

The stated ground for the cancellation was therefore nonexistent.  * * *  [HN4]
One may not repudiate his contract obligations upon the ground that he
reasonably, though mistakenly, believed that the other party to the contract had
breached it.

Companhia Atlantica v. United States, 148 Ct. Cl. 71, 75, 180 F. Supp. 342, 345,
cert. denied, 364 U.S. 862 (1960).

The fact that the termination letter was actually signed by the state director
as required by the regulations does not alter the result.  In fact, the evidence
indicates that the state director simply abdicated his discretionary
responsibility.  He never made an independent investigation nor contacted the
plaintiffs before the ordered the supervised bank account closed.  He accepted
the running record with all its apparent imperfections, and Mr. Bailey's
statements and recommendations as determinative.  Perhaps the following quote
from a leading contract case would be apt in this connection:

[*40]  We are certain that there have been a great many instances in which the
Government has not terminated a contractor in technical default, but has granted
an extension or waived the noncompliance.  * * * Our ruling today is not new.
More than ten years ago, the court specified that  [HN5] procurement officials
had to exercise judgment in terminating an agreement for default and were not
automatons.

Schlesinger v. United States, 182 Ct. Cl. 571, 581, 390 F.2d 702, 708 (1968).
Clearly the state director exercised none of the required discretion.

When the plaintiffs gave the bank the security it desired for the interim loan,
there no longer were any rational grounds for the FmHA's refusal to release the
farm operating loan funds.  Instead, the FmHA terminated the contract.  This
action breached the contract and was an bause of administrative discretion.

[HN6] The defendant used its discretionary power of unilateral termination under
7 C.F.R.  § 1803.10(d) "as a useful pretext for the taking of action felt to be
necessary on other grounds unrelated to the plaintiff's performance * * * and
never made a 'judgment as to the merits of the case.' * * * Such abdication of
responsibility we have [*41]  always refused to sanction where there is
administrative discretion under a contract." [Citations omitted.] Schlesinger v.
United States, supra, 182 Ct. Cl. at 583-84, 390 F.2d at 709.

The second justification the Government asserts for terminating this contract
was that when terminated, the plaintiffs had assumed more debt such that they
would have no chance of success in farming. The Government, again, in asserting
this reason is pointing out that the plaintiffs ultimately gave the bank
security on their golf course house, which they were not legally obligated to
do.  The plaintiffs could have refused to secure the bank, if they had wanted
to.  But they did not.  In good faith they incurred an obligation in order to
reduce the tension between the bank and the FmHA, and also to win release of the
farm operating loan proceeds.  The FmHA responded to this good faith effort by
terminating the contract, thus violating the obligations it was contractually
bound to perform.  These included, for instance, the FmHA's obligation to assist
and supervise borrowers as contained in  [HN7]  7 C.F.R.  § 1802.2 (1977):

(a) All loans made by FmHA are designed to assist individual borrower families
[*42]  to attain specific objectives.  Therefore, each borrower family will be
provided the supervision necessary to achieve those objectives and to protect
the financial interest of the Government.

In addition, the mortgage the plaintiffs gave the bank simply secured the bank
until such time as the plaintiffs sold their golf course house.  This is what
always had been planned, as evidenced by the October 4, 1976 farm plan.  The
Government was well aware of this.  The mortgage would have short term, if any,
effect on the plaintiffs' ultimte success in farming. The reality was that the
plaintiffs were in precisely the same economic position as the farm plan
contemplated.

It is also important to remember that  [HN8] no where in the FmHA's governing
statutes, regulations or the other contractual documents is there a prohibition
against the plaintiffs incurring subsequent debt.

Finally, this court cannot discount the possibility that this contract could
have been terminated for improper motives, which, of course, would amount to bad
faith.  The record makes clear that there was a history of "bad blood" between
Mr. Dahl and Mr. Bailey.  Although Mr. Bailey denied in his testimony that such
[*43]  "bad blood" had anything to do with his recommendations to the state
director to terminate the loan, the rapidity with which he took action upon
assuming control of the Dahl file, would suggest otherwise.  Mr. Bailey
forwarded the file to the state director on April 18, 1977, within 3 working
days after assuming control as acting county supervisor.

At the very least, it is obvious that Mr. Bailey did not approach the situation
with a neutral disposition.  Instead, he prejudged the situation without doing
so much as discussing it with either Mr. Dahl or Mr. Peterson.  In the process,
he relied on erroneous and inappropriate information.  This is not the
cooperation that the FmHA regulations mandate, nor that the contract requires.

The administration of this case clearly does not represent one of the FmHA's
finest hours.  For all of the above reasons, this court, therefore, conclude
that the plaintiffs are entitled to recover for breach of their contract by the
FmHA.

Damages

The plaintiffs have requested a damage award composed of the following elements:
(1) the reasonably anticipated profits from the dairy farm, if it had been
capitalized under the farm operating loan amount [*44]  of $ 35,000 for a 3-year
period of time from 1977 through 1979; (2) the reasonably anticipated increase
in the market value of the cows which would have been purchased in the spring of
1977 and appreciated through the end of 1979; and (3) the refund of the interest
paid to the FmHA on the farm operating loan proceeds which funds were never
released for the plaintiffs' use.

The Government has argued, in opposition to the above request, that the
plaintiffs are not entitled to any damages at all in this case, even if the
court would find for the plaintiffs as to liability.  The Government reasons
that this is so because any of the damages listed above by the plaintiffs are
consequential as being too remote and speculative.  The Government points out
that the plaintiffs were not engaged in any ongoing business and, consequently,
there is no way, short of pure speculation, to determine what their profits
would have been, nor what the actual appreciation of the cows would have been.
1 In support of this legal position, the Government asks the court to follow its
language in Chain Belt Co. v. United States, 127 Ct. Cl. 38, 60-62, 115 F. Supp.
701, 715-17 (1953), and Neely v. United States,  [*45]  152 Ct. Cl. 137, 146-47,
285 F.2d 438, 443 (1961), where the court stated:

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - Footnotes - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

1 This argument presumably would not apply to the return of interest, since such
a figure is an actual amount paid in this case.
- - - - - - - - - - - - End Footnotes- - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Plaintiff asks for  [HN9] loss of his anticipated profits.  This is a recognized
measure of damages, where their loss is the proximate result of the breach and
the fact that there would have been a profit is definitely established, and
there is some basis on which a reasonable estimate of the amount of the profit
can be made.  But profits are uncertain; they depend on so many contingencies,
especially in a new enterprise, that it is, in most cases, impossible to say
that the breach was the proximate cause of the loss of them, or that a profit
would have been realized, in any event; nor is there any basis to determined
what they might have amounted to.  This is especially true where the breach
occurred before operations had begun.

This question is carefully and fully considered in an opinion written for the
court by Judge Littleton in the case of Chain Belt Co. v. United States, 127 Ct.
Cl. 38. We shall not repeat what we said there.  Suffice it to say that almost
always, in the [*46]  case of a new venture, the fact that there would have been
a profit, had there been no breach, is too shrouded in uncertainty for loss of
anticipated profits to form a reliable measure of the damages suffered.

While the above is quite true and has been considered by this court, it is also
quite true that  [HN10] this court will not allow a party to be wronged without
at least attempting to put him in as good a position pecuniarily as he would
have been in if the contract had been completed.  Merely because the plaintiffs
have failed to establish exact damages with mathematical precision will not
defeat their right to recover.  If there is enough evidence adduced to enable
the court to make a fair and reasonable approximation of damages, that will
suffice.  See S.W. Electronics and Mfg. Corp. v. United States, 228 Ct. Cl.    ,

   , 655 F.2d 1078, 1088-89 (1981) and cases cited therein.  It is also
interesting to note that in Chain Belt, supra, and Neely, supra, notwithstanding
the language quoted above, the court ultimately allowed the plaintiffs to
recover.

This case, of course, is not the ordinary contract to loan money case.  In the
ordinary case, the measure of damages normally [*47]  would be the difference in
cost between the substitute loan obtained and the breached loan contract.
However in this case, that normal rule cannot be applied since the Dahls were
unable to obtain other commercial loans.  Of course, the Government knew this,
since that was one of the requirements for the farm operating loan in the first
instance.  Under these circumstances, the more specific damage rule for a
contract to loan money that should be applied is that  [HN11] "the borrower can
get judgment for damages measured by his resulting injury so far as the
defendant had reason to foresee such injury when the contract was made." 5
Corbin, Contracts § 1078 (1964 & Supp. 1980), Restatement (Second) of Contracts
§ 351e (1981).  Although the FmHA in no way guaranteed that the plaintiffs'
farming operation would succeed, both parties contemplated that it would.
Therefore, it was foreseeable to the FmHA that the plaintiffs would lose farming
operation profits upon the breach of the contract to loan money.  The farm
operating loan program is designed to aid those farmers who are unable to obtain
credit elsewhere.  The Dahls had no other source for operating capital.Thus, the
Government is liable [*48]  for the foreseeable losses which resulted from the
Dahls not having the use of the loan funds.

Mr. Gary Zimmer, the plaintiffs' witness on damages, qualified as an expert
based on his background, education and experience.  He was credible and he
provided a reasonable basis for measuring damages by making use of price and
cost data from similar family farm units in this area of southeastern Minnesota.
Where possible, he made reasonable use of the actual figures from the Dahl farm.
Although the Government's expert witness disagreed with the relevance of the
figures as to any one particular farmer, he overall concurred in the accuracy of
the data and the sources.  Generally, with corrections to conform to the
evidence, the plaintiffs' expert's report is used as a basis for granting
damages based on expected farm operating profits from the Dahl farm operation.
Trial was held in 1980 and the expert calculated damages for the years 1977-79,
the only years for which data was available.  Although plaintiffs' damages may
have continued, 3 years was a reasonably foresseable period of time for which to
grant damages, and no damages will be awarded beyond calendar 1979.

The first element [*49]  of damages requested and allowed is that element
relating to anticipated profits from the operation of the farm. The plaintiffs
could reasonably anticipate profits based on the production of milk from their
dairy herd and from the sale of excess grain raised on the farm and not needed
to feed the animals.  These anticipated profits were also foreseeable by the
FmHA.

Mr. Zimmer's report indicated, and he further testified, that the Holstein cows
the Dahls planned to purchase in the spring of 1977, would have produced an
average of 13,500 pounds of milk per cow per year starting in 1977, with an
anticipated increase of 500 pounds per year thereafter.  Thus he used these
figures in computing damages.  However, this court is adopting a lower starting
figure of 12,000 pounds of milk per cow per year starting in 1977 and allowing a
500-pound increase per year for 1978 and 1979.  This is being done because the
plaintiffs' farm plan of October 4, 1976, indicated that 12,000 pounds of milk
per year was the anticipated production on which the plan was financially based.
Consequently, this figure was contemplated by the FmHA and thus the damages
based on this figure was foreseeable.  In [*50]  addition, this was a beginning
milk production figure that the Government's damage expert agreed was a
reasonable one.

The court also adopts the Zimmer report's damage figures in regard to the sale
of excess grain that was not needed to feed the cows. Mr. Zimmer's figures were
based in part on the Dahls' actual crop production figures during 1977 through
1979, and in part on the production figures of other full-time farm units of
comparable size in the surrounding counties.  This was a reasonable method of
computing damages in view of the plaintiffs' inability to fully utilize the crop
potential of their farm due to the lack of operating capital, brought on by the
defendant's breach.

In 1977, the plaintiffs could have reasonably anticipated selling $ 38,880.00
worth of milk and $ 7,011.00 worth of excess grain.  Subtracting out the dairy
costs, crop costs, interest expense and real estate taxes totaling $ 38,566.42
would yield a net income of $ 7,324.58.  In 1978, the plaintiffs could have
reasonably anticipated selling $ 45,000.00 worth of milk and $ 4,836.00 worth of
excess grain.  Subtracting out the same costs listed above would yield a net
income of $ 5,385.70.  Likewise [*51]  in 1979, the plaintiffs could reasonably
anticipate selling $ 54,146.60 of milk, selling culled cows at $ 7,500.00 and
selling excess grain at $ 5,760.30.  Subtracting out the same costs would yield
plaintiffs a net income of $ 21,419.62.

The total net income figure for 1977-79 would thus be $ 34,129.90.  From this
net income figure, several other subtractions and additions were made.  First,
Mr. Dahl's actual nonfarm income would not have been earned if he had been able
to engage in full-time farming, which is what both contracting parties
contemplated.  Therefore, this amount of $ 10,397.91 earned by Mr. Dahl during
the 1977-79 years must be subtracted from the net income figure.  Second, there
has to be an adjustment made from the above net income figure to reflect the
actual farm income received by the Dahls during this period of time (1977-79),
which was a negative $ 20,388.02.  Because the farm actually operated at a loss
during this 3-year period of time, what would normally be a reduction from net
income (subtraction) becomes an addition.  Third, a further subtraction from net
income must be made for the depreciation deductions already taken by the
plaintiffs during this [*52]  3-year period of time in the amount of $ 9,648.00.
These were noncash items as shown on the plaintiffs' income tax returns for the
3 years at issue.  Taking into account these three adjustment figures from the
net income figure yields an anticipated profit figure of $ 34,472.01.

The plaintiffs are, therefore, entitled to their anticipated profit damages of $
34,472.01.  The court is well aware that this figure is something less than an
exact damage amount computed with methematical precision.  But as this court
stated in Electronic & Missile Facilities, Inc. v. United States, 189 Ct. Cl.
237, 257, 416 F.2d 1345, 1358 (1969):

[HN12] The ascertainment of damages, * * * is not an exact science, and where
responsibility for damage is clear, it is not essential that the amount thereof
be ascertainable with absolute exactness or mathematical precision: "It is
enough if the evidence adduced is sufficient to enable a court or jury to make a
fair and reasonable approximation."

It is the opinion of this court that the damages awarded herein are a fair and
reasonable approximation of the damages suffered by the plaintiffs in this case.

The second element of damages the plaintiffs requested [*53]  is an award for
the increase in appreciation of the cows from 1977 to 1979.  The plaintiffs
presented proof that the Holstein cows planned to be purchased under the farm
plan would have appreciated in value from $ 700 to $ 1,500 from 1977 to 1979.

In essence, this request is asking for an award of market appreciation.  Market
appreciation such as this was not foreseeable by the Government when it entered
this contract, nor was it a part of the anticipted profits.  The contract was
not entered into with the view of holding or investing in the cows for this type
of appreciation.  This is not the type of case where the defendant is liable for
damages for a lost investment opportunity where the investment itself was the
object of the contract.  See G. L. Christian v. United States, 160 Ct. Cl. 1,
11, 312 F.2d 418, 423, reh'g denied, 160 Ct. Cl. 58, 320 F.2d 345, cert. denied,
375 U.S. 954 (1963). These cows were not planned to be purchased for their
resale value but instead were planned for use in the production of income.

Thus, this second element of damage was not foreseeable and will not be awarded
as part of the damages.

The plaintiffs' third element of damages requested is [*54]  for a refund of the
interest paid to the FmHA on the farm operating loan.  The plaintiffs are
entitled to recover this sum also.  This is so because the Government should not
get the benefits of a bargain that it breached.  As this court has previously
stated:

It has been held for generations that a party to a contract may not interfere
with performance by the party to be charged and still enforce the letter of the
contract.

Roberts v. United States, 174 Ct. Cl. 940, 951, 357 F.2d 938, 945 (1966),
quoting Bateson-Stolte, Inc. v. United States, 145 Ct. Cl. 387, 394, 172 F.
Supp. 454, 458 (1959) (Jones, C.J. concurring).  This maxim applies here.  The
Government should not be able to retain the interest paid, the tangible benefit
it contracted to receive under the loan contract that it breached.  And, of
course, the plaintiffs never got the use of the FmHA loan funds.

The evidence shows that the plaintiffs paid total interest of $ 1,417.88 to the
FmHA.  They are entitled to further recovery in that amount.

The plaintiffs are therefore entitled to recover a total amount of $ 35,889.89
in this case.

FINDINGS OF FACT

1.  Plaintiffs, Eldon H. Dahl and Jeanette M. Dahl are husband [*55]  and wife.
They reside in rural southeastern Minnesota near Rushford, which is located in
Fillmore County.  Both Eldon and Jeanette Dahl were born and raised on family
farms located in and around Fillmore County.  They both grew up with other
siblings in the family and assisted their parents in operating the family farm.
In addition, they had previously lived on a family farm as a married couple.

2.  The defendant is the United States of America acting through the Farmers
Home Administration (FmHA), an agency within the Department of Agriculture.

3.  Jurisdiction is founded on 28 U.S.C.  § 1491 (Supp. III 1979).

4.  The plaintiffs make claim for damages incurred as a result of the
defendant's breach of a contract to loan money.  They claim that the defendant
made a operating loan to them under the authority of 7 U.S.C.  §§ 1941-47 (Supp.
IV 1980).  The defendant refused to advance the funds and unilaterially
terminated the loan thereby breaching the contract to loan money.  Plaintiffs
further claim that this unilateral termination was an abuse of administrative
discretion.  In addition, plaintiffs ask for the return of interest paid on the
loan proceeds.

5.  The Secretary [*56]  of Agriculture established the FmHA by order dated
August 14, 1946.  11 Fed. Reg. 9007. The agency operates principally under the
Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act, 7 U.S.C.  § 1921 et seq. (Supp. IV
1980) and Title V of Housing Act of 1949, 42 U.S.C.§ 1471 et seq. (Supp. III
1979).  The FmHA makes loans to farmers who are unable to obtain credit
elsewhere from commercial sources.

[The FmHA] is responsible for Loan and Grant and other assistance programs
including: Rural Housing; Farm Operating; Farm Ownership; Emergency; Soil and
Water; Business and Industrial; Watershed; Resource Conservation and
Development; Comprehensive Area Plans; Water and Waste Disposal; and Community
Facilities.  The programs are administered in accordance with regulations are
administered in authority and assignment of functions * * * codified in Chapter
XVIII, Title 7, Code of Federal Regulations. * * *

7 C.F.R.  § 1800.1 (1977).

6.  The FmHA makes several types of loans.  Among them are operating loans, 7
U.S.C.  § 1941 (1976):

(a) The Secretary is authorized to make loans under this subchapter to farmers
and ranchers in the United States and in Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands
[*57]  who (1) are citizens of the United States, (2) have a farm background and
training or farming experience which the Secretary determines is sufficient to
assure reasonable prospects of success in the proposed farming operation, (3)
are or will become operators of not larger than family farms, and (4) are unable
to obtain sufficient credit elsewhere to finance their actual needs at
reasonable rates and terms, taking into consideration prevailing private and
cooperative rates and terms in the community in or near which the applicant
resides for loans for similar purposes and periods of time.

and real estate purchase loans, 7 U.S.C.  § 1922 (1976):

The Secretary is authorized to make and insure loans under this subchapter to
farmers and ranchers in the United States and in Puerto Rico and the Virgin
Islands who (1) are citizens of the United States, (2) have a farm background,
except with respect to veterans as defined in section 1983(e) of this title, a
farm background shall not be required as a condition precedent to obtaining any
loan, and either training or farming experience which the Secretary determines
is sufficient to assure reasonable prospects of success in the proposed [*58]
farming operations, (3) are or will become owner-operators of not larger than
family farms, and (4) are unable to obtain sufficient credit elsewhere to
finance their actual needs at reasonable rates and terms, taking into
consideration prevailing private and cooperative rates and terms in the
community in or near which the applicant resides for loans for similar purposes
and periods of time.

7.  Operating loan funds may be used for such things as purchase of livestock,
farm equipment and feed.  7 C.F.R.  § 1831.9 (1977).  Operating loans may not be
used for the purchase of real estate. 7 U.S.C.  § 1943 (1976), 7 C.F.R.  §
1831.10(b) (1977).

8.  FmHA loans are made through local county offices which are run by a county
supervisor. The county supervisor in turn reports to a district director.  The
program in each state is run by a state director.

9.  The FmHA county office keeps a file on the transactions of each borrower.
Part of this file is the running record in which all borrower contacts or
borrower-related contacts are to be noted.  The running record in the Dahl file
is incomplete as to contacts; entries were made after the fact; entries are
undated or misdated;  [*59]  and parts of the pages in the running record were
torn off, or otherwise mutilated or unreadable.  The running record in this file
was maintained in a negligent and imprecise manner.  Thus, the running record in
this case does not provide the complete picture of what occurred in this
transaction.

10.  During the winter of 1975-76, the plaintiff, Mr. Eldon Dahl first came into
