contact with Mr. Lynn Peterson, the FmHA County Supervisor serving Houston and
Fillmore Counties of southeastern Minnesota.  On one occasion Mr. Peterson spoke
before a farm management vocational class attended by Mr. Dahl at the Winona
Area Technical Institute in Winona, Minnesota.  At that time, Mr. Peterson
explained to the class the farm loan assistance programs offered by the FmHA and
available to local farmers.

11.  To receive a farm operating loan, a farmer makes a written application to
the county office and submits a Farm and Home Plan (farm plan).  The farm plan
consists of a balance sheet presentation of assets and liabilities, cash flow
analysis and the proposed use of the loan funds.

12.  On May 17, 1976, Mr. Dahl went to see Mr. Peterson at the FmHA office in
Preston, Minnesota, to discuss [*60]  securing an operating loan to purchase
livestock and machinery in connection with a possible purchase of a 160-acre
farm owned by Mr. Merle Hatleli and his wife.  The plaintiffs intended to sell
their house located adjacent to a golf course near Rushford, Minnesota (golf
course house), to raise the proceeds for a down payment on the Hatleli farm. Mr.
Dahl, with the assistance of Mr. Peterson, filled out a farm plan and completed
an FmHA application for an operating loan.  Sale negotiations subsequently fell
through and no sale of the Hatleli farm was completed at that time.  There was
no further processing of the application or farm plan.

13.  However, in late August or early September of 1976, the Hatlelis again
contacted the plaintiffs and indicated their renewed desire to sell their farm.
One necessary term was that there be one sale of both the real estate and also
the personal property located on the farm such as cattle, machinery and
equipment.

14.  Mr. Dahl again contacted Mr. Peterson in September of 1976 and arranged to
meet him at the Hatleli farm. On September 21, 1976, Mr. Peterson and Mr. Dahl
together visited the Hatleli farm for the purpose of assessing the [*61]  value
of the farm and the personal property. The Hatlelis were asking $ 160,000 for
the farm real estate and $ 48,500 for the personal property located on the farm.
After the visit, Mr. Peterson and Mr. Dahl discussed the terms in Peterson's
car.  Mr. Peterson thought that the Hatlelis were getting maximum value for
their farm, but because the barn and house were in excellent shape, the farm
all-in-all would make a good purchase.Mr. Peterson recommended that if the Dahls
wanted to go into farming and wanted the farm, they should buy it.  Also he
indicated there would be no problem getting approval of a FmHA operating loan
because of the Dahls' background in family farming and Mr. Dahl's vocational
training in farm management.  Both parties agreed that the Hatlelis' Brown Swiss
cows should be sold in the coming spring of 1977 and new Holstein cows purchased
in their place.  They also agreed that some other equipment, including a
tractor, should be sold and replaced.  Both parties then left the Hatleli farm.
On September 24, 1976, Mr. Dahl returned to Mr. Peterson's office in Preston to
fill in a new farm plan and reactivate the original application for an operating
loan.

15.  On [*62]  September 27, 1976, the plaintiffs signed an earnest money
contract on the Hatleli farm and personal property. The terms were $ 48,500 for
the personal property and $ 160,000 for the real estate. Of the $ 16,000 cash
down payment, $ 1,000 was applied to the real estate and $ 15,000 was applied to
the personal property. Payment of the balance due on the personal property and
closing of the personal property were set for November 1, 1976.  Possession of
the farm was also set for November 1, 1976.  The sale of the real estate was on
a 20-year installment contract for deed.  An additional $ 39,000 was due on the
real estate down payment on January 1, 1977, the date set for the real estate
closing.

16.  On October 4, 1976, Mr. Dahl submitted the completed farm plan to Mr.
Peterson.  The period for the farm plan was February 1, 1977 to February 1,
1978.

17.  One essential element of the October 4 farm plan was the intention to sell
the Hatlelis' Brown Swiss cows and replace them the following spring with better
milk-producing Holstein cows. The balance of the operating loan funds was to be
used to purchase a bulk tank for milk storage and a half interest in a tractor.
The second [*63]  essential element was that the Dahls intended to sell their
house to realize the equity of approximately $ 27,000 which was to be used
towards the down payment on the real property portion of the Hatleli contract.
Since the Dahls would be living in the Hatleli farm house, there would be no
need to keep their golf course house.

18.  The defendant's regulations provide that the county supervisor reviews the
application and verifies the information.

[He] will analyze the applicant's request, giving careful consideration to his
experience, abilities, resources, and credit needs, and will tentatively
determine which type of FmHA assistance will most effectively meet the
applicant's needs.

7 C.F.R.  § 1801.3(b) (1977).

19.  The application then goes to the County Committee which is composed of
three individuals residing in the county, at least two of whom make their living
principally by farming. The County Committee determines if an applicant is
eligible for a loan.

20.  The determination of eligibility encompasses a review of the borrower's
financial status to determine among other things, that the borrower is unable to
secure a loan elsehwere and that the borrower [*64]  has a reasonable prospect
of success in the proposed operation.  7 C.F.R.  §§ 1801.3(a)(2), 1831.5 (1977).
If a borrower is eligible, the County Committee certifies the eligibility and
establishes the maximum amount of credit which may be extended to the borrower
to meet actual needs.  7 C.F.R.  § 1831.7 (1977).

21.  On October 27, 1976, the County Committee certified that Mr. Dahl was
eligible and recommended that he be granted a loan not to exceed $ 35,000.

22.  After certification, it is the responsibility of the county supervisor to
decide whether or not to approve a loan.  This administrative determination
includes whether:

(1) The applicant is eligible and likely to be successful in the proposed
operations and to achieve the objectives of the loan.

(2) The applicant has available, under satisfactory tenure arrangements, a unit
adequate in size and productivity to reasonably expect success, taking into
consideration farm and other income including income from a recreational or
other nonfarm enterprise.

(3) Plans have been made and documented for:

(i) A suitable system of farming or type of recreation or other nonfarm
enterprise.

(ii) The crucial adjustments [*65]  and improvements and key practices essential
for the applicant's success.

(iii) Effective supervision and corrective action.

(4) The proposed farm and home operations, and recreational or other nonfarm
enterprise(s) of the applicant are feasible.

(5) The loan is feasible and can be repaid from income as scheduled, except as
provided in § 1831.11(a)(4), with respect to the last installment.

(6) The amount of the loan and the purposes for which the funds are to be used
are consistent with the applicant's needs and are for authorized purposes.

(7) The security requirements can be met.

(8) The certifications required of the applicant and County Committee have been
made and are a part of the loan docket.

(9) The loan meets all other FmHA requirements.

7 C.F.R.§ 1831.14 (1977).

23.  The running record in this case contains an undated entry sometime in
October or November of 1976:

To enable young man to purchase livestock & mach. he will sell cattle on farm
(Brown Swiss) & use our money to purchase machinery & cattle in spring.

Loan approved

[signed] Lynn R. Peterson c/s

24.  Processing of loan checks takes approximately 6 weeks from loan approval.
[*66]  In order for the balance of the personal property down payment to be made
to the Hatlelis, interim financing for the Dahls was arranged through the First
National Bank of Rushford, Minnesota (the bank).  Sometime after October 27,
1976, Mr. Peterson responded to a call from Mr. Albert Spande, an officer of the
bank.  Mr. Peterson told Mr. Spande that the Dahl farm operating loan would be
approved.  Mr. Spande requested a letter confirming this, which Mr. Peterson
forwarded on November 12, 1976.

25.  On or about November 2, 1976, Mr. Dahl took possession of the personal
property on the Hatleli farm. He discovered that many of the cows had been
misrepresented as being pregnant when in fact many were not.  He also discovered
that the quantity of feed and crops was too low to adequately feed the cows over
the winter because the Hatlelis had been using the feed in the barn instead of
pasturing the cows. There were also mechanical problems with the farm machinery.
Throughout November 1976 these facts were relayed by Mr. Dahl to Mr. Peterson
and were brought to the attention of the Dahls' attorney, Mr. David Joerg, of
Preston, Minnesota.

26.  On November 5, 1976, an employee of [*67]  the bank went to the Dahl
residence and the plaintiffs executed an unsecured promissory note for $ 35,000
payable to the bank on December 15, 1976, the approximate date of the FmHA loan
closing.  The proceeds of this interim loan were used to pay the required
balance for the Hatleli personal property. The note did indicate on its face
that the purpose of the loan was for a "downpayment on the farm."

27.  Although the contract with the Hatlelis required that the real estate down
payment and the payment for the personal property be placed in a trust account
at the Rushford State Bank until January 1, 1977, the Hatlelis received all or
substantially all of the money directly in November of 1976.

28.  When the interim bank loan was made, the bank's funds were used for an
authorized FmHA operating loan purpose, i.e., the purchase of the Hatleli
personal property.

29.  On November 8, 1976, Mr. Peterson formally approved the $ 35,000 operating
loan to the Dahls, repayable over 7 years.  He thereafter forwarded the
appropriate financial and loan certification documents to the FmHA national
finance office for processing of the loan check.  The FmHA loan approval states:

I HEREBY [*68]  CERTIFY that all of the committee and administrative
determinations and certifications required by law or regulations prerequisite to
providing assistance of the type indicated above have been made and that
evidence thereof is in the docket, and that all requirements of pertinent
regulations and laws have been complied with.  I hereby approve the
above-described assistance in the amount set forth above, and by this document,
subject to the availability of funds, the Government agrees to advance such
amount to the applicant for the purposes of and subject to the conditions
prescribed by the laws and regulations applicable to this type of assistance.
[Emphasis added.]

30.  On November 12, 1976, Mr. Peterson wrote to the bank pursuant to Mr.
Spande's request:

We have approved a $ 35,000 loan to enable Mr. Dahl to purchase livestock and
machinery. If it becomes necessary for Mr. Dahl to purchase items included in
our loan, we will be glad to pay them off at the time we get our funds.

31.  It was the custom and practice in the southeastern Minnesota banking
community to grant FmHA borrowers interim unsecured loans when the FmHA had
obligated itself to the borrower, but the funds [*69]  had not yet been received
at the local FmHA office.  The November 12 letter written by Mr. Peterson to the
bank informing it that an FmHA loan had been approved for the Dahls was a part
of the custom and practice established by the banks in cooperation with the
FmHA.  What legal implications such a letter had, however, were in sharp dispute
in this case.  The bank viewed the letter as a guarantee and that the FmHA had a
legal and moral obligation to make the interim loan good to the bank in the
event the borrower defaulted.  The FmHA took the position that there was no
legal or moral commitment (nor legal authority to pay) contained in the letter
of November 12.  The letter was merely an informational letter that the bank
could use for whatever purpose it chose.

32.  Mr. Dahl's dissatisfaction with the Hatleli personal property led him to
consult his attorney, Mr. Joerg on November 10, 1976.  He consulted further with
his attorney throughout November and December.  On December 2, 1976, his
attorney sent the Hatlelis a formal notice of rescission of the sale of the
personal property. It was the intention of the Dahls throughout this settlement
process to attempt to rescind the personal [*70]  property portion of the
Hatleli transaction and still preserve or continue with the purchase of the real
estate portion.

33.  On November 26, 1976, Mr. Peterson notified the Dahls that the FmHA loan
closing was scheduled for December 3, 1976; however, the closing was
subsequently cancelled and rescheduled for December 13, 1976.

34.  Settlement negotiations with the Hatlelis continued throughout November and
December because they would not return the $ 51,000 paid by the Dahls.  Mr.
Peterson was apprised of these negotiations.

35.  The defendant's regulations provide in  [HN13]  7 C.F.R.  § 1831.32(b)
(1977):

(ii) If it is found, after an applicant has been certified as eligible, that
there will be a major change in operations or that an amount of credit in excess
of the maximum previously established by the County Committee will be required
for the designated corp or operating year, it will be necessary for the County
Committee again to certify the applicant as eligible on the basis of the changed
circumstances if a loan is to be made.

36.  At no time prior to the loan closing, did Mr. Peterson feel it was
necessary to have the County Committee recertify Mr. Dahl.

37.On December [*71]  13, 1976, the FmHA operating loan for $ 35,000 was closed
at the FmHA office in Preston, Minnesota.  At the closing, plaintiffs signed a
promissory note, a security agreement and a deposit agreement for a supervised
bank account.

38.  The proceeds of the FmHA loan were deposited in a supervised bank account
at the First National Bank of Rushford.  This is an arrangement whereby the FmHA
supervises the borrower to make certain that the loan proceeds are used for the
intended purposes of the Farm and Home Plan and that the borrower is not taken
advantage of by unscrupulous vendors.  Withdrawals may be made only with the
joint signatures of the county supervisor and the borrower. 7 C.F.R.  §§
1803.1-.11 (1977).

39.  The security agreement provided that the FmHA would take an immediate
security interest in the plaintiffs' crops in the field or in storage.  No
specific security interest was taken in the machinery and cows except as to
those items that might thereafter be acquired.  Nothing was listed because the
personal property part of the transaction was still in the process of settlement
negotiations.

40.  Interest began to accrue on the loan proceeds as of the loan closing [*72]
on December 13, 1976.  The loan provided for repayment in seven annual
installments due on January 1 of each succeeding year.

41.  When the loan was closed on December 13, 1976, Mr. Peterson, the county
supervisor and authorized agent of the defendant, knew that the Hatleli personal
property was being rejected, and that there were problems getting the Hatlelis
to return the money paid for the personal property, including the bank's interim
loan funds.  Despite this knowledge, Mr. Peterson closed the loan.  He further
encouraged Mr. Dahl to continue the real estate portion of the contract and to
resolve his problems with the Hatlelis as to the personal property portion of
the transaction.

42.  This series of events and transactions between the Dahls and the FmHA
constituted a contract to loan money for the purposes as provided in the
original farm plan.

43.  On December 15, 1976, the due date of the Dahls' promissory note to the
bank on the interim loan, Messrs. Dahl, Peterson and Spande met in Mr. Spande's
office at the bank.  The purpose of the meeting was for all parties concerned
with the Dahls' interim loan to be apprised of the status of the loan and the
underlying Hatleli [*73]  settlement negotiations. Mr. Spande made it clear to
Mr. Dahl and Mr. Peterson that he expected payment on the interim loan as soon
as possible from either Mr. Dahl or from the FmHA loan proceeds now in the
supervised bank account (sba).  Mr. Peterson indicated that the FmHA could not
release the sba funds to the bank until such time as the Hatleli legal tangles
had been cleared up so that the FmHA could be sure that the funds would be spent
for the authorized purpose of purchasing cows and machinery. Mr. Dahl indicated
that he was in no position to repay the interim loan until settlement had been
achieved on the Hatleli personal property. Mr. Dahl indicated that the
negotiations appeared to be going well.  He advised that it was his intention to
rescind the personal property part of the Hatleli transaction and to go forward
with the purchase of the real estate portion.  If such a settlement did work
out, then he would be in a position to sell the golf course house and use those
funds to pay off the bank or otherwise release the FmHA funds to the bank and
use the house equity funds for the purchase of the personal property. All
parties agreed that the Hatleli problems had to be [*74]  resolved first and
then the loan repayment would be resolved.  The meeting ended with this
understanding.  All parties agreed to work together to achieve this goal.  At
that time, Mr. Spande extended the due date on the Dahls' promissory note from
December 15, 1976 to February 15, 1977.

44.  On January 3, 1977, the Hatlelis and the Dahls signed a new sales contract
for the purchase of only the real estate. This settlement agreement, obtained
within 60 days of when the personal property misrepresentation was first
discovered by Mr. Dahl, solved the legal problems with the personal property.
This new contract for deed delayed the first installment payment until December
1, 1977.  It also raised the sales price by $ 5,000; however, this was not
payable until the end of the 20-year contract for deed term.As a down payment,
the Hatlelis retained $ 40,000 from the $ 51,000 originally paid for the
combined real estate and personal property transaction.

45.  On January 4, 1977, the Dahls made the first scheduled payment due on the
FmHA loan.  The payment of $ 303.00 was applied as follows: $ 118.41 to
principal and $ 184.59 to interest.

46.  On January 6, 1977, with the money returned [*75]  by the Hatlelis, the
Dahls made an $ 8,000.00 payment to the bank on the interim loan.  It was
applied as follows: $ 7,426.39 to principal and $ 573.61 to interest.  This left
the principal balance on the interim loan from the bank at $ 27,573.61.

47.  Under the October 4, 1976 farm plan and the original contract, it was
necessary for the Dahls to sell their golf course house to make the down payment
on the Hatleli real estate. At that time they took all necessary steps to list
and sell the house.  After discovering the defects in the Hatleli personal
property, however, they took the home off the market awaiting the outcome of the
settlement negotiations. They promptly relisted the house upon the signing of
the January 3, 1977 real estate contract.

48.  Despite having been used originally to purchase the Hatleli personal
property, part of the bank's interim loan money went towards the down payment on
the real estate when the Hatleli personal property contract problem was settled.
The bank's monies were substituted for the funds that had been expected from the
equity of Dahls' house which had not yet been sold.

49.  The October 4, 1976 farm plan lists the house as an asset [*76]  with a
value of $ 48,500 subject to a mortgage of $ 15,572 to First Federal Savings.
However, not shown on the farm plan was a small second mortgage owed to a
private individual.  The Dahls purchased the home subject to the second
mortgage. The balance due on this mortgage was approximately $ 2,163.11.  It is
common for applicants for FmHA loans to inadvertently omit both debts and assets
on farm plans.

50.  The October 4, 1976 farm plan showed, in relevant part, assets and
liabilities as follows:
Assets
Farm                              $ 160,000
House                                45,000
Hatleli personal
property                             48,500
Total Assets                      $ 253,500
Less: Total
Liabilities                        (208,072)
Net Worth                          $ 45,428
Liabilities
Hatleli Mortgage                  $ 144,000
House Mortgage                       15,572
Owed on Hatleli personal property    48,500
Total Liabilities                 $ 208,072

51.  As of January 3, 1977, when the Hatlelis agreed to the rescission of the
personal property, the Dahls' relevant net worth picture was as follows:
Assets
Farm              $ 165,000
House                45,000
Total Assets      $ 210,000
Less: Total
Liabilities        (168,145)
Net Worth          $ 41,855
Liabilities
Hatleli mortgage  $ 125,000
House mortgage       15,572
First Nat'l Bank
of Rushford          27,573
Total Liabilities $ 168,145

[*77]  52.  On January 26, 1977, Mr. Peterson wrote Mr. Dahl:

Please stop at our office some Monday in the near future to clarify the
following:

1.  If our FmHA money is to be used to buy livestock, how are you going to pay
the First National Bank back for the advance they made which we all felt was for
chattels, but apparently was used for farm downpayment?

2.  We would like to have a copy of the contract for deed on the farm.

Please take care of this in the near future (within two weeks).

53.  In February of 1977, Mr. Dahl requested that Mr. Peterson release from the
sba, funds to purchase dairy cows as listed in the farm plan.  This farm plan
covered the period from February 1, 1977 to February 1, 1978.The FmHA would not
release the funds.  A similar request was made by Mr. Dahl in order to purchase
the half interest in a tractor, which was also denied.

54.  On February 22, 1977, Mr. Dahl and Mr. Peterson met.  Mr. Peterson filled
out the asset and liability portion of another farm plan on Mr. Dahl's behalf.
This plan showed total assets of $ 246,300 and liabilities of $ 201,090.  The
Dahls' net worth was then $ 45,210.

55.  When Mr. Dahl and Mr. Peterson met at various [*78]  times during the month
of February 1977, Peterson still manifested a willingness to work with him by
urging plaintiffs to continue trying to sell their house to pay off the bank's
interim unsecured debt.  The Dahls' house was on the market and they were doing
their best to get it sold.

56.  On or about February 28, 1977, Mr. Peterson resigned his position with the
FmHA to begin a new life as a dairy farmer in Wisconsin.  He made no written
summary of the events which had transpired in regard to the Dahl matter nor did
he make any written recommendations for future action by his successors.  At
trial, Mr. Peterson testified that even with all the problems that transpired,
if the Dahls had repaid or secured the bank's interim loan (through the sale of
the golf course house or in another manner), he would have released or
recommended that the funds in the sba be released to the Dahls so that they
could start the dairy farming operation.

57.  On February 25, 1977, Mr. Gregory Kalinowski was appointed acting county
supervisor from February 28, 1977 to April 29, 1977.  This was a temporary
appointment because Mr. Kalinowski also was leaving the FmHA.  Mr. Kalinowski
actually left FmHA [*79]  employment on April 15, 1977.  Early in March, Mr.
Dahl and Mr. Kalinowski met in an attempt to get the problems resolved so that
some or all of the funds in the sba could be released.  Mr. Kalinowski reviewed
the incomplete running record, however, he never attempted to contact his
predecessor, Mr. Peterson.  He concluded that the bank's funds and the FmHA
funds were the same dollars and that they had been used for an improper
purpose--to buy real estate. He also erroneously concluded that the down payment
on the farm was larger.

58.  Throughout March of 1977, the bank continued to pressure Mr. Kalinowski
(just as it had done to Mr. Peterson in January and February) to release the
funds in the sba to the bank and to secure the FmHA loan by taking a second
mortgage on the Dahls' golf course house or by converting the operating loan to
a real estate loan.  Mr. Kalinowski continued to resist the bank's requests.

59.  On April 12, 1977, since he also was leaving the FmHA to pursue a career in
farming, Mr. Kalinowski summarized in the running record the history of the Dahl
matter as he understood it.  However, he made no recommendation as to how he
thought the Dahl matter should [*80]  be handled by his successors.  He also
testified at trial, the unilateral withdrawal of loan funds by the FmHA was an
extreme sanction, which he never before had heard of being used during his 3
years of FmHA experience.  He also concluded that the Dahl matter was not that
extreme or unusual a case to justify such an extreme action.

60.  Although both Mr. Peterson and Mr. Kalinowski felt that the plaintiffs'
debt structure had changed, at no time did they ever do a cash flow analysis or
examine the plaintiffs' net worth.

61.  On or about April 18, 1977, the district director, Mr. Bruce Bailey, after
reviewing the running record, decided that the state office should be notified
of the prior developments.  He did not contact Mr. Peterson or the Dahls.  In
his running record summary forwarding the entire Dahl file to the state
director, Mr. Bailey noted that the bank wanted the FmHA to take a second
mortgage on plaintiffs' house and eventually be repaid out of the proceeds from
a subsequent sale.  Mr. Bailey also commented on the "uncomfortable" position
the FmHA was in vis a vis the bank, and that the FmHA was in this uncomfortable
position due to the borrowers' foul up.  The blame [*81]  was placed squarely on
the Dahls.

62.  During the mid-1960's in connection with a previous FmHA loan made out of
the Preston, Minnesota FmHA office, Mr. Bailey and the Mr. Dahl had had some
disagreements.  It was clear that a certain amount of personal animosity existed
between the two men, although Bailey denied recommending withdrawal of the loan
funds based on any past disagreements.However, the rapidity with which this
action was taken by him suggests otherwise.

63.  On April 19, 1977, the file was reviewed in the state office by Mr. Leslie
Matts, Chief of Farmers Programs for Minnesota, then also Acting State Director
of the FmHA.  He replied to Mr. Bailey on that same day:

We have reviewed the file and also reviewed the circumstances with the National
Office.

We regret the way in which this case was handled and the comment from the County
Supervisor, however, he could not commit the U.S. Government to close the
transaction when conditions completely changed.

We would suggest that you further contact the borrower and the bank and assist
in any manner that you can so that the bank would get security on the proceeds
from the house and security in the real estate. There [*82]  is no legal way we
can release funds from supervised bank account to pay the bank for funds that
went into real estate.

The borrower should also be requested to co-sign a check withdrawing money from
the supervised bank account plus an additional amount for interest that has
accrued.

64.  After receiving these directions from the state office, Mr. Bailey wrote
plaintiffs on April 23, 1977, requesting that they co-sign a check which would
have the effect of voluntarily terminating the loan agreement and returning the
funds to the FmHA.  The plaintiffs did not comply with this request.

65.  On or about April 18, 1977, Mr. Spande contacted Mr. Bailey again to
discuss the Dahl problem now that he had assumed acting county supervisory
control over the Preston, Minnesota FmHA office.  He reiterated the entire
history of the case and reminded Mr. Bailey that the FmHA had agreed under Mr.
Peterson and Mr. Kalinowski to work with the Dahls and the bank.  Since the
Dahls had not yet been able to sell their golf course house, Mr. Spande
suggested again that the FmHA take a second mortgage on the house and then
release the funds in the sba to the bank.  Another alternative discussed was
[*83]  for the FmHA to convert the operating loan to a real estate loan and to
take a mortgage on the farm. Mr. Spande insisted that the FmHA had the
flexibility and discretionary authority to do either of the above.  Mr. Bailey,
however, categorically refused to consider either avenue.  From this discussion,
Mr. Spande was left with the impression that Mr. Bailey would do nothing further
to assist the Dahls and the bank.  Mr. Bailey further denied any FmHA legal
responsibility to the bank based on the November 12, 1976 "guarantee" letter.

66.  After the above conversation, Mr. Spande contacted the Dahls to obtain
security on the interim loan.  He asked the Dahls to give the bank a second
mortgage on the golf course house and to list the house with the bank's real
estate agent.  The Dahls readily agreed to both requests in order to secure the
bank and to get the FmHA operating loan funds released.  On April 29, 1977, the
bank took a second mortgage for $ 28,439.11 on the Dahls' golf course house.
This mortgage bore interest at the rate of 10 percent payable annually.  The
bank was then fully secured on its interim loan and thus no longer pressured the
FmHA.

67.  Shortly thereafter,  [*84]  Mr. Dahl requested an appointment with Mr.
Bailey.  On May 5, 1977, they met.  Mr. Dahl advised Mr. Bailey that the bank
was now secured and would no longer pressure the FmHA.  Since this impediment
had been removed and the parties were back in the position contemplated by the
October 4 farm plan, he requested the release of the operating loan funds so he
could begin his spring planting, buying of cows, and other farm activities.  At
this meeting, Mr. Bailey refused unequivocally to allow the plaintiffs to use
the loan proceeds.  It made no difference to Mr. Bailey that the plaintiffs had
secured the bank and that they were now in the same economic position presented
in the October 4, 1976 farm plan.

68.  When Mr. Dahl refused to sign a check that would have voluntarily
terminated the loan, Mr. Bailey informed him that he would forward the entire
file to the state director, with a recommendation that the loan be unilaterally
terminated. The file was forwarded on the same day, May 5, 1977.

69.  In his cover letter to the state office, Mr. Bailey recommended that the
state director use his discretionary authority to unilaterally withdraw the
funds from the supervised bank account,  [*85]  thereby terminating the loan.
This recommendation was based upon Mr. Bailey's incorrect observation that: (1)
the plaintiffs had attempted to misuse the funds and (2) that the plaintiffs'
debt picture had changed substantially because they now had a $ 27,000 liability
which had not existed when the October 4 farm plan had been executed.  This
recommendation ignored the fact that the $ 27,000 liability was fully secured in
the equity in the Dahls' house and that this equity always had been intended to
be used toward the purchase of the Hatleli real estate. The cover letter makes
clear that Mr. Bailey wanted out of the loan contract with the Dahls because
"after what had transpired we should not become re-involved." It also indicates
that Mr. Dahl may contact his Congressman; that Mr. Dahl "has problems with
people and situations"; that Mr. Dahl had a back injury and possibly should give
up farming; and it alludes to some "old history" of bad blood between the two
men.

70.  Unilateral terminations of loans are rarely done by the FmHA and only in
the most extreme and unusual circumstances.

71.  Supervised bank accounts may be closed by unilateral action of the state
director for [*86]  the following reasons: death of borrowers, borrower in
default, inactive borrower or when the borrower is paid up.  7 C.F.R.  §
1803.10(1)-(4) (1977).  None of the above apply to the facts in this case.

72.  On May 12, 1977, without any investigation, the state director wrote the
bank and unilaterally ordered the supervised bank closed and the funds sent to
the FmHA.  The bank complied on May 25, 1977.

73.  The $ 35,000.00 in the sba was applied as follows: $ 1,187.41 to interest,
$ 33,812.59 to principal.

74.  The promissory note from the Dahls to the FmHA provides:

Borrower agrees to use the loan evidenced hereby solely for purposes authorized
by the Government.

DEFAULT: Failure to pay when due any debt evidenced hereby or perform any
covenant or agreement hereunder shall constitute default under any other
instrument evidencing a debt of Borrower owing to or insured or Guaranteed by
the Government or securing or otherwise relating to such a debt; and default
under any such other instrument shall constitute default hereunder.  UPON ANY
SUCH DEFAULT, the Government at its option may declare all or any part of any
such indebtedness immediately due and payable.

75.  [*87]  The security agreement for the FmHA loan provides:

Default shall exist hereunder if Debtor fails to perform or discharge any
obligation or to pay promptly any indebtedness hereby secured or to observe or
perform any covenants or agreements herein or in any supplementary agreement
contained, or if any of Debtor's representations or warranties herein prove
false or misleading, or upon the death, bankruptcy, insolvency or incompetency
of Debtor or any person so called herein.

76.  The security agreement contains the following representations and imposes
the following duties on the Dahls, the debtors:

Statements contained in Debtor's loan application(s) are true and correct; and
Debtor will (1) use the loan funds for the purposes for which they were or are
advanced, (2) comply with such farm and home management plans as may be agreed
upon from time to time by Debtor and Secured Party, (3) care for and maintain
the collateral in a good and husbandlike manner, (4) insure the collateral in
such amounts and manner as may be required by Secured Party, and if Debtor fails
to do so, Secured Party, at its option, may procure such insurance, (5) permit
Secured Party to inspect the collateral [*88]  at any reasonable time, (6) not
abandon the collateral or encumber, conceal, remove, sell or otherwise dispose
of it or of any interest therein, or permit others to do so, without the prior
written consent of Secured Party, and (7) not permit the collateral to be levied
upon, injured or destroyed, or its value to be impaired, except by using
harvested crops in amounts necessary to care for livestock covered hereby.

77.  At the time the supervised bank account (sba) was closed, the Dahls were
not in default. They had already made the one payment which had come due.  The
next payment was not due until January 1, 1978.  They fulfilled all their duties
under the contract.

78.  No funds were ever withdrawn from the sba. The only requests for
withdrawals were for the purchase of cows and personal property as outlined in
the farm plan.  No misuse of federal funds took place since none were ever
expended from the sba.

79.  Despite the fact that the plaintiffs had repaid the bank approximately $
8,000, the FmHA would not release any funds to be used for operating loan
purposes until the bank became secured or was otherwise repaid on its interim
loan.

80.  From December 15, 1976 [*89]  until April 29, 1977, when the bank took the
second mortgage, the bank applied continuous pressure on successive FmHA
employees to repay the bank for the interim loan.  This pressure consisted of
phone calls as well as threats of legal action over the letter of November 12,
1976.

81.  The security agreement imposes on the FmHA (the secured party) the
following duty:

Secured Party will make or insure future loans or advances to Debtor to enable
him to raise or harvest farm corps or raise livestock or other animals, provided
funds are available and the Debtor meets all then current requirements imposed
by regulations of the Secured Party.

82.  The FmHA's actions in refusing to release the operating loan proceeds from
the sba were designed to protect the bank's interests, not the Dahls'.  The FmHA
made very little effort to work with the Dahls as provided in its regulations. 7
C.F.R.  § 1802.11 et seq. (1977).

83.  During the time from the loan closing on December 13, 1976 until the sba
was ordered closed on May 12, 1977, the FmHA, while not allowing any
withdrawals, never suggested depositing the funds in an interest-bearing
account.  The regulations specifically provided [*90]  for such a deposit of
loan funds "not required for immediate disbursement * * *." 7 C.F.R.  §
1803.1(f) (1977).

84.  On November 19, 1977, the plaintiffs paid the defendant $ 1,114.88 under
protest, as the FmHA would not release its security interest in the plaintiffs'
crops.  This payment was applied as follows: $ 45.88 to interest and $ 1,069.00
to principal, which closed out the entire Dahl transaction with the FmHA.

85.  As of December 13, 1976, the FmHA owed the Dahls its obligation to deal
with them as borrowers under its regulations, and as a contracting party under
its contract.

86.  The plaintiffs' witness on damages, Mr. Gary Zimmer, qualified as an expert
witness.  His qualifications included being a dairly farmer and growing up on a
dairy farm. Mr. Zimmer has a bachelors and masters degrees in animal science
from the University of Wisconsin and the University of Hawaii, respectively.  In
addition, he has taken courses at the University of Wisconsin in education, farm
management and economics.  For 5 years he taught courses in farm operation and
management at the Winona Area Technical Institute in Winona, Minnesota, where he
had Mr. Dahl as a student for 2 years.  [*91]  For several years he has done
private consulting on dairy nutrition and soil.

87.  As a basis for his damage computation, Mr. Zimmer used three Farm Business
Management reports summarizing actual yearly income and expenses of farms in
Fillmore and adjacent counties where the Dahl farm is located.  The reports were
chosen because of the large size of the sample and because of the detail used.
Also as a group, the reporting farmers had received a similar vocational
agricultural education as Mr. Dahl.  In addition, the farms were located in the
same area and the reporting farms included farms with similar size acreage.  Mr.
Zimmer factored in the size of the Dahl farm and the cows and machinery expected
to be purchased under the farm plan.

88.  Mr. Zimmer was a credible witness and his damage report is adopted on
income production except with the modifications outlined below and corrections
made to conform to the evidence.  This report provides a reasonable
approximation of the damages for the breach.

89.  The plaintiffs could have bought the 36 cattle for $ 700 each and the items
of machinery as listed in the farm plan in the spring of 1977.

90.  Nothing is allowed as an [*92]  element of damages for any market
appreciation in the value of the cows.

91.  It was foreseeable that the 36 cows would produce only 12,000 pounds of
milk in 1977 as contemplated in the farm plan.

92.  The plaintiffs evidenced the knowledge and ability to increase milk
production by at least 500 pounds/per cow/per year.  Thus 12,500 pounds and
13,000 pounds are the approximate measures to use for milk production per
cow/per year for 1978 and 1979, respectively.  Also, cows will produce more milk
once they are accustomed to the other cows in the herd.

93.  The plaintiff would have received the following price for milk:
1977  $ 9.00 CWT (per hundred lbs.)
1978  10.00 CWT
1979  11.57 CWT

94.  Gross income from milk sold would have been as follows:

1977 -- 36 cows X 12,000 lbs. milk X $ 9.00 CWT = $ 38,880.00

1978 -- 36 cows X 12,500 lbs. milk X $ 10.00 CWT = $ 45,000.00

1979 -- 36 cows X 13,000 lbs. milk X $ 11.57 CWT = $ 54,147.60

95.  The plaintiffs' expert did not deduct real estate taxes as a cost.  A
deduction should be made for 1977 and 1979 from income to reflect the actual
taxes deducted in those years.  No taxes were deducted on the [*93]  Dahls' 1978
income tax return.  However, $ 790 is the appropriate deduction for 1978.

96.  Plaintiff Eldon Dahl earned the following net income in non-farm jobs which
he would not have earned had the defendant performed its contract.
1977       $ 304.06
1978       2,170.85
1979       7,923.00
Total   $ 10,397.91

97.  That plaintiff Jeanette Dahl earned the following net income in non-farm
jobs which she would have earned whether or not the FmHA loaned money to the
plaintiffs:
1977   $ 5,210
1978     2,734
1979     5,876

98.  The plaintiffs reported actual farm income as follows:
1977               ($ 4,655.18)
1978                     91.16
1979              ($ 15,824.00)
Total farm income ($ 20,388.02)

99.  In computing actual farm income, plaintiffs were allowed depreciation
deductions as follows:
1977   $ 3,216.00
1978     3,416.00
1979     3,987.43

In each of these years, $ 3,216.00 represents a deduction for an allocation to
depreciable assets of the principal price paid for the farm. The plaintiffs'
expert made no corresponding deduction.  Therefore, $ 3,216 per year (total $
9,648) must be added back to plaintiffs' actual farm income.

100.  The following summary [*94]  outlines a reasonable basis for the award of
damages.

                                    $ 35,889.89

[*95]  101.The plaintiffs have been damaged by the defendant's breach of
contract and abuse of administrative discretion.  The plaintiffs are entitled to
a judgment in the sum of $ 35,889.89.  This sum represents the amount of damages
that are reasonable and were foreseeable by the Government.  To award damages
beyond a 3-year duration would be too remote and speculative.  However, damages
awarded for the 3-year duration of 1977-79 are foreseeable, appropriate, and
reasonable under the circumstances of this case.

CONCLUSION OF LAW

Based upon the foregoing findings and opinion, the court concludes that the
plaintiffs are entitled to recover in this farm operating loan contract matter
the sum of $ 35,889.89 and judgment is entered accordingly.


                             391 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The American Banker

CONSUMER BANKING: LENDING - A Mortgage-Heavy Kansas Thrift Eases Burdens with
Outsourcing

                             March 29, 1993, Monday

By RANDY WELCH


BANKERS WHO THINK they've seen enough of outsourcing might want to take another
look.

Some of the old objections, such as 10-year contracts that cost banks heavily in
the later years, are being washed away. Bankers had feared that giving up their
bank's data processing guts meant giving up its soul. But such fears are less
relevant these days. Outsourcers now often focus on a specific niche that does
not threaten the central processing operation.

Take the case of Farm and Home Savings of Missouri. The $3.5 billion savings and
loan, with 48 branches scattered across Missouri, Texas, and Kansas, has long
been heavily weighted toward residential mortgages. Its mortgage bank, based in
Houston, services more than $5 billion in mortgages and originated $865 million
in residential first mortgages in 1992.

When Farm and Home decided to broaden its product line, it turned to
outsourcing. It offers mutual funds, annuities, home equity and other consumer
loans from third parties, and is looking into adding insurance products,
small-business accounts, and trust services.

Farm and Home is "moving away from the very narrowly defined product line
associated with a traditional thrift - CDs and first mortgages - to broaden our
relationships with the customers we have, and attract new customers," said John
Morton, Farm and Home's president and chief executive.

"Our idea is to find state-of-the-art products that offer very high levels of
customer service, without having to invest a fortune in supporting these
products," he added.

The typical Farm and Home customer is an older, loyal client likely to stop in
at the bank lobby to sip coffee and read the newspaper. Few of the banks have
drive-in windows. The average branch boasts more than $65 million in deposits,
and the average branch employee has been with the bank for seven years.

"The customer base is absolutely incredible. The culture of the company is to
cater to this customer segment. We plan to broaden from the 60-year-olds to the
45-year-olds, who are more inclined to need loans. But those are the segments
that we want to serve real well." said Mr. Morton, a former executive vice
president with Maryland National Bank.

For that reason, the thrift's chief priority is to have top-quality products,
with the capacity to grow. Outsourcing offers both.

But it's "also a way to keep our expenses low," Mr. Morton said. "In my view,
the margins in the financial industry have been at an all-time high for the past
few years. We can't depend on that for the future, so we want to stay a low-cost
producer of services."

Farm and Home's consumer loans, for example, are maintained by CLS Corp. of Blue
Bell, Pa.

To begin processing a loan, a Farm and Home employee takes the loan application
and faxes it to CLS.

"That's no different than if we sent it by fax to our own operating center," Mr.
Morton pointed out.

The CLS computers recognize the application is from Farm and Home, then directly
access the best credit bureau in the Missouri area to check the customer's
credit record. Systems then "scrub" the application by checking the applicant's
identifications, calculating the debt service ratios for the proposed loan, and
comparing it to Farm and Home's lending guidelines.

Farm and Home officers then decide whether to make the loan. If the bank says
yes, CLS computers then order appraisals and title searches, and begin servicing
the loan. Farm and Home makes the loans basically for the cost of training its
officers, sending a fax, and paying a fee to CLS.

The relationship between Farm and Home and CLS reflects the latest trend in
management - the "virtual corporation." Ladd Willis, an executive vice president
with First Manhattan Consulting Group, explained the concept as "a corporation
that comes together by buying services from different players to service its
marketplace. It buys the things it can't add strategic value to."

CLS started in 1986 in the Philadelphia suburbs.

Chairman Norman Bitterman, a former senior vice president and head of lending
with Meritor Savings Bank, began the company on the assumption that more
institutions would want to enter consumer lending and would need back-office
help.  "As with any fundamentally new idea, it takes longer than one anticipates
to prove the concept," said Harry Weitzell, president of CLS. "Bankers are not
typically early adopters. But it has really taken off the past two years."

CLS was helped by an Resolution Trust Corp. contract which, Mr. Weitzell said,
"gave us the scale to be a true national servicer. We are now servicing in
virtually every state."

CLS services more than $1 billion in consumer loans for 60 financial
institutions. In November the company entered a joint marketing agreement with
Electronic Data Systems Corp., Plano, Tex. As part of the pact, EDS bought a 10%
stake in CLS.

The two companies will integrate their systems for servicing consumer loan
portfolios and mortgages, offering the products separately or as a package.

Mr. Weitzell, who was a friend and business colleague of Mr. Morton's at
Maryland National, offered a long list of advantages available through his
company, including lower costs for banks, improved loan quality, faster decision
making, and freedom from maintaining regulatory compliance.

The fact that CLS is servicing a loan is also transparent to the customer.

Any correspondence to borrowers goes out on the stationery of the local bank.
Customers who call the 800 service number know only that it is "customer
service," not that it is a separate company.

Mr. Willis of First Manhattan said most of the outsourcing's perceived
negatives, though based on past experience, are fading in importance. Banks that
once lost money on the back end of 10-year contracts are smarter now, he pointed
out.

"There are legitimate issues to raise, which were not properly dealt with when
the contracts were first structured," said Mr. Willis. "But now, there should be
as much ability to control future cost structure and processing capability as
you can achieve in-house."

Mr. Morton added a distinction between outsourcing a bank's operations center
and outsourcing individual products.

"Product providers don't have the large exit penalties," he noted. "Big
operating and DP system outsourcers do, because they've got a huge front end
investment in the institution and they want to recoup it. When you outsource
your data center, you pay a big price to exercise your right to leave."

Mr. Morton does want to eventually get information from product providers onto
Farm and Home's monthly customer statements, "So we are not just (service)
providers, but are managing the information that goes back to them," he said.

But across the board, he appeared to agree with Mr. Weitzell's attitudes on
outsourcing.

"When outsourcing developed," Mr. Morton said, "the only people that used it
were troubled institutions. That clearly has changed. People should concentrate
on the two or three things they add value to. How much value-added can a bank
bring to its back office on consumer lending? That's like every Ford dealer
having its own manufacturing plant."

SECTION: MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES; Pg. 12A

LENGTH: 1204 words

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Morton photo, chart

                      Copyright 1993 American Banker, Inc.


                             392 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                       The Daily Record (Baltimore, MD.)

                           November 27, 2001, Tuesday

BYLINE: By a Daily Record Legal Affairs Writer

SECTION: Pg. 1Bmid.inf

LENGTH: 296 words


A Caroline County dairy farmer can proceed with his claim that the government
discriminated against him on the basis of age in denying him a farm operating
loan and other services, a federal judge in Baltimore has ruled.     Farmer
James A. Faulkner claims that representatives of the USDA's Farm Service Agency
told him in late 1996 and early 1997 that he was "getting too old to fool with
cows" and that he "maybe ought to be thinking about securing a different line of
work." At the time, Faulkner was 56.     While the defense claims Faulkner never
completed the loan application and never submitted a required legal description
or deed to the property, Senior U.S. District Judge Alexander Harvey II last
week declined to enter summary judgment for either side.     Faulkner "should be
permitted to present to the jury his claim that there existed direct evidence of
discrimination on the part of representatives of the FSA," Harvey wrote. "It
will be for the jury to determine whether the statements in question were more
than stray or isolated remarks and whether a sufficient nexus existed between
the remarks in question and the adverse actions" taken by the FSA
representatives.     Harvey did grant the defense motion on one point,
dismissing Faulkner's claim that he had been discriminated against because of
his marital status.     Faulkner was going through a divorce at the time he was
seeking the operating loan, and the divorce had a bearing on his failure to
supply the documents the FSA representatives requested regarding the security
for the loan. However, there was no credible evidence of discrimination based on
marital status, Harvey wrote.     The published memorandum and order are
available as RecordFax #1-1119-40 (22 pages).

LOAD-DATE: November 27, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 2001 The Daily Record Co.

                           Greeley Tribune (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 5, 2013 Tuesday

BRIEF: USDA simplifying guaranteed farm loans

BYLINE: Greeley Tribune, Colo.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 172 words


March 05--The U.S. Department of Agriculture announced last week an interim rule
that sets thresholds on the interest rates charged by lenders on guaranteed farm
ownership and operating loans.

According to USDA officials, the changes will amend guidelines for interest
rates and establish new policies that clearly set the maximum interest rate
lenders may charge to borrowers.

USDA's Farm Service Agency guaranteed loans reduce the risk of loss to lenders
-- banks, farm credit institutions and credit unions -- by guaranteeing up to 95
percent of the loss of principal and interest on a loan.

By reducing a lender's risk, borrowers benefit from a lower rate.

USDA officials say the improvements in the new rule will make credit pricing
procedures easier to follow and improve compliance for lenders.

To learn more, call the Weld County Farm Service Agency office at (970)
356-8097.

___ (c)2013 the Greeley Tribune (Greeley, Colo.) Visit the Greeley Tribune
(Greeley, Colo.) at www.greeleytribune.com Distributed by MCT Information
Services

LOAD-DATE: March 7, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ACC-NO: 20130305-GY-BRF-USDA-simplifying-guaranteed-farm-loans-0305-20130305

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: GY


                         Copyright 2013 Greeley Tribune


                             396 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                             National Mortgage News

                                October 25, 1993

FmHA Slated To Disappear?

BYLINE: By TED CORNWELL

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 380 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


As part of a broad restructuring of the Department of Agriculture, the Farmers
Home Administration may become a thing of the past.

Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy has recommended that FmHA programs be divided
and assigned to new agencies as part of a "reinvention" and consolidation of
USDA headquarters.  The USDA's 43 agencies will be consolidated into 30 agencies
centered around six administrative units.

The Farm Credit Administration, which administers the Farm Credit System, will
not be affected by the reorganization.

Under the proposal, FmHA farm programs would become part of a new farm service
agency.  Housing and community development programs would be assigned to a rural
development service agency.

Other FmHA programs would become part of a rural business development and
cooperative development agency and the rural utilities service agency.

The Federal Crop Insurance Corp. will also be merged into the farm service
agency.

The USDA has often been criticized because of its baffling network of offices
and programs.  Almost every county in the U.S. has a USDA field office.

The Clinton administration has proposed reducing the number of field offices
from 3,700 to 2,485.

The FmHA, often referred to as "the lender of last resort," provides a
significant source of credit for rural homeowners and farmers who have trouble
obtaining conventional credit.

In recent years, the FmHA has increasingly relied on loan guarantees to augment
its direct loan programs.  Under most of the guarantees, the FmHA provides
insured loans that are originated by private lenders.

In fiscal 1993, which ended Sept. 30, the FmHA guaranteed $ 539 million in
single-family housing loans.  The FmHA also provided $ 1.29 billion in direct
rural housing loans.

The FmHA also guaranteed $ 1 billion in farm operating loans and $ 490 million
in farm ownership loans in fiscal 1993.

Speaking during a rural development conference earlier this month.  Secretary
Espy said the USDA will attempt to be a partner with local governments,
nonprofit agencies and the private sector.

"The days of massive federal budgets for development initiatives are long gone.
I see the federal government as part of a larger whole -- a drive shaft in the
giant economic engine," he said.

LOAD-DATE: November 05, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1993 National Thrift News, Inc.


                             397 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                    June 19, 1989, MONDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

S&LS HERE SHOW MIXED RESULTS

BYLINE: David Nicklaus Of the Post-Dispatch Staff

SECTION: BUSINESS PLUS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 494 words


First-quarter results were mixed at the 23 savings and loan associations
operating in St. Louis and St. Louis County. Twelve of the S&Ls posted higher
profits, five posted lower profits and at least three lost money. Those
reporting losses were Clayton Savings and Loan Association, Public Service
Savings and Loan Association and St. Louis County Federal Savings and Loan
Association.  Three other S&Ls - Missouri Savings Association, Cass Federal
Savings and Loan Association and New Age Federal Savings and Loan Association -
did not provide their profit-or-loss figures. Missouri Savings and Cass Federal
are already insolvent; Cass Federal has been placed in conservatorship by the
Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., and Missouri Savings is being run by new
management brought in by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.  S&Ls reporting
profit declines, and the comparison with the first quarter of 1988, were:
American Home, down 73 percent; Farm & Home, down 36 percent; Germania, down 50
percent; Pulaski, down 25 percent; and Reliance Federal, down 28 percent.  The
S&Ls' recent balance sheets show that most of them would not have enough capital
to comply with standards in the S&L bailout bill passed last week by the U.S.
House of Representatives.  The bill would require a capital-to-assets ratio of 6
percent. Only seven S&Ls operating in St. Louis currently show that level of
capital, and only three of those - American Home, Farm & Home and First Federal
- currently use generally accepted accounting principles, which are required
under the bill.  The other institutions use more liberal regulatory accounting
rules that were created for S&Ls in the early 1980s.  Results for other S&Ls in
the metropolitan area will be reported in a future Financial Institution Watch
feature.

LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1993

LANGUAGE: English

GRAPHIC: Graphic; TABLE/CHART....St. Louis Savings and Loan Results...Source:
Greater St.  Louis League of Savings Institutions and individual institutions.

                            Agfirst Farm Credit Bank

                                  1901 Main St
                            COLUMBIA,  SC 29201-2443
                                 United States

* * * * * * * * * * COMMUNICATIONS * * * * * * * * * *
TELEPHONE: Main Phone: 1-800-8747737
URL: Home Page: http://www.agfirst.com/
E-MAIL: smmu@agfirst.com

* * * * * * * * * * COMPANY INFORMATION * * * * * * * * * *
INCORPORATION DATE: 1916
LEGAL STATUS: Private
OPERATING STATUS: Active

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

   AgFirst Farm Credit Bank (the Bank or AgFirst), incorporated in 1916, is a
member-owned cooperative that provides credit and credit-related services to
qualified borrowers. The Bank is chartered to serve the states of Pennsylvania,
Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, West Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina,
Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Mississippi, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and
portions of Ohio, Tennessee, Kentucky and Louisiana. AgFirst is a member of the
Farm Credit System, which is an agricultural lending organization in the United
States. AgFirst is a lending institution in the Farm Credit System (the System),
which is an across the nation network of cooperatively owned banks, associations
and related service organizations. The System specializes in providing financing
and related services to qualified borrowers for agricultural and rural purposes.
The Bank provides funding and services to about 19 affiliated Agricultural
Credit Associations in 15 eastern states and Puerto Rico. It provides financing
to farmers, ranchers, rural homeowners and agribusinesses. AgFirst has a Capital
Markets Unit that purchases and sells loan participations and syndications.

   Lending Activities

   AgFirst's loan portfolio consists primarily of direct loans to District
Associations (Direct Notes), loan participations/syndications purchased,
Correspondent Lending loans (primarily first lien rural residential mortgages),
and loans to other financing institutions (OFIs). The Bank's loan portfolio,
which includes purchased interests in loans, has been segmented by the various
loan types, such as Direct Notes, production and intermediate-term loans, loans
to cooperatives, processing and marketing loans, farm-related business loans,
rural residential real estate loans, communication loans, energy loans, water
and waste disposal loans, international loans, lease receivables, loans to OFIs
and other (including Mission Related). Real estate mortgage loans are offered to
purchase farm real estate, refinance existing mortgages, construct various
facilities used in agricultural operations, or purchase other rural
residential/lifestyle real estate for both full-time and part-time farmers.

   Production and intermediate-term loans are offered for operating funds,
equipment and other purposes. Loans to cooperatives are provided for any
cooperative purpose other than for communication, energy, and water and waste
disposal. Processing and marketing loans are for operations to process or market
the products produced by a farmer, rancher, or producer or harvester of aquatic
products, or by a cooperative. Communication loans are offered primarily to
finance rural communication companies. Energy loans are offered primarily to
finance electric generation, transmission and distribution systems serving rural
areas. Water and waste disposal loans are offered primarily to finance water and
waste disposal systems serving rural areas. International loans are provided for
loans or credit enhancements to other banks to support the export of United
States agricultural commodities or supplies. Long-term real estate mortgage
loans have original maturities up to 30 years. All short- and intermediate-term
loans for agricultural production or operating purposes have maturities of 10
years or less.

   Investment Activities

   AgFirst's investments consist primarily of mortgage-backed securities (MBSs)
collateralized by the United States Government or the United States agency
guaranteed residential and commercial mortgages. Its held-to-maturity
investments consist of Mission Related Investments, acquired primarily under the
Rural Housing Mortgage-Backed Securities (RHMS) and Rural America Bond (RAB)
pilot programs. The available-for-sale investments are non-agency collateralized
mortgage obligations (CMOs) and asset backed securities (ABSs). As of December
31, 2014, its total investments amounted to $7.6 billion.

   Sources of Funds

   AgFirst, unlike commercial banks and other depository institutions, obtains
funds for its lending operations primarily from the sale of Systemwide Debt
Securities issued jointly by the System banks through the Funding Corporation.
It issues Systemwide Debt Securities, including Federal Farm Credit Banks
Consolidated Systemwide Bonds, Federal Farm Credit Banks Consolidated Systemwide
Discount Notes, Federal Farm Credit Banks Consolidated Systemwide Master Notes,
Federal Farm Credit Banks Global Debt Securities and Federal Farm Credit Banks
Consolidated Systemwide Medium-Term Notes.

                              Colonial Farm Credit

                          7104 Mechanicsville Turnpike
                           Mechanicsville,  VA 23111
                                 United States

* * * * * * * * * * COMMUNICATIONS * * * * * * * * * *
TELEPHONE: (804) 746-4581
FAX: (804) 746-9627
URL: www.colonialfarmcredit.com

* * * * * * * * * * COMPANY INFORMATION * * * * * * * * * *
EMPLOYEES: 175

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *

   Colonial Farm Credit is part of the nationwide Farm Credit System, a
financial cooperative owned by its member-borrowers since 1916. Our primary
function is to provide loans, including:   Farm and country home loans Loans for
land purchase, home construction, and improvements Loans for buildings,
machinery, livestock and equipment Production loans for both full-time and
part-time farmers Loans for ag-related businesses Wood industry loans for
operating capital, timberland acquisition, standing timber   Our cooperative
structure means that a portion of the profits generated from our lending
activity is returned to our borrowers in the form of patronage refunds. These
patronage refunds are based on the proportion of interest earned on an
individual loan. This significantly reduces the cost of borrowing for our
customers.  The team at Farm Credit are financial professionals with the
experience and knowledge to provide the help you need when you need it. And we
know agriculture and country living. We're locally operated by people you know
and trust.  Our combination of competitive rates, personal service and extensive
local knowledge is unmatched in the financial world. Just contact us and see
what we can do for you.  We serve 50 counties in Virginia and Maryland, with
offices conveniently located near you.

* * * * * * * * * * FINANCIALS * * * * * * * * * *

REVENUE: USD 17,500,000
